questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a BMI of 30 kg/m² is diagnosed with stage 1 hypertension. He is advised to lose weight as part of non-pharmacological management. How much reduction in SBP per 10 kg of weight loss can he expect?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 5–20 mm Hg

 

  • Weight reduction is a crucial lifestyle modification for blood pressure (BP) control.
  • Studies have demonstrated that for every 10 kg of weight loss, there is an approximate reduction of 5–20 mm Hg in systolic blood pressure (SBP).
  • The impact varies based on individual physiology, baseline BP, dietary habits, and physical activity levels.
  • Weight reduction improves cardiovascular health by:
    • Decreasing peripheral vascular resistance
    • Improving insulin sensitivity
    • Reducing sympathetic nervous system activity
    • Lowering plasma renin and aldosterone levels
  • Thus, weight loss is strongly recommended as a first-line non-pharmacological intervention for hypertension management.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Weight reduction is an effective non-pharmacological strategy for managing hypertension, with an expected SBP reduction of 5–20 mm Hg per 10 kg of weight loss.

 

Lifestyle modification to manage hypertension:

questions.text:
A lumbar puncture is performed on a child with suspected meningitis, and CSF analysis reveals the following findings:

 

Pressure: Increased

 

Leukocytes: 10-500 Lymphocytes

 

Protein: 100-500 mg/dL (high)

 

Glucose: < 40 mg/dL (low)

 

Based on the CSF findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tubercular Meningitis

 

  • The classic CSF profile for TBM is increased pressure, lymphocytic predominance, high protein, and low glucose.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Viral Meningitis: Would have normal/high glucose and lymphocytes.

 

Option C. Bacterial Meningitis: Would have neutrophilic predominance.

 

Option D. Brain Abscess: Has normal glucose levels.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: A 5-year-old girl with Systemic JIA presenting with fever and rash
A 9-year-old boy with Oligoarthritis affecting 3 joints
A 12-year-old girl with Psoriatic arthritis and dactylitis
A 16-year-old male with Acute Rheumatic Fever (ARF) presenting with polyarthritis

questions.text: According to the ILAR criteria for Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis (JIA), which of the following patients would not be classified under JIA?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A 16-year-old male with Acute Rheumatic Fever (ARF) presenting with polyarthritis

 

  • The ILAR criteria define Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis (JIA) as arthritis in one or more joints, with onset before 16 years of age and persisting for at least 6 weeks.
  • Acute Rheumatic Fever (ARF) is NOT a subtype of JIA because:
    • ARF arthritis is migratory, transient, and self-limiting.
    • ARF is associated with Group A Streptococcal infection.
    • Unlike JIA, ARF does not cause chronic joint inflammation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A 5-year-old girl with Systemic JIA presenting with fever and rash: Presents with fever, salmon-colored rash, arthritis, hepatosplenomegaly.

 

Option B. A 9-year-old boy with Oligoarthritis affecting 3 joints: Involves ≤ 4 joints and is the most common JIA subtype.

 

Option C. A 12-year-old girl with Psoriatic arthritis and dactylitis: Associated with dactylitis, nail pitting, and family history of psoriasis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis (JIA) includes several chronic arthritis subtypes, while Acute Rheumatic Fever is an inflammatory, post-streptococcal condition that does not cause chronic joint disease.

questions.text:
A 34-year-old man presents with abdominal pain and vomiting for 4 hours. He has been confused and tired since the onset of symptoms. He has a history of type 1 diabetes mellitus, managed with a basal-bolus insulin regimen.

 

Investigations:

 

  • Random blood glucose: 18.4 mmol/L (Normal: 4.0–7.0)
  • Urine dipstick:
    • Glucose: +++
    • Ketones: ++
    • Blood: Negative
    • Leucocytes: Negative

 

Which is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) IV 0.9% NaCl

 

  • The patient presents with classic features of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA):
  • Abdominal pain and vomiting (common in DKA)
  • Hyperglycemia (18.4 mmol/L)
  • Ketonaemia (urine ketones: ++)
  • Altered mental status (confusion, fatigue)
  • Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) occurs due to insulin deficiency and subsequent lipolysis, producing free fatty acids which are converted to ketone bodies, leading to metabolic acidosis.

 

First-line Management:

 

Initial priority: IV 0.9% NaCl (1L over 1 hour) for:

 

  • Rapid intravascular volume expansion
  • Reduction of hyperglycemia (by dilution and improved renal clearance)
  • Correction of electrolyte imbalances (especially potassium shifts)

 

Fluid replacement is the cornerstone of DKA management because:

 

  • Hypovolemia is a major contributor to mortality in DKA.
  • Rehydration alone can reduce blood glucose significantly, even before insulin administration.

 

Order of DKA Management (ABCs):

 

  1. Airway, Breathing, Circulation (ABCs) – Assess and stabilize.
  2. Fluids first: IV 0.9% NaCl (1L over 1 hour).
  3. Insulin infusion: Start 0.1 unit/kg/hour IV insulin after initial fluid resuscitation.
  4. Potassium replacement: Based on initial serum potassium.
  5. Dextrose: Add 5% dextrose to IV fluids once blood glucose falls to <14 mmol/L to prevent hypoglycemia.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. 0.01 unit/kg/h IV insulin: Too low a dose to treat DKA effectively. The standard is 0.1 unit/kg/h.

 

Option B. 0.1 unit/kg/h IV insulin: Correct insulin dose, but fluids must be started first to prevent circulatory collapse and electrolyte imbalances.

 

Option C. IV 5% dextrose: Only indicated after blood glucose falls to <14 mmol/L during treatment to prevent hypoglycemia, not as the initial step.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Diabetic Ketoacidosis (DKA) Management Priorities:
    1. First-line: IV 0.9% NaCl (to correct hypovolemia)
    2. Second-line: IV insulin (0.1 unit/kg/h) (to stop ketone production)
    3. Add Potassium: If serum K+ <5.5 mmol/L before insulin
    4. Add Dextrose: When glucose <14 mmol/L to prevent hypoglycemia
  • Complication Monitoring: Watch for cerebral edema, hypokalemia, and hypoglycemia.

questions.text:
Consider the following statements about the treatment of nicotine use disorder:

 

Statement 1: Nicotine replacement therapy (NRT) should always be used alone and never in combination with other pharmacologic treatments.

 

Statement 2: Varenicline acts as a partial agonist at the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor, reducing cravings and withdrawal symptoms.

 

Statement 3: Bupropion is contraindicated in patients with a history of seizures or eating disorders.

 

Statement 4: Behavioral therapy is a first-line treatment for nicotine dependence and enhances long-term abstinence rates.

 

Which of the following is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2, 3 and 4 are correct

 

Statement 2. Varenicline acts as a partial agonist at the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor, reducing cravings and withdrawal symptoms:

 

  • Varenicline is a partial agonist at the α4β2 nicotinic acetylcholine receptor, which helps by reducing cravings and withdrawal symptoms while also blocking nicotine’s rewarding effects, making it an effective smoking cessation aid.

 

Statement 3. Bupropion is contraindicated in patients with a history of seizures or eating disorders:

 

  • Bupropion lowers seizure threshold, so it is contraindicated in patients with epilepsy or conditions predisposing to seizures, such as anorexia nervosa and bulimia (due to electrolyte disturbances increasing seizure risk).

 

Statement 4. Behavioral therapy is a first-line treatment for nicotine dependence and enhances long-term abstinence rates: 

 

  • Behavioral therapy is an essential part of smoking cessation treatment, often used alone or in combination with pharmacotherapy to improve long-term abstinence rates.

 

Other Option:

 

Statement 1: Nicotine replacement therapy (NRT) should always be used alone and never in combination with other pharmacologic treatments.

 

  • NRT can be used in combination with other treatments. In fact, using long-acting NRT (e.g., nicotine patch) with short-acting NRT (e.g., gum, lozenge, inhaler) is more effective than using a single form of NRT.
  • Varenicline or bupropion can also be combined with NRT in some cases, although caution is required.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • First-line treatments for nicotine use disorder include NRT, varenicline, and bupropion, often combined with behavioral therapy for maximum efficacy. Bupropion is contraindicated in seizure-prone individuals, and combination NRT (patch + short-acting form) is more effective than monotherapy.

choices.text: Granulosa cell tumor of the ovary
Invasive lobular carcinoma of the breast

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is undergoing routine cancer screening. She has no significant gynecologic history but is at increased risk for which of the following malignancies?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Granulosa cell tumor of the ovary

 

  • Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is associated with an increased risk of sex cord-stromal tumors, particularly ovarian granulosa cell tumors, which secrete estrogen and can cause early puberty or postmenopausal bleeding.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endometrial carcinoma: Incorrect. Linked to Lynch syndrome (MLH1, MSH2/6 mutations), not PJS.

 

Option C. Serous ovarian carcinoma: Incorrect. Typically associated with BRCA1/2 mutations, not PJS.

 

Option D. Invasive lobular carcinoma of the breast: Incorrect. Linked to CDH1 mutations, not STK11 mutations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Peutz-Jeghers syndrome increases the risk of sex cord-stromal tumors (e.g., granulosa cell tumors) due to STK11 mutations.

 

Why Granulosa Cell Tumor is Most Strongly Associated:

 

  • Ovarian sex cord-stromal tumors are classic extraintestinal neoplasms seen in PJS.
  • Most common among them: granulosa cell tumors, especially the juvenile type.
  • These are estrogen-producing tumors, which may present with:
    • Precocious puberty (in girls)
    • Menstrual irregularities or postmenopausal bleeding (in adults)

       

This association is distinctive for PJS and is one of the most consistent gynecologic malignancies in these patients.

 

Most common malignancies in PJS:

questions.text: Identify the type of plexus marked in the picture with a blue arrow:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Venous

 

  • Venous is the correct answer. Woodruff's plexus is primarily a venous plexus. It is located in the posterior part of the nasal cavity, near the inferior meatus, and is a significant site for posterior nosebleeds, especially in adults.

 

 

  • Woodruff’s plexus is a plexus of veins situated inferior to posterior end of inferior turbinate. It is a site of posterior epistaxis in adults.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Arterial: Woodruff's plexus is not primarily arterial. It does receive some arterial supply, but this is not its defining characteristic.

 

Option C. Both A&B: While Woodruff's plexus does receive some arterial supply, it is predominantly venous, making this option incorrect.

 

Option D. AV Malformation: An Arterio-Venous (AV) malformation is an abnormal connection between arteries and veins. Woodruff's plexus is not an AV malformation but rather a venous plexus that can be a site of significant bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Woodruff’s plexus is primarily a venous plexus (Option B) located in the posterior part of the nasal cavity.
  • It is known for being a potential site of significant posterior nosebleeds, particularly in adults.
  • Understanding its venous nature is important in the clinical management of posterior epistaxis.

questions.text:
A 51-year-old man presents with difficulty speaking fluently for 3 hours, but his comprehension is intact. He also has left-sided weakness and homonymous hemianopia.

 

Investigations:

 

  • CT Angiography:

 

 

What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) IV thrombolysis and thrombectomy

 

  • This patient has an acute ischemic stroke affecting the anterior circulation (likely right MCA territory):
    • Broca’s aphasia (non-fluent speech, intact comprehension) → Suggests dominant frontal lobe involvement (right MCA in a left-handed person or left MCA in a right-handed person).
    • Left-sided hemiparesis and homonymous hemianopia → Suggests contralateral MCA stroke.
    • CT angiography shows proximal anterior circulation occlusion, indicating a large vessel occlusion (LVO).

 

Acute Stroke Management Timeline:

 

  • IV thrombolysis (alteplase) within 4.5 hours of symptom onset
  • Mechanical thrombectomy within 6 hours for large vessel occlusion (LVO)
  • If stroke is in the posterior circulation (basilar artery), thrombectomy can be performed up to 24 hours

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Carotid artery endarterectomy: Indicated for symptomatic carotid stenosis (70–99%), but not used in the acute phase of stroke.

 

Option B. Clopidogrel: Used for secondary stroke prevention, but not for acute management.

 

Option C. IV thrombolysis: Appropriate for smaller strokes, but large vessel occlusion (LVO) requires thrombectomy for optimal outcomes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Acute ischemic stroke due to a large vessel occlusion in the anterior circulation (MCA) requires IV thrombolysis (if within 4.5 hours) and mechanical thrombectomy (if within 6 hours) for best functional recovery.

choices.text: CD4:CD8 ratio >10 and loss of CD7 expression
Presence of Bence-Jones proteins in urine
Decreased CD19+ B-cell population in peripheral blood

questions.text: A 64-year-old man presents with diffuse erythroderma, pruritus, and thickened skin over several months. Physical examination reveals generalized lymphadenopathy and lichenified plaques on his torso and extremities. Peripheral blood smear shows circulating atypical lymphocytes with cerebriform nuclei. Which of the following laboratory findings is most characteristic of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) CD4:CD8 ratio >10 and loss of CD7 expression

 

  • This patient has Sézary Syndrome, a leukemic variant of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma (CTCL) characterized by erythroderma, circulating Sézary cells (cerebriform nuclei), and generalized lymphadenopathy.
  • Sézary cells are atypical CD4+ T cells that express an abnormally high CD4:CD8 ratio (>10:1) and frequently lose CD7 expression, a hallmark of CTCL.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CD5 and Cyclin D1 positivity: Incorrect. Seen in mantle cell lymphoma (t11;14, Cyclin D1 overexpression), not Sézary syndrome.

 

Option C. Presence of Bence-Jones proteins in urine: Incorrect. Suggests multiple myeloma, which does not present with erythroderma.

 

Option D. Decreased CD19+ B-cell population in peripheral blood: Incorrect. Sézary syndrome is a T-cell disorder and does not cause a reduction in B cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Sézary Syndrome is a leukemic variant of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma with a high CD4:CD8 ratio, loss of CD7, and circulating Sézary cells with cerebriform nuclei.

questions.text:
A 34-year-old woman with a history of postpartum hemorrhage undergoes thromboelastography (TEG) analysis for abnormal bleeding. The results show:

  • R time: Prolonged
  • K time: Normal
  • α-angle: Normal
  • MA: Normal

Which of the following is the most likely explanation for these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Factor VIII deficiency

 

  • R time represents the time until clot formation begins and is prolonged in coagulation factor deficiencies.
  • Normal K time, α-angle, and MA indicate normal fibrinogen and platelet function.
  • This pattern suggests hemophilia A (factor VIII deficiency) or other clotting factor deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Deficiency of fibrinogen: Incorrect. Hypofibrinogenemia would prolong K time and reduce α-angle.

 

Option C. Platelet dysfunction: Incorrect. Platelet dysfunction would cause a reduced MA, which is normal here.

 

Option D. Hyperfibrinolysis: Incorrect. Hyperfibrinolysis would show an increased LY30 (not provided).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A prolonged R time with normal fibrinogen and platelet function suggests a coagulation factor deficiency, such as hemophilia A.

 

TEG Interpretation & Treatment

questions.text: A researcher studying caloric restriction and longevity finds that nutrient deprivation increases autophagy in cultured cells. This effect is abolished when cells are treated with an inhibitor targeting a key regulatory pathway. Which of the following pathways is most likely involved in autophagy suppression in nutrient-rich conditions?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) mTOR activation

 

  • The mTOR (mechanistic target of rapamycin) pathway inhibits autophagy when nutrients are abundant. 
  • Caloric restriction suppresses mTOR, allowing autophagy to degrade dysfunctional organelles and misfolded proteins, promoting cell survival and longevity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. AMPK activation: Incorrect. AMPK activates autophagy in response to low energy states, opposing mTOR.

 

Option C. p53 tumor suppressor pathway: Incorrect. While p53 can regulate autophagy, it is not the main suppressor.

 

Option D. Wnt/β-catenin signalling: Incorrect. Wnt signalling is involved in cell proliferation, not autophagy suppression.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • mTOR is a key negative regulator of autophagy and is inhibited by caloric restriction, promoting cell survival and longevity.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old woman presents with reduced exercise tolerance and shortness of breath while lying down (orthopnea). She had an ST-elevated myocardial infarction (STEMI) three years ago. Examination reveals a raised JVP and a displaced apex beat.

 

Investigations:

 

  • Echocardiogram: Ejection fraction (EF) = 0.38 (38%)

 

Which is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Furosemide

 

  • This patient has heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF), indicated by:
    • History of STEMI (ischemic cardiomyopathy).
    • Symptoms: Reduced exercise tolerance, orthopnea.
    • Signs: Raised JVP (fluid overload), displaced apex beat (ventricular enlargement).
    • Echocardiogram: EF < 40% confirms HFrEF.

 

Why Furosemide?

 

Furosemide (a loop diuretic) is the most immediate treatment to relieve pulmonary congestion and fluid overload. It provides symptomatic relief but does not improve long-term survival.

 

Heart Failure Management Approach:

 

  1. Acute decompensation (fluid overload symptoms) → Furosemide (first-line for symptom relief).
  2. Chronic treatment to improve mortality in HFrEF →
    • ACE inhibitors (Ramipril) or ARBs (Losartan)
    • Beta-blockers (Bisoprolol, Carvedilol)
    • Aldosterone antagonists (Spironolactone, if EF <35%)
    • SGLT2 inhibitors (Dapagliflozin, Empagliflozin, if indicated)

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amlodipine: Not used in HFrEF as it does not improve survival and may cause fluid retention.

 

Option B. Bisoprolol: Essential for long-term HFrEF management, but in acute decompensation, beta-blockers can worsen heart failure and should be introduced after stabilization.

 

Option D. Losartan: ARB (alternative to ACE inhibitors), but not first-line for symptom relief in acute settings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Furosemide is the most appropriate first-line treatment for symptomatic relief of pulmonary congestion in acute decompensated heart failure.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding the utility of eFAST in trauma patients are correct? 

 

  1. eFAST is performed during the primary survey of trauma patients.
  2. eFAST can reliably exclude injuries in penetrating trauma.
  3. eFAST is unreliable in detecting small amounts of free blood (<80 mL).
  4. eFAST is not useful for assessing retroperitoneal injuries.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 3, 4

 

Statement 1. eFAST is performed during the primary survey of trauma patients: Correct. eFAST (extended Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma) is routinely performed during the primary survey of trauma assessment. It is non-invasive, rapid, and helps guide immediate management decisions in hemodynamically unstable patients.

 

Statement 3. eFAST is unreliable in detecting small amounts of free blood (<80 mL): Correct. eFAST has limited sensitivity for detecting small amounts of free blood (<80–100 mL). It is better at identifying larger fluid collections but may miss early hemorrhage.

 

Statement 4. eFAST is not useful for assessing retroperitoneal injuries: Correct. eFAST is not reliable for assessing retroperitoneal injuries, as the retroperitoneum is deep and obscured by bowel gas and other structures. CT scan is preferred for evaluating retroperitoneal injuries.

 

Other Option:

 

Statement 2. eFAST can reliably exclude injuries in penetrating trauma: Incorrect. eFAST does not reliably exclude injuries in penetrating trauma. While it is useful for detecting free fluid (suggestive of bleeding), it may miss hollow viscus injuries, vascular injuries, or diaphragmatic tears commonly seen in penetrating trauma.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • eFAST is a valuable rapid imaging tool in trauma, especially in unstable patients, but it cannot reliably exclude injuries in penetrating trauma, misses small fluid collections, and is unreliable for retroperitoneal assessment.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old male undergoing immunosuppressive therapy with cyclosporine after a kidney transplant presents to the clinic for a routine follow-up. Which of the following are recognized complications associated with cyclosporine therapy in this patient? 

 

1. Hypertension 

2. Pulmonary fibrosis 

3. Hirsutism 

4. Nephrotoxicity 

5. Hyperkalemia
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 3, 4 and 5

 

  • Cyclosporine is a calcineurin inhibitor widely used in transplant medicine to prevent rejection. Its use is associated with several side effects:

 

1. Hypertension: A common side effect due to cyclosporine’s effect on renal blood flow and sodium retention.

 

3. Hirsutism: This is an overgrowth of hair, which is a well-documented effect of cyclosporine, particularly noticeable in populations not typically prone to hairiness.

 

4. Nephrotoxicity: Cyclosporine can cause renal dysfunction, manifested as an increase in serum creatinine and urea, which can progress to chronic kidney disease if not managed appropriately.

 

5. Hyperkalemia: Related to the nephrotoxic effects, as impaired kidney function can lead to an inability to excrete potassium adequately.

 

Other Options:

 

2. Pulmonary fibrosis: Pulmonary fibrosis is not typically associated with cyclosporine use. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The common complications associated with cyclosporine therapy, particularly in post-transplant patients, including hypertension, hirsutism, nephrotoxicity, and hyperkalemia, to monitor and manage these side effects effectively in clinical practice.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with progressive dysphagia to solids, unintentional weight loss, and early satiety. Upper endoscopy reveals thickened gastric folds with linitis plastica. A biopsy shows signet ring cells infiltrating the gastric wall. Which of the following additional malignancies is most strongly associated with the genetic mutation underlying this patient’s disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lobular breast carcinoma

 

Clinical presentation:

 

  • Progressive dysphagia to solids, early satiety, weight loss → Suggests gastric outlet obstruction or infiltrative gastric malignancy
  • Endoscopy: Thickened gastric folds with linitis plastica → Infiltrative, rigid stomach, aka "leather bottle stomach"
  • Biopsy: Signet ring cells → Classic for diffuse-type gastric adenocarcinoma

 

This patient has hereditary diffuse gastric cancer, associated with CDH1 mutations. CDH1 encodes E-cadherin, which maintains cell adhesion. Loss of E-cadherin leads to diffuse gastric cancer and lobular breast carcinoma due to uncontrolled cell infiltration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Medullary thyroid carcinoma: Incorrect. RET mutations cause MEN2, leading to medullary thyroid carcinoma and pheochromocytomas.

 

Option C. Pheochromocytoma: Incorrect. Seen in VHL, NF1, and MEN2, not CDH1 mutations.

 

Option D. Renal cell carcinoma: Incorrect. VHL mutations cause renal cell carcinoma, not CDH1 mutations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • CDH1 mutations cause hereditary diffuse gastric cancer and lobular breast carcinoma due to loss of cell adhesion.

questions.text:
A 61-year-old man presents with:

 

  • Fatigue, night sweats, and weakness for the past 5 months
  • Type 2 diabetes mellitus, managed with metformin
  • Mild conjunctival pallor with splenomegaly and petechiae

 

Investigations:

 

  • Haemoglobin: 111 g/L (Normal range: 130–180)
  • Platelets: 524 × 10⁹/L (Normal range: 150–400)
  • Cytogenetic analysis: 

 

 

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chronic myeloid leukaemia

 

  • The patient’s symptoms of fatigue, night sweats, and weakness over the past 5 months, combined with pallor, splenomegaly, petechiae, and anaemia, strongly suggest chronic myeloid leukaemia (CML). 
  • Additionally, the cytogenetic analysis showing t(9;22) (Philadelphia chromosome) is a defining feature of CML. Here's why:
    • Philadelphia chromosome (t(9;22)): This translocation results in the fusion of the BCR-ABL1 gene, leading to uncontrolled tyrosine kinase activity that drives the proliferation of leukemic cells in CML.
    • Splenomegaly and petechiae are common signs of CML, reflecting splenic involvement and bone marrow dysfunction.
    • Thrombocytosis (elevated platelets) and anaemia are also typical in CML, as the bone marrow becomes overwhelmed with immature cells, which disrupt normal blood cell production.
    • Fatigue, night sweats, and weakness are classic symptoms of CML, especially in the chronic phase of the disease.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Acute myeloid leukaemia (AML): AML presents more acutely and would typically show a more severe drop in hemoglobin and platelets along with the presence of myeloblasts in the blood film, which are not seen in CML. The Philadelphia chromosome is not associated with AML.

 

Option C. Hodgkin lymphoma: Hodgkin lymphoma typically presents with painless lymphadenopathy, not the splenomegaly and petechiae seen in this patient. Additionally, Hodgkin lymphoma is not associated with the Philadelphia chromosome.

 

Option D. Multiple myeloma: Multiple myeloma is a plasma cell malignancy that typically presents with bone pain, renal failure, hypercalcemia, and monoclonal protein (M-protein) in the blood or urine. It does not present with splenomegaly, petechiae, or the Philadelphia chromosome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Chronic myeloid leukaemia (CML) is a hematologic malignancy characterized by the Philadelphia chromosome (t(9;22)) and BCR-ABL1 fusion gene, leading to uncontrolled cell proliferation.
  • Symptoms of CML include fatigue, night sweats, splenomegaly, petechiae, anaemia, and thrombocytosis.
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by cytogenetic analysis showing the Philadelphia chromosome.
  • Treatment for CML includes targeted therapy with tyrosine kinase inhibitors (e.g., imatinib), which effectively blocks the abnormal protein produced by the BCR-ABL1 fusion gene.

questions.text: A patient presents with a left breast lump of size 3cm x 4cm. The overlying skin has a ‘orange-like skin’ appearance. On the right side, mobile axillary nodes are palpable. On the left side, supraclavicular lymph nodes are palpable. The most appropriate tumor staging is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) T4b N3c M1

 

  • In the TNM staging system for breast cancer, T refers to the size and extent of the main tumor, N describes the absence or presence and extent of regional lymph node involvement, and M indicates the absence or presence of distant metastases. 
    • Tumor of any size with overlying skin involvement (Peau d'orange appearance): T4b
    • Ipsilateral supraclavicular lymph node involvement: N3c
    • Involvement of any contralateral lymph nodes indicates metastasis in the case of breast carcinoma: M1

 

Therefore, the staging is T4b N3c M1.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

For breast cancer presenting with a Peau d'orange appearance and bilateral lymph node involvement, the TNM classification is T4b N3c M1, indicating advanced local and metastatic disease.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman presents with progressive dyspnea and fatigue over the past year. Physical exam reveals a loud P2 and a parasternal heave. Right heart catheterization confirms mean pulmonary arterial pressure (mPAP) of 32 mmHg at rest with a normal pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP), consistent with idiopathic pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH, Group 1 PH). Which of the following is the most appropriate first-line therapy for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bosentan

 

  • Idiopathic pulmonary arterial hypertension (Group 1 PH) is treated with targeted pulmonary vasodilator therapy.
  • Endothelin receptor antagonists (e.g., bosentan, ambrisentan) reduce pulmonary vascular resistance by blocking endothelin-1, a potent vasoconstrictor.
  • They are first-line therapy unless vasoreactivity testing suggests a favorable response to calcium channel blockers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amlodipine: Calcium channel blockers are only used in patients who show a positive vasodilator response during right heart catheterization (only ~10% of patients).

 

Option C. Furosemide: Diuretics may help symptoms of right heart failure but do not address the underlying pulmonary hypertension.

 

Option D. Metoprolol: Beta-blockers are contraindicated in PAH because they may worsen right heart failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Endothelin receptor antagonists (e.g., bosentan) are first-line therapy for idiopathic pulmonary arterial hypertension (Group 1 PH), unless vasoreactivity testing indicates a response to calcium channel blockers.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient with a long-term indwelling urinary catheter develops fever, dysuria, and pyuria. Urine culture grows a non-lactose fermenting gram-negative rod. Which of the following is the most common non-lactose fermenting organism responsible for catheter-associated urinary tract infections (CAUTI)?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pseudomonas

 

  • Pseudomonas aeruginosa is the most common non-lactose fermenting gram-negative bacilli that causes catheter-associated urinary tract infections (CAUTI).
  • Risk factors:
    • Prolonged catheterization
    • Immunosuppression
    • Previous antibiotic use
  • Characteristics of Pseudomonas:
    • Gram-negative rod
    • Non-lactose fermenting
    • Oxidase positive
    • Motile and produces blue-green pigment (pyocyanin, pyoverdine)
    • Intrinsically resistant to multiple antibiotics
  • Pathogenesis in CAUTI:
    • Pseudomonas forms biofilms on catheter surfaces, making it highly resistant to host immune defences and antibiotics.
    • It produces exotoxins (Exotoxin A, elastases, and proteases) that contribute to tissue damage.
    • Can lead to complicated UTIs, pyelonephritis, and even urosepsis.

 

Since Pseudomonas aeruginosa is the most common non-lactose fermenting organism responsible for CAUTI, option D is correct.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. E. coli: 

 

  • Escherichia coli is the most common overall cause of UTI, including CAUTI.
  • However, E. coli is a lactose fermenter, not a non-lactose fermenter.
  • Produces pink colonies on MacConkey agar (unlike Pseudomonas, which remains colorless).

 

Option B. Shigella: 

 

  • Shigella spp. is a non-lactose fermenting gram-negative rod, and it is not commonly associated with catheter-associated UTIs.

 

Option C. Enterococcus: 

 

  • Enterococcus spp. (e.g., Enterococcus faecalis, Enterococcus faecium) are gram-positive cocci, not gram-negative rods.
  • It is an important cause of nosocomial UTIs, especially in catheterized patients.
  • However, it does not fit the description of a non-lactose fermenting gram-negative organism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pseudomonas aeruginosa is the most common non-lactose fermenting gram-negative bacillus causing catheter-associated UTIs.
  • E. coli is the most common cause of UTI overall but is a lactose fermenter.
  • Shigella spp. is a non-lactose fermenting gram-negative rod, and it is not commonly associated with catheter-associated UTIs.
  • Enterococcus is a gram-positive cause of CAUTI and does not fit the description of a gram-negative non-lactose fermenter.
  • Biofilm formation on catheters contributes to antibiotic resistance and chronic infections.

questions.text: Identify the maneuver shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ritgen's maneuver

 

  • Ritgen's maneuver is used to control the delivery of the fetal head, especially in breech or vaginal deliveries, by placing a hand on the perineum and supporting the fetal chin to allow controlled head flexion. 
  • This maneuver helps minimize perineal trauma by controlling the descent and speed of head delivery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Woods corkscrew: This maneuver is used to rotate the shoulders in shoulder dystocia, not during breech head delivery.

 

Option B. Piper's maneuver: This is used to deliver the fetal head in breech presentations, but involves guiding the head with forceps, not by hand support.

 

Option C. McRoberts maneuver: This maneuver involves flexing the mother’s thighs to her abdomen to alleviate shoulder dystocia and is unrelated to breech delivery or head flexion.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Ritgen's maneuver assists in controlled delivery of the fetal head by supporting the chin and promoting head flexion, often used in breech deliveries to prevent perineal trauma.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents at 6 weeks of pregnancy with mild spotting. An ultrasound confirms a single live fetus corresponding to 6 weeks gestational age. The mild spotting is suspected to be due to early implantation. What is this type of sign also known as?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hartman's sign

 

  • Hartman's sign refers to mild spotting or bleeding that can occur in early pregnancy, often due to implantation. 
  • This type of bleeding is usually light and brief and occurs when the embryo attaches to the uterine wall. 
  • Implantation bleeding is relatively common in early pregnancy and is typically not associated with miscarriage or complications if the ultrasound shows a live fetus, as in this case.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Goodell's sign: Incorrect. Goodell's sign refers to the softening of the cervix seen in early pregnancy due to increased vascularization, not to implantation bleeding.

 

Option C. Hoffman's sign: Incorrect. Hoffman's sign is a neurological test used to detect upper motor neuron lesions. It is unrelated to pregnancy or implantation bleeding.

 

Option D. Reinz's sign: Incorrect. There is no Reinz's sign in the context of obstetrics or pregnancy, making this option incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Hartman's sign is the term used to describe implantation bleeding, which can present as mild spotting in early pregnancy. 
  • This phenomenon is generally benign and is associated with the process of the embryo embedding into the uterine lining.

choices.text: Microbiological cultures contaminated with Bacillus spores
Single-use plastic syringes and latex gloves
Cytotoxic drug vials and radioactive materials
Large metal implants and amputated body parts

questions.text: A biomedical waste treatment facility is considering adopting microwaving as a method of sterilization. During a review of national guidelines, it is noted that certain types of waste cannot be processed using this method. Which of the following categories of waste is not suitable for microwave sterilization?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Large metal implants and amputated body parts

 

  • Microwave sterilization utilizes moist heat, generated by microwave radiation, to kill microorganisms, making it effective for disinfecting soft bio-medical waste. 
  • However, large metal implants and body parts cannot be microwaved, as metals reflect microwaves, disrupting the sterilization process and potentially causing equipment damage. 
  • Additionally, body parts require incineration or deep burial, as microwaving is ineffective for treating bulk organic waste.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Microbiological cultures contaminated with Bacillus spores: Incorrect. Microwave sterilization is approved for microbiological waste, including cultures contaminated with Bacillus spores, provided that an appropriate biological indicator (Bacillus atrophaeus) is used to validate sterilization.

 

Option B. Single-use plastic syringes and latex gloves: Incorrect. Microwaving can partially disinfect plastics, but it is not a recommended method for destroying syringes and gloves, which should be shredded and incinerated instead.

 

Option C. Cytotoxic drug vials and radioactive materials: Incorrect. While these materials should never be treated via microwaving, the best answer choice remains Option D, as large metal implants and body parts are explicitly mentioned in guidelines as not suitable for microwave sterilization.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Microwave sterilization is not suitable for large metal implants, body parts, cytotoxic drugs, radioactive waste, and hazardous materials. 
  • These require alternative disposal methods, such as incineration, plasma pyrolysis, or deep burial.

questions.text:
A 72-year-old man presents with sudden-onset left-sided weakness in both upper and lower limbs and difficulty speaking, which spontaneously resolves within 30 minutes. He has a history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia, managed with amlodipine and atorvastatin.

 

Examination Findings:

 

  • BP: 145/100 mmHg
  • No persistent neurological deficits

 

What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aspirin

 

  • This patient experienced a transient ischemic attack (TIA), characterized by:
    • Focal neurological symptoms (hemiparesis, speech impairment) lasting <24 hours
    • Complete spontaneous resolution of symptoms
    • Vascular risk factors (hypertension, hypercholesterolemia)

 

Management of TIA:

 

  • Aspirin 300 mg immediately, followed by 75 mg daily for secondary prevention.
  • Assess stroke risk using the ABCD² score (Age, BP, Clinical features, Duration, Diabetes).
  • Carotid imaging (doppler ultrasound/CT angiography) to assess for significant stenosis.
  • High-dose statin (atorvastatin 80 mg) for secondary prevention.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Carotid endarterectomy: Indicated only if carotid stenosis is ≥70% and the patient has had a recent symptomatic stroke/TIA in the ipsilateral carotid territory. Needs vascular imaging first.

 

Option C. Thrombectomy: Used for acute large vessel occlusion strokes (MCA, basilar artery) with persistent deficits, not for TIAs that resolve spontaneously.

 

Option D. Thrombolysis: Indicated for acute ischemic stroke within 4.5 hours of onset, but this patient had transient symptoms that fully resolved (TIA, not stroke).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • TIA is managed with immediate aspirin (300 mg) and secondary stroke prevention (statins, BP control, and lifestyle modifications). 
  • Further investigations (carotid imaging, ECG for atrial fibrillation) guide long-term management.

choices.text: COCPs reduce the risk of ovarian cancer by 80%, but only for the duration of use.
COCPs reduce the risk of endometrial cancer by 50%, and this protection lasts for over 20 years.
COCPs provide a protective effect against cervical cancer, reducing its incidence by 40%.
COCPs increase the risk of ovarian cancer if used for more than 10 years.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman has been taking combined oral contraceptive pills (COCPs) for over 10 years. She is concerned about her risk of developing gynecological cancers. Which of the following statements is correct regarding the protective effects of COCPs?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) COCPs reduce the risk of endometrial cancer by 50%, and this protection lasts for over 20 years.

 

  • Combined oral contraceptives (COCPs) are well known to reduce the risk of ovarian and endometrial cancers.
  • Protection increases with longer duration of use:
    • Risk reduction for ovarian cancer: 40%
    • Risk reduction for endometrial cancer: 50%
    • Use for over 10 years leads to an 80% reduction in risk.
    • Protection persists for more than 20 years after stopping COCPs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. COCPs reduce the risk of ovarian cancer by 80%, but only for the duration of use: Protection continues for over 20 years post-use.

 

Option C. COCPs provide a protective effect against cervical cancer, reducing its incidence by 40%: COCPs do not reduce cervical cancer risk; long-term use may slightly increase it.

 

Option D. COCPs increase the risk of ovarian cancer if used for more than 10 years: They reduce the risk of ovarian cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • COCPs provide long-term protection against ovarian and endometrial cancers, with effects persisting for over 20 years post-use.

questions.text:
A 51-year-old man presents to the emergency department with sudden, severe chest pain radiating to his left jaw. He has a history of hyperlipidemia, managed with atorvastatin. On examination, he is pale and clammy to the touch.


Investigations reveal:

 

  • Troponin: Elevated
  • ECG: 

 

 

Which is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lateral STEMI

 

  • Lateral ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) occurs due to occlusion of the left circumflex artery (LCx) or branches of the left anterior descending artery (LAD). 
  • The ECG hallmark of lateral STEMI includes ST elevation in leads I, V5, and V6, which is seen in this case. 
  • The patient’s sudden, severe chest pain radiating to the jaw, clamminess, and hyperlipidemia increase the suspicion of an acute coronary syndrome (ACS), confirming an ischemic etiology.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anterior STEMI: Typically presents with ST elevation in leads V1–V4, indicating LAD occlusion, which is not seen in this case.

 

Option B. Anterolateral STEMI: Involves both anterior (V1-V4) and lateral (I, V5, V6) leads, suggesting LAD involvement. This case shows pure lateral involvement.

 

Option C. Inferior STEMI: ST elevations in II, III, and aVF indicate RCA occlusion, which is not the case here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Lateral STEMI is diagnosed when ST elevation occurs in leads I, V5, and V6, often due to left circumflex artery occlusion.
  • Immediate reperfusion therapy (PCI or fibrinolysis) is critical to prevent myocardial damage.

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida at 32 weeks gestation with a history of gestational hypertension has a tonically contracted uterus, absent fetal heart sounds, hemoglobin of 6 g/dL, and a blood pressure of 90/60 mmHg, with no visible bleeding on examination. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Concealed abruptio placentae

 

Explanation:

 

  • This patient's presentation of abdominal pain, uterine contraction, fetal demise, and the absence of vaginal bleeding is most consistent with concealed abruptio placentae. Abruptio placentae, or placental abruption, refers to the premature separation of the placenta from the uterus. In concealed abruptio placentae, the blood collects behind the placenta, leading to the clinical findings of a contracted uterus, fetal heart absence, and no visible bleeding. It is associated with conditions like gestational hypertension.
  • Key findings:
    • The patient has a history of hypertension, which is a risk factor for placental abruption. The uterus is tonically contracted, there is abdominal pain, and fetal heart tones are absent, all of which suggest placental abruption.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Revealed placenta previa: Placenta previa usually presents with painless vaginal bleeding, not with abdominal pain, uterine contraction, or absent fetal heart sounds. The absence of visible bleeding and the clinical findings here rule out placenta previa.

 

Option C. Concealed placenta previa: Concealed placenta previa is not a recognized clinical entity. Placenta previa generally involves bleeding as the placenta partially or completely covers the cervix, but does not cause the uterine contraction seen in this case.

 

Option D. Revealed abruptio placentae: While abruptio placentae can present with vaginal bleeding, the absence of visible bleeding in this patient suggests the concealed type of abruptio placentae rather than the revealed type.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of concealed abruptio placentae, a patient may present with abdominal pain, uterine contraction, and fetal heart sound absence without vaginal bleeding. This condition is associated with a history of gestational hypertension.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman is in active labor, and the fetus is noted to be in a persistent occiput transverse position. Despite strong contractions, there is no progress, and deep transverse arrest is suspected. Which type of pelvic shape is most commonly associated with deep transverse arrest?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Android pelvis

 

  • Deep transverse arrest is most commonly associated with an android pelvis. 
  • The android pelvis has a heart-shaped brim and narrower transverse diameter in the midpelvis, which restricts the rotation of the fetal head during labor. 
  • As a result, the fetal head can become stuck in a transverse position, leading to arrest of descent. 
  • The android pelvis is less accommodating for the rotation and descent of the fetal head compared to the gynecoid pelvis, making deep transverse arrest more likely in labor.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anthropoid pelvis: Incorrect. The anthropoid pelvis has an oval shape with a wider anteroposterior diameter, which generally allows the fetal head to descend in the occiput posterior or anterior position more easily. Deep transverse arrest is less common with this pelvic shape.

 

Option B. Platypelloid pelvis: Incorrect. The platypelloid pelvis is flat with a wide transverse diameter. While it can lead to certain complications in labor, deep transverse arrest is not typically associated with this pelvic type.

 

Option D. Gynecoid pelvis: Incorrect. The gynecoid pelvis is the most favorable pelvic type for childbirth, with a round brim and wide dimensions. It is less likely to result in deep transverse arrest due to its accommodating shape.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Deep transverse arrest is most commonly associated with an android pelvis due to its narrow midpelvic dimensions, which can restrict the fetal head's rotation and descent during labor.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are correct regarding the parasympathetic supply of the stomach and epithelial lining in different regions of the body?

 

  1. The anterior vagal trunk is formed from the left vagus nerve, while the posterior vagal trunk is formed from the right vagus nerve.
  2. The vagus nerve provides secretomotor stimulation to gastric glands and motor function to the gastric musculature.
  3. Relaxation of the pyloric sphincter and promotion of gastric emptying is a function of parasympathetic stimulation.
  4. Pseudostratified columnar epithelium with stereocilia is commonly found in the male reproductive tract, such as the epididymis.
  5. Simple columnar epithelium lines the uterus and parts of the gastrointestinal tract.
  6. The distal urethra is lined by stratified squamous epithelium for added durability.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 and 6 

 

Statement 1 (Correct): The anterior vagal trunk originates from the left vagus nerve, and the posterior vagal trunk originates from the right vagus nerve. This anatomical distinction is crucial for surgical procedures like vagotomy.

 

Statement 2 (Correct): The vagus nerve provides secretomotor stimulation to gastric glands and motor stimulation to the gastric musculature, enhancing digestion.

 

Statement 3 (Correct): Parasympathetic stimulation via the vagus nerve leads to pyloric sphincter relaxation and promotes gastric emptying.

 

Statement 4 (Correct): Pseudostratified columnar epithelium with stereocilia is a characteristic feature of the epididymis and vas deferens, aiding in sperm maturation and transport.

 

Statement 5 (Correct): Simple columnar epithelium lines the uterus (endometrium) and parts of the gastrointestinal tract such as the small intestine and large intestine.

 

Statement 6 (Correct): The distal urethra (including the external urethral meatus) is lined by stratified squamous epithelium, providing protection from mechanical stress.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the emergency department with recent onset right lower quadrant pain, nausea, and low-grade fever. Which diagnostic test is most appropriate to confirm the suspected diagnosis of appendicitis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis

 

  • CT scan is the diagnostic test of choice for suspected appendicitis in adults, as it provides detailed images that can confirm the presence of an inflamed appendix and help identify any complications such as perforation or abscess.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Complete blood count: Incorrect as a complete blood count can show leukocytosis but is nonspecific.

 

Option B. Abdominal ultrasound: Incorrect because while ultrasound is useful, especially in children and pregnant women, it is less sensitive than CT in adults.

 

Option D. MRI of the abdomen: Incorrect as MRI is not typically used for the initial evaluation of appendicitis due to less availability and higher cost compared to CT.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • CT scan is the most appropriate initial diagnostic test for appendicitis in adults.

choices.text: Abducts the vocal cords during inspiration
Adducts the vocal cords during phonation
Opens the inlet of the larynx
Tenses the vocal cords for high-pitched sounds

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the primary function of the marked muscle in the larynx?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Opens the inlet of the larynx

 

  • The thyroepiglottic muscle is a structure within the larynx that is involved in opening the inlet of the larynx.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Abducts the vocal cords during inspiration: Abducting the vocal cords during inspiration is primarily the role of the posterior cricoarytenoid muscle, not the thyroepiglottic muscle.

 

Option B. Adducts the vocal cords during phonation: Adducting the vocal cords during phonation is mainly controlled by the lateral cricoarytenoid muscle and not related to the thyroepiglottic muscle.

 

Option D. Tenses the vocal cords for high-pitched sounds: Tensing the vocal cords for high-pitched sounds is primarily controlled by the cricothyroid muscle, not the thyroepiglottic muscle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The primary function of the thyroepiglottic muscle in the larynx is to open the inlet of the larynx.

choices.text: Administer steroid cover, monitor with biophysical profile (BPP), and plan delivery
Administer steroid cover, IVIG and plan delivery at 34 weeks
Admit, daily NST, repeat Doppler after 2 weeks and plan delivery at 34 weeks.

questions.text: A 28-week pregnant woman presents with reduced fetal movements. An umbilical artery Doppler study reveals the below picture. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Administer steroid cover, monitor with Doppler and biophysical profile (BPP), and plan delivery

 

  • Absent diastolic flow in the umbilical artery indicates fetal hypoxia.
  • As she is 28 weeks, steroid cover should be given and delivery planned.
  • Administering corticosteroids such as dexamethasone accelerates fetal lung maturity, reducing RDS risk. 
  • Monitoring the fetus with Doppler and BPP allows time for optimal preparation for delivery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immediate termination of pregnancy: Immediate termination at 28 weeks would result in significant neonatal morbidity and mortality.

 

Option C. Administer steroid cover, IVIG and plan delivery at 34 weeks. IVIG does not have a role in fetal growth restriction. 

 

Option D. Admit, daily NST, repeat Doppler after 2 weeks and plan delivery at 34 weeks. As there is already absent diastolic flow, delivery cannot wait till 34 weeks. 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • In fetal growth restriction, delivery is warranted whenever there is absent or reversal of flow in the umbilical artery. 
  • If < 34 week, steroid cover should be given before delivery.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman with a history of acute intermittent porphyria (AIP) presents with severe abdominal pain, confusion, and dark-colored urine. She reports starting a new medication for insomnia two days ago. The drug induces CYP450 enzymes, worsening her symptoms. Which enzyme is most directly upregulated in her heme biosynthetic pathway?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) ALA synthase

 

  • Barbiturates (e.g., phenobarbital) induce CYP450, increasing hepatic heme metabolism.
  • This reduces free heme levels, leading to de-repression of ALA synthase, the rate-limiting enzyme in heme biosynthesis.
  • In patients with AIP, this results in porphobilinogen (PBG) and ALA accumulation, triggering neurovisceral symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Porphobilinogen deaminase: Incorrect. This enzyme is deficient in AIP, but it is not induced by CYP450 inducers.

 

Option B. Uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase: Incorrect. Deficiency in this enzyme causes porphyria cutanea tarda, not AIP.

 

Option C. Ferrochelatase: Incorrect. This enzyme is inhibited by lead poisoning but is not involved in AIP attacks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • CYP450 inducers (e.g., barbiturates) worsen AIP by increasing ALA synthase activity, leading to excess ALA and porphobilinogen accumulation.

questions.text: A forensic examiner is presented with a set of preserved clothing articles from a case that is 4 months old. Suspicion arises regarding the presence of aged seminal stains on the fabric. Which of the following biochemical tests should the examiner prioritize to yield reliable results for detection of seminal stain?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Creatine phosphokinase (CPK) test

 

  • Spermatozoa contain a high concentration of CPK, which is more than double, than found in any other body fluid. 
  • The enzyme is stable and can be demonstrated even in old stains of six months, making it an effective tool for confirming the presence of semen in stains.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acid phosphatase test:  It is very useful test for recent stains as concentration of acid phosphatase is very high in seminal fluid. However, the concentration of acid phosphatase gradually falls with time, with gradual disappearance in 72 hours. So it is not good for old stains 

 

Option B. Barberio test: Detects spermine from the prostate in the seminal fluid, which is characterized by the formation of yellow needle-shaped rhombic crystals (spermine picrate). It is a presumptive test for seminal stain, not very reliable.

 

Option C. Florence test: Florence test is indicative of the presence of choline from seminal vesicles and results in dark brown rhombic crystals of choline iodide upon treatment with Florence reagent. It is a presumptive test for seminal stain, not very reliable

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Florence test—Not a reliable test. For choline (dark brown rhombic crystals)
  • Barberio test— Detects spermine (yellow needle-shaped rhombic crystals)
  • Acid phosphatase test—Conclusive test in absence of sperm
  • Creatine phosphokinase—Helpful in old seminal stain

questions.text: A 27-year-old pregnant woman in her second trimester visits a health center for routine check-up. As part of maternal health programs, she is offered Albendazole 400 mg. What is the recommended dosing schedule for deworming in pregnant women?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Once in the second trimester

 

  • Pregnant women receive a single dose of Albendazole (400 mg) in the second trimester.
  • Deworming in pregnancy is crucial to prevent anemia, as parasitic infections can exacerbate maternal iron deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pregnant women receive a single dose of Albendazole (400 mg) in the second trimester to prevent helminthic infections and anemia.

choices.text: pKa of a drug is the pH at which the drug is 50% ionized
Small changes in pH near the pKa of a weak acidic drug will not affect its degree of ionization
Knowledge of pKa of a drug is useful in predicting its behavior in various body fluids
Phenobarbital with a pKa of 7.2 is largely unionized at acid pH and will be about 40% nonionized in plasma

questions.text: Which of the following statements about drug ionization and pKa is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Small changes in pH near the pKa of a weak acidic drug will not affect its degree of ionization

 

  • pKa represents the pH at which a drug is 50% ionized and 50% unionized.
  • For weak acids (e.g., phenobarbital, aspirin), ionization is highly dependent on pH.
  • Near the pKa, small pH changes significantly affect ionization. For example, increasing pH above pKa will shift equilibrium toward ionization, enhancing renal elimination.
  • This principle is used in treating phenobarbital overdose by alkalinizing the urine (e.g., with sodium bicarbonate) to trap ionized drug and enhance excretion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. pKa of a drug is the pH at which the drug is 50% ionized: pKa is the pH at which 50% of a drug is ionized and 50% is unionized.

 

Option C. Knowledge of pKa in body fluids: Knowing the pKa helps predict drug distribution and excretion in compartments with different pH (e.g., plasma, urine, gastric fluid).

 

Option D. Phenobarbital ionization: Phenobarbital (pKa 7.2) is mostly unionized in acidic pH (stomach) and partially ionized (about 60%) in plasma (pH ~7.4), meaning ~40% remains non-ionized.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The ionization of weak acids and bases is highly pH-dependent, especially near their pKa. 
  • Small pH changes near pKa significantly alter ionization, affecting drug absorption, distribution, and excretion.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the sterilization procedure shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Irwing procedure

 

  • The image shows a sterilization technique where a portion of the fallopian tube is folded and sutured, known as the Irwing procedure. 
  • This technique involves folding the tube back on itself and tying it off, making it more easily reversible compared to other methods like fimbriectomy or hysteroscopic sterilization.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pomeroy procedure: This is a commonly used method where a loop of the fallopian tube is tied and a segment is excised. It is also reversible but involves cutting the tube.

 

 

Option B. Fimbriectomy: In this procedure, the fimbriae (the fingerlike projections at the end of the fallopian tubes) are removed, which is a permanent and non-reversible sterilization method.

 

 

Option D. Hysteroscopic sterilization: This method involves placing a device in the fallopian tubes through the uterus, leading to tubal occlusion. It is considered a permanent sterilization method and is not easily reversible.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Irwing procedure is a reversible form of tubal sterilization that involves folding and suturing the fallopian tube. 
  • This is important for patients who may consider fertility restoration in the future.

questions.text: A 14-year-old old girl is brought to the OPD by her concerned mother. Her mother tells you that the patient has not yet attained menarche. She is performing well in school and takes part in several sports activities. On examination, you note that the breast and pubic hair are Tanner stage 1. Her height is appropriate. On evaluation, her FSH and LH are low. What could be a possible cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Physiological delay

 

  • This patient has primary amenorrhea with absent secondary sexual characteristics (Tanner Stage 1 breasts & pubic hair).
  • Low FSH and LH indicate hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, suggesting an issue with the hypothalamic-pituitary axis rather than the ovaries.
  • Physiological delay is the most common cause of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, often seen in adolescents who are high-achievers or engage in intense physical activity.

 

Causes of Hypogonadotropic Hypogonadism (Low FSH, LH):

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pure Gonadal Dysgenesis - 46XX or Turner Syndrome - 45XO: Incorrect because gonadal dysgenesis is associated with high FSH & LH due to ovarian failure (hypergonadotropic hypogonadism).

 

Option C. Swyer Syndrome - 46XY Complete Gonadal Dysgenesis: Incorrect because patients with Swyer syndrome have streak gonads, leading to high FSH & LH levels (hypergonadotropic hypogonadism).

 

Option D. Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome - 46XY: Incorrect because AIS presents with normal breast development (due to estrogen conversion), absent uterus, and absent pubic hair. FSH & LH levels are normal or high.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Physiological delay is the most common cause of primary amenorrhea with hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, especially in adolescents who are high achievers or active in sports.

questions.text: A patient with liver failure is found to have impaired gluconeogenesis, leading to hypoglycemia during fasting. Which of the following enzymes is most likely affected by hepatic dysfunction?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pyruvate carboxylase

 

  • Gluconeogenesis is the liver’s major pathway for maintaining blood glucose during fasting.
  • Key regulatory enzymes unique to gluconeogenesis:
    1. Pyruvate carboxylase (pyruvate → oxaloacetate)
    2. PEP carboxykinase (oxaloacetate → PEP)
    3. Fructose-1,6-bisphosphatase (F-1,6-BP → F-6-P)
    4. Glucose-6-phosphatase (G-6-P → glucose)
  • In liver failure, deficiency of these enzymes → impaired gluconeogenesis → hypoglycemia in fasting.
  • Among the options, pyruvate carboxylase is directly essential for gluconeogenesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pyruvate kinase 

 

  • Glycolysis enzyme (PEP → pyruvate).
  • Not required for gluconeogenesis; in fact, it works in the opposite direction.

 

Option B. Phosphofructokinase-1 (PFK-1) 

 

  • Rate-limiting enzyme of glycolysis (F-6-P → F-1,6-BP).
  • Not part of gluconeogenesis.

 

Option D. Hexokinase 

 

  • Catalyzes glucose → G-6-P (glycolysis).
  • Not involved in gluconeogenesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pyruvate carboxylase is essential for hepatic gluconeogenesis, and its impairment in liver failure leads to fasting hypoglycemia.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements about the lienorenal (splenorenal) ligament are correct? 

 

  1. It connects the spleen to the kidney.
  2. It contains the splenic artery and vein.
  3. It contains the short gastric arteries.
  4. It encloses the tail of the pancreas.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A, B and D only

 

Statement A is correct → The lienorenal ligament connects the spleen to the left kidney.

 

Statement B is correct → The splenic artery and vein run within this ligament.

 

Statement D is correct → The tail of the pancreas passes through the lienorenal ligament.

 

Other Option:

 

Statement C is incorrect → The short gastric arteries are found in the gastrosplenic ligament, not the lienorenal ligament.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding Killian’s dehiscence and Zenker’s diverticulum are correct? 

 

  1. Killian’s dehiscence is a weak area between the cricopharyngeus and thyropharyngeus.
  2. Zenker’s diverticulum is a posterior pharyngeal outpouching above the upper esophageal sphincter.
  3. Palatopharyngeus muscle is involved in Zenker’s diverticulum formation.
  4. Cricopharyngeal dysfunction contributes to Zenker’s diverticulum development.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A, B and D only

 

Statement A is correct → Killian’s dehiscence is the weak spot between the cricopharyngeus and thyropharyngeus.

 

Statement B is correct → Zenker’s diverticulum is a false diverticulum, occurring in the posterior pharyngeal wall above the UES.

 

Statement D is correct → Cricopharyngeal dysfunction leads to excessive pressure, contributing to diverticulum formation.

 

Other Option:

 

Statement C is incorrect → Palatopharyngeus is NOT involved in Zenker’s diverticulum formation.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Match the Following Question – Intracranial Hemorrhage and Vessel Involved
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-D, 2-B, 3-A, 4-C

 

  • Extradural (epidural) hemorrhage – Middle meningeal vessels (1-D):
    • Commonly due to trauma with skull fractures, especially at the pterion, where the middle meningeal artery lies beneath the bone.
    • Leads to a biconvex hematoma on CT.
  • Subdural hemorrhage – Bridging veins (superior cerebral veins) (2-B):
    • Caused by tearing of bridging veins connecting cortical veins to dural sinuses.
    • Common in elderly and alcoholics due to brain atrophy, leading to crescent-shaped hematoma on CT.
  • Subarachnoid hemorrhage – Rupture of berry aneurysm of Circle of Willis (3-A):
    • Commonly occurs at the anterior communicating artery.
    • Presents with thunderclap headache, photophobia, neck stiffness.
    • Shows hyperdense blood in the basal cisterns on CT.
  • Intracerebral hemorrhage – Rupture of striate branches of cerebral arteries (4-C):
    • Often due to hypertension, affecting lenticulostriate arteries (Charcot-Bouchard aneurysms).
    • Common in the basal ganglia, thalamus, pons, and cerebellum.

 

Educational Objective :

choices.text: Application of tincture iodine to the lesion
Covering the lesion with normal saline-soaked gauze
No intervention, waiting for the child to gain weight before surgery

questions.text: A 2-day-old newborn is diagnosed with spina bifida cystica and is planned for surgery. Which of the following is the most appropriate preoperative management for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Covering the lesion with normal saline-soaked gauze

 

  • Normal saline-soaked gauze prevents desiccation, trauma, and infection before surgery.
  • Surgery is usually performed within 24-48 hours, but initial moist dressing and infection prevention are crucial.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Application of tincture iodine to the lesion: Not recommended as it can irritate and damage tissue.

 

Option B. Immediate surgery repair within 6 hours: While urgent, surgery is not immediate; preoperative care is needed.

 

Option D. No intervention, waiting for the child to gain weight before surgery: Increases infection risk; early surgery is preferred.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding the layers and nerve plexuses of the intestinal wall are correct?

 

  1. Meissner’s plexus is located in the submucosa and regulates glandular secretions and blood flow.
  2. The myenteric (Auerbach’s) plexus is located between the circular and longitudinal muscle layers and controls gut motility.
  3. Villi are present in both the small and large intestines to enhance absorption.
  4. The intestinal wall layers from outside to inside are: Serosa → Longitudinal muscle → Circular muscle → Submucosa → Mucosa.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2 and 4 only

 

Statement 1 (Correct): Meissner’s plexus, located in the submucosa, regulates secretion and blood flow within the GI tract.

 

Statement 2 (Correct): The myenteric (Auerbach’s) plexus, located between the circular and longitudinal muscle layers, primarily controls gut motility.

 

Statement 4 (Correct): The correct sequence of intestinal layers (outer to inner) is: Serosa → Longitudinal smooth muscle → Circular smooth muscle → Submucosa → Mucosa.

 

Other Option:

 

Statement 3 (Incorrect): Villi are absent in the large intestine and are only present in the small intestine, where they increase the surface area for absorption.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The intestinal wall consists of five layers (serosa → longitudinal muscle → circular muscle → submucosa → mucosa), with Meissner’s plexus in the submucosa (controls secretion) and Auerbach’s plexus between muscle layers (controls motility).

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding acid secretion and urine acidification is/are correct?

 

  1. The proximal tubule has maximum acid secretion.
  2. The collecting duct is the primary site of urine acidification.
  3. The minimum urinary pH is 4.5, which is the limiting pH.
  4. The distal convoluted tubule (DCT) is more involved in bicarbonate reabsorption than acid secretion.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2 and 3 only

 

Statement 1. The proximal tubule has maximum acid secretion which primarily facilitate the bicarbonate reabsorption.

 

Statement 2. The collecting duct is the primary site of urine acidification, where hydrogen ions are actively secreted to regulate urine pH.

 

Statement 3. The minimum urine pH is 4.5, which represents the lowest pH that can be achieved due to the limitations of hydrogen ion excretion.

 

Other Option:

 

Statement 4. is incorrect because the distal convoluted tubule is more involved in sodium and bicarbonate reabsorption, rather than acid secretion.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • The collecting duct plays the most critical role in urine acidification, with a minimum achievable urine pH of 4.5.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman with CKD is prescribed an erythropoiesis-stimulating agent (ESA). Her physician explains that the chosen ESA has a longer half-life and requires less frequent dosing than traditional erythropoietin. Which of the following drugs was most likely prescribed?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Methoxy polyethylene glycol-epoetin beta

 

  • Methoxy polyethylene glycol-epoetin beta (CERA – Continuous Erythropoietin Receptor Activator) has the longest half-life of all ESAs.
  • It is given once every 2–4 weeks, significantly reducing the need for frequent dosing compared to epoetin alfa and darbepoetin alfa.
  • It works by stimulating erythropoiesis in the bone marrow, leading to an increase in red blood cell production.
  • The polyethylene glycol (PEG) modification prolongs its activity, reducing the need for frequent injections.

 

Thus, Methoxy polyethylene glycol-epoetin beta is the most likely prescribed drug in this scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Epoetin Alfa:

 

  • Epoetin alfa is a recombinant erythropoietin with the shortest half-life (6–8 hours IV; 20–24 hours SC).
  • It requires frequent dosing (typically 2–3 times per week).
  • While effective, it does not match the long-acting nature of methoxy polyethylene glycol-epoetin beta.

 

Option B. Darbepoetin Alfa:

 

  • Darbepoetin alfa has an intermediate half-life (~3 times longer than epoetin alfa) and is dosed weekly or biweekly.
  • It is more convenient than epoetin alfa but still requires more frequent dosing than methoxy polyethylene glycol-epoetin beta.

 

Option D. Filgrastim:

 

  • Filgrastim is not an ESA but a granulocyte colony-stimulating factor (G-CSF) used to stimulate neutrophil production in neutropenic patients (e.g., chemotherapy-induced neutropenia).
  • It does not affect erythropoiesis and is not used for anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the outpatient department with complaints of lower abdominal discomfort and spotting. She has a history of amenorrhea for 6 weeks. A transvaginal ultrasound reveals a left adnexal mass measuring 3 cm with a small gestational sac and a fetal pole, but no fetal heart activity. Her beta-HCG level is 2800 IU/L, and she is hemodynamically stable. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Medical management

 

  • Medical management with methotrexate is the best approach in this case because the patient meets the criteria for non-surgical management of ectopic pregnancy:
    1. Hemodynamic stability: The patient is clinically stable.
    2. Beta-HCG levels <5000 IU/L: Her levels are 2800 IU/L, which is within the acceptable range for methotrexate.
    3. Adnexal mass size <3.5 cm: The mass is 3 cm, making it suitable for medical therapy.
    4. Absence of fetal cardiac activity: No cardiac activity is detected, which is a key prerequisite for methotrexate use.
  • Methotrexate is administered as a single dose of 50 mg/m², and the patient is monitored with serial beta-HCG levels to ensure a >15% decrease by day 7.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wait and watch: Expectant management is not appropriate in this case because beta-HCG levels are >2000 IU/L, and the mass is 3 cm, which does not meet the criteria for conservative management. Additionally, the presence of a fetal pole indicates a more advanced ectopic pregnancy that requires intervention.

 

Option B. Salpingectomy: Salpingectomy involves the removal of the fallopian tube and is typically reserved for cases of ruptured ectopic pregnancy, large ectopic masses (>5 cm), or when family completion is desired. This patient is stable, and the mass size is suitable for medical therapy, making surgery unnecessary at this stage.

 

Option D. Salpingostomy: Salpingostomy involves the removal of the ectopic gestation without removing the fallopian tube and is performed surgically. While it preserves fertility, it is generally indicated when medical management fails or is contraindicated, which is not the case here.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Medical management with methotrexate is a safe and effective option for treating ectopic pregnancies in hemodynamically stable patients with beta-HCG levels <5000 IU/L, a mass size <3.5 cm, and no fetal cardiac activity. 
  • Proper patient selection and close monitoring are crucial for the success of this approach. 
  • Surgical intervention is reserved for cases of rupture, hemodynamic instability, or failure of medical therapy.

questions.text: Match the Following: Anatomical Planes and their characteristics
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1-C, 2-B, 3-A, 4-D

 

  • Coronal Plane (1-C): The coronal plane divides the body into anterior (front) and posterior (back) parts. This is commonly referred to as a frontal plane as well, reflecting its orientation along the front and back division of the body.
  • Transverse Plane (2-B): The transverse plane cuts perpendicularly to the body's long axis, dividing it into superior (upper) and inferior (lower) parts. This plane is also known as the horizontal or axial plane.
  • Median Plane (3-A): The median plane runs down the center of the body, dividing it into left and right halves. This plane is a specific type of sagittal plane that aligns exactly with the midline.
  • Sagittal Plane (4-D): Sagittal planes are any vertical planes that run parallel to the median plane. They divide the body into left and right portions, but unlike the median plane, they do not necessarily pass through the midline.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Coronal Plane → Divides the body into anterior and posterior parts.
  • Transverse Plane → Divides the body into superior and inferior parts.
  • Median Plane → Divides the body into left and right halves.
  • Sagittal Plane → Any vertical plane parallel to the median plane.

choices.text: Sodium 90 mmol/L, Glucose 111 mmol/L, Total Osmolarity 310 mmol/L
Sodium 75 mmol/L, Glucose 75 mmol/L, Total Osmolarity 245 mmol/L
Sodium 60 mmol/L, Glucose 75 mmol/L, Total Osmolarity 200 mmol/L
Sodium 50 mmol/L, Glucose 50 mmol/L, Total Osmolarity 180 mmol/L

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought to the emergency department with acute watery diarrhea and signs of dehydration. The child has reduced urine output, sunken eyes, and increased thirst but is alert and drinking fluids eagerly. The physician decides to initiate oral rehydration therapy using reduced-osmolarity ORS as per WHO guidelines. Which of the following is the correct composition of reduced-osmolarity ORS used for rehydration in diarrheal diseases?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sodium 75 mmol/L, Glucose 75 mmol/L, Total Osmolarity 245 mmol/L

 

  • The WHO-recommended reduced-osmolarity ORS is the standard treatment for mild to moderate dehydration caused by diarrhea. It contains:
    • Sodium: 75 mmol/L
    • Chloride: 65 mmol/L
    • Glucose (Anhydrous): 75 mmol/L
    • Potassium: 20 mmol/L
    • Citrate: 10 mmol/L
    • Total Osmolarity: 245 mmol/L
  • This composition provides optimal sodium-glucose cotransport, ensuring efficient rehydration while reducing the risk of hypernatremia and osmotic diarrhea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sodium 90 mmol/L, Glucose 111 mmol/L, Total Osmolarity 310 mmol/L: This represents the older WHO ORS formulation, which had a higher osmolarity and increased the risk of osmotic diarrhea.

 

Option C. Sodium 60 mmol/L, Glucose 75 mmol/L, Total Osmolarity 200 mmol/L: This does not match WHO guidelines and may provide insufficient sodium replacement.

 

Option D. Sodium 50 mmol/L, Glucose 50 mmol/L, Total Osmolarity 180 mmol/L: This is too dilute and does not provide adequate electrolyte and glucose balance for effective rehydration.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: The curve shifts leftward, decreasing Km
The curve shifts rightward, increasing Km
The curve shifts rightward, decreasing Km
The curve shifts downward, without altering Km

questions.text: An allosteric modulator is introduced into the system, which stabilizes the enzyme-substrate complex and increases the enzyme’s efficiency at lower substrate concentrations. How will this affect the graph?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) The curve shifts leftward, decreasing Km

 

  • The effect of an allosteric modulator on the enzyme kinetics graph, which is typically represented by sigmoidal curve in case of allosteric enzymes:
    • An allosteric modulator binds to a site other than the active site of the enzyme.
    • The question says it stabilizes the enzyme-substrate complex and increases the enzyme's efficiency at lower substrate concentrations.
    • This means the enzyme is becoming more active even at lower substrate concentrations, which directly affects Km (Michaelis constant).
  • If the enzyme becomes more efficient at lower substrate concentrations, Km will decrease (lower Km means higher affinity). 
  • The curve will shift leftward because less substrate is required to reach half of Vmax.

 

Other Options:
