Option B. The curve shifts rightward, increasing Km: If the curve shifts rightward, it means the enzyme needs more substrate to reach half of Vmax, which represents lower affinity — opposite of what is mentioned in the question.

 

Option C. The curve shifts rightward, decreasing Km: The graph shifting rightward would indicate that the enzyme needs more substrate, which does not match the scenario of increased efficiency at lower substrate concentrations.

 

Option D. The curve shifts downward, without altering Km: A downward shift means decreased Vmax, which happens in non-competitive inhibition — not allosteric activation. Also, Km would not remain constant in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Incarcerated femoral hernia; immediate surgical intervention

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman with a history of a cough presents with a sudden sharp pain and a bulge in her groin, below the inguinal ligament, that does not reduce with pressure. What is the most likely diagnosis, and what is the immediate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Incarcerated femoral hernia; immediate surgical intervention

 

  • The presentation of non-reducible groin bulge with pain suggests an incarcerated femoral hernia, more common in women. 
  • This condition can progress to strangulation; hence, immediate surgical intervention is necessary to prevent further complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Strangulated inguinal hernia; elective surgery: While strangulated inguinal hernia is a serious condition requiring urgent intervention due to compromised blood flow to the herniated tissue, the immediate need contrasts with the notion of "elective surgery." Strangulation necessitates emergency surgery, not an elective procedure, to prevent tissue necrosis and other severe complications.

 

Option C. Reducible umbilical hernia; conservative management: A reducible umbilical hernia, where the herniated contents can be pushed back into the abdomen, typically does not present with sharp pain or irreducibility as described in the scenario. Conservative management might include observation and possibly wearing a hernia belt, but this option is not consistent with the symptoms of a painful, non-reducible bulge.

 

Option D. Obturator hernia; wait and watch: It does not usually present with swelling. Symptomatic hernias require surgical management.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • The patient’s symptoms of a sudden, sharp pain and a non-reducible bulge in the groin area strongly suggest an incarcerated femoral hernia, particularly in a 60-year-old woman with a cough, which could exacerbate the hernia.

choices.text: Substrate-level phosphorylation occurs exclusively in mitochondria, while oxidative phosphorylation occurs in the cytoplasm.
Substrate-level phosphorylation is oxygen-dependent, while oxidative phosphorylation occurs anaerobically.
Substrate-level phosphorylation generates ATP directly from high-energy intermediates, while oxidative phosphorylation requires a proton gradient.
Substrate-level phosphorylation generates more ATP than oxidative phosphorylation in a single reaction cycle.

questions.text: Which of the following best differentiates substrate-level phosphorylation from oxidative phosphorylation in ATP production?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Substrate-level phosphorylation generates ATP directly from high-energy intermediates, while oxidative phosphorylation requires a proton gradient.

 

  • Substrate-level phosphorylation directly transfers a phosphate group from a high-energy substrate to ADP to form ATP, independent of oxygen.
  • Oxidative phosphorylation relies on the electron transport chain (ETC) and a proton gradient to drive ATP production through ATP synthase.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Substrate-level phosphorylation occurs exclusively in mitochondria, while oxidative phosphorylation occurs in the cytoplasm: Incorrect. Substrate-level phosphorylation occurs in both the cytoplasm (glycolysis) and mitochondria (TCA cycle).

 

Option B. Substrate-level phosphorylation is oxygen-dependent, while oxidative phosphorylation occurs anaerobically: Incorrect. Substrate-level phosphorylation does not require oxygen, whereas oxidative phosphorylation does.

 

Option D. Substrate-level phosphorylation generates more ATP than oxidative phosphorylation in a single reaction cycle: Incorrect. Oxidative phosphorylation generates significantly more ATP per glucose molecule than substrate-level phosphorylation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Substrate-level phosphorylation directly generates ATP from high-energy intermediates, while oxidative phosphorylation depends on the electron transport chain and proton gradient.

choices.text: India entered its demographic window in 1950 and exited in 2000.
India is expected to remain in its demographic window until 2050.
The demographic window occurs when people over 65 exceed 30% of the population.
The demographic window lasts for only 10 years in any country.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about India’s Demographic Window is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) India is expected to remain in its demographic window until 2050.

 

  • Demographic Window refers to the period when a country has a high proportion of working-age population compared to dependents.
  • For India, the demographic window is from 2010 to 2050.
  • This creates economic opportunities through a growing labor force and economic growth potential.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. India entered its demographic window in 1950 and exited in 2000: This timeline refers to Europe, not India.

 

Option C. The demographic window occurs when people over 65 exceed 30% of the population: It occurs when people under 15 are <30% and those over 65 are <15%.

 

Option D. The demographic window lasts for only 10 years in any country: It typically lasts 30-40 years.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • India's demographic window (2010-2050) offers an opportunity for economic growth due to a large working-age population.

 

Summary

choices.text: Abrin, an RNA N-glycosidase that inhibits protein synthesis.
Ricin, a DNA polymerase inhibitor that disrupts cellular replication.
Cyanide, inhibits cytochrome c oxidase in the electron transport chain.
Solanine, disrupts acetylcholinesterase leading to cholinergic excess.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child is brought to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain, vomiting, and bloody diarrhea after accidentally ingesting seeds that resemble those shown in the image. Which toxin is primarily responsible for his symptoms, and what is its mechanism of action?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Abrin, an RNA N-glycosidase that inhibits protein synthesis.

 

  • Abrin, a potent plant toxin found in Abrus precatorius seeds, functions as an RNA N-glycosidase, which inhibits protein synthesis by inactivating the 60S ribosomal subunit. 
  • This mechanism leads to cellular apoptosis and is responsible for the severe gastrointestinal and systemic symptoms observed in the patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ricin, a DNA polymerase inhibitor that disrupts cellular replication: Ricin is a similar toxin found in castor beans, not Abrus precatorius.

 

Option C. Cyanide, inhibits cytochrome c oxidase in the electron transport chain: Cyanide poisoning leads to cellular asphyxiation, unrelated to the seed ingestion described.

 

Option D. Solanine, disrupts acetylcholinesterase leading to cholinergic excess: Solanine is found in nightshade plants and causes different symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with a history of bipolar disorder is scheduled to start treatment with a mood stabilizer. The psychiatrist orders several pre-treatment tests before initiating therapy. Match the mood stabilizer in Column A with the appropriate pre-treatment test in Column B, which must be performed before starting the medication.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-C, 2-A, 3-B, 4-D

 

  • Before initiating mood stabilizers, specific pre-treatment tests are required to assess potential risks and avoid complications associated with each medication.

 

1. Lithium → Renal function and thyroid function tests (C): Lithium is primarily excreted by the kidneys, making renal function tests (creatinine, BUN, eGFR) essential before starting treatment. Thyroid function tests (TSH, free T4) are also necessary since lithium can cause hypothyroidism.

 

2. Valproate → Liver function tests (A): Valproate is hepatotoxic, so liver function tests (LFTs, including ALT, AST, bilirubin) must be checked before starting therapy. It is also teratogenic, requiring pregnancy screening in women of childbearing age.

 

3. Carbamazepine → Complete blood count (B): Carbamazepine can cause bone marrow suppression, leading to leukopenia, agranulocytosis, or aplastic anemia, making CBC an essential pre-treatment test.

 

4. Lamotrigine → None specifically required (D): Lamotrigine does not require routine pre-treatment lab tests, though patients should be educated about monitoring for rash, as it can cause Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Each mood stabilizer has specific pre-treatment tests to identify potential risks:

 

  • Lithium → Renal & thyroid function tests
  • Valproate → Liver function tests (LFTs)
  • Carbamazepine → Complete blood count (CBC)
  • Lamotrigine → No routine pre-treatment tests are required, but monitor for rash (SJS risk).

questions.text:
A 42-year-old HIV-positive man presents to the emergency department with severe epigastric pain radiating to the back, nausea, and vomiting for the past 8 hours. He denies alcohol use but reports that his HIV medications were recently changed due to resistance. His vitals are stable, and laboratory tests reveal:

 

  • Serum amylase: 950 U/L (Normal: 23–85 U/L)
  • Serum lipase: 1,200 U/L (Normal: 0–160 U/L)
  • Triglycerides: 120 mg/dL
  • AST, ALT, ALP: Normal
  • Calcium: 9.1 mg/dL (Normal: 8.5–10.2 mg/dL)

 

Abdominal ultrasound shows no gallstones or biliary dilation. Which of the following medications is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Didanosine

 

  • Didanosine (ddI) is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI) used in HIV treatment.
  • One of its most serious adverse effects is dose-dependent pancreatitis, which can be life-threatening.
  • Other side effects include peripheral neuropathy, hepatic steatosis, and lactic acidosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Zidovudine:

 

  • Causes bone marrow suppression (anemia, neutropenia) but is not strongly associated with pancreatitis.
  • Other side effects: Myopathy, lactic acidosis.

 

Option C. Zalcitabine:

 

  • Rarely used due to toxicity but is more associated with peripheral neuropathy rather than pancreatitis.

 

Option D. Stavudine:

 

  • Can cause lipoatrophy, lactic acidosis, and peripheral neuropathy, but less commonly pancreatitis than didanosine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Didanosine (an NRTI) is the antiretroviral drug most commonly associated with pancreatitis. 
  • It should be avoided in patients with a history of pancreatitis, and serum amylase/lipase should be monitored in symptomatic patients.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman with hypothyroidism has been taking levothyroxine (T4) for 5 years. Her TSH levels have been stable, but after starting a new medication, she reports fatigue, weight gain, and cold intolerance. A follow-up thyroid function test reveals elevated TSH and low free T4, suggesting impaired absorption of levothyroxine. Which of the following drugs is least likely to interfere with levothyroxine absorption?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Metformin

 

  • Levothyroxine absorption occurs primarily in the small intestine and can be affected by various factors, including gastric pH and drug interactions.
  • Metformin does not interfere with levothyroxine absorption.
  • Iron salts, raloxifene, and bile acid sequestrants (colesevelam) bind to levothyroxine in the gut and reduce its absorption.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Iron salts: Iron forms insoluble complexes with levothyroxine, reducing its bioavailability.

 

Option C. Raloxifene: Raloxifene (used for osteoporosis) binds to levothyroxine in the GI tract, significantly reducing its absorption.

 

Option D. Colesevelam: Bile acid sequestrants (e.g., colesevelam, cholestyramine) bind levothyroxine in the intestine, preventing absorption.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Metformin does not interfere with levothyroxine absorption. 
  • However, iron salts, raloxifene, and bile acid sequestrants (e.g., colesevelam) reduce T4 absorption by binding it in the gastrointestinal tract.

choices.text: Perform ultrasound (USG) to assess cervical length

questions.text: A 28-year-old G3P2L0 woman presents at 9 weeks gestation. She has a history of cervical conization performed one year ago, with no recurrence on follow-up Pap smears. Her obstetric history includes preterm births at 30 and 32 weeks gestation in her previous pregnancies. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Perform ultrasound (USG) to assess cervical length

 

  • Cervical insufficiency is a likely concern in this patient given her history of cervical conization and preterm births. 
  • The first step in management is to perform transvaginal ultrasound (USG) to measure the cervical length. 
  • Serial cervical length measurements between 16–24 weeks can help guide management, including the need for cerclage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Perform cervical cerclage: Incorrect. Prophylactic cervical cerclage is not the initial step in management. It is indicated if cervical insufficiency is confirmed (e.g., cervical length <25 mm or prior history of second-trimester painless delivery).

 

Option C. Advise complete bed rest: Incorrect. Bed rest alone is not sufficient management for a patient at risk of cervical insufficiency.

 

Option D. Perform abdominal cerclage: Incorrect. Abdominal cerclage is performed only in patients with a history of failed transvaginal cerclage or other significant contraindications to transvaginal approaches.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For patients with a history of preterm births or cervical conization, transvaginal ultrasound for cervical length measurement is recommended between 16–24 weeks gestation. 
  • This helps guide the need for cerclage or other interventions to prevent preterm birth.

choices.text: Serum sickness reaction due to malaria prophylaxis
Katayama fever due to Schistosoma mansoni infection
Loeffler’s syndrome due to hookworm infection

questions.text: A 24-year-old traveller returns from an endemic region in Africa and presents with fever, malaise, generalized lymphadenopathy, and hepatosplenomegaly. Blood tests reveal eosinophilia and elevated IgE levels. Stool microscopy is negative for parasitic ova, but serology detects antibodies against Schistosoma species. What is the most likely cause of his condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Katayama fever due to Schistosoma mansoni infection

 

  • Katayama fever is an acute hypersensitivity reaction to Schistosoma egg antigens, leading to fever, lymphadenopathy, and hepatosplenomegaly. 
  • Serology is positive in the early stage, whereas stool microscopy is often negative since egg shedding occurs later.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Serum sickness reaction due to malaria prophylaxis: Incorrect, as malaria prophylaxis (e.g., doxycycline or mefloquine) does not cause hepatosplenomegaly and eosinophilia.

 

Option B. Visceral leishmaniasis: Incorrect, as leishmaniasis causes pancytopenia, not eosinophilia.

 

Option D. Loeffler’s syndrome: Incorrect, as Loeffler’s syndrome is due to migrating helminth larvae affecting the lungs, not an immune response to Schistosoma eggs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Katayama fever is an acute hypersensitivity reaction to Schistosoma egg antigens, leading to fever, eosinophilia, and hepatosplenomegaly.
  • Schistosoma mansoni is more commonly associated with Katayama fever than Schistosoma japonicum.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with progressive numbness and skin lesions on her hands. She has a history of travel to Southeast Asia. Examination reveals hypopigmented skin plaques with loss of sensation. A skin biopsy is performed, and a stain is applied to confirm the presence of intracellular acid-fast bacilli. Which of the following stains is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Fite-Faraco

 

  • This patient has leprosy (Hansen’s disease), caused by Mycobacterium leprae, which infects Schwann cells and skin macrophages. 
  • Diagnosis is confirmed using Fite-Faraco stain, a modification of the Ziehl-Neilsen acid-fast stain, which detects acid-fast bacilli in tissue samples.

     

Other Options:

 

Option A. Prussian Blue: Incorrect. Prussian Blue stains iron deposits, not acid-fast bacilli.

 

Option B. Congo Red: Incorrect. Congo Red detects amyloid deposits, not Mycobacterium leprae.

 

Option C. PAS (Periodic Acid-Schiff): Incorrect. PAS stains glycogen and mucopolysaccharides, not acid-fast bacilli.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Fite-Faraco stain is used to detect Mycobacterium leprae, which appears as acid-fast bacilli in tissue samples.

questions.text: Match the drug with the recommended time to discontinue prior to surgery.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A-2, B-1, C-4, D-3

 

  • A-2. Metformin: Should be discontinued 48 hours before surgery to avoid the risk of hypoglycemia, particularly with medications that increase insulin secretion.
  • B-1. Sildenafil: Typically discontinued 24 hours before surgery due to its potential interaction with anesthetics and effects on blood pressure.
  • C-4. NSAIDs: Discontinue 7 days before surgery to minimize bleeding risk, as NSAIDs inhibit platelet aggregation.
  • D-3. MAO inhibitors: Should be stopped 14 days before surgery to reduce the risk of hypertensive crisis or serotonin syndrome due to interactions with anesthetic agents or other medications.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • It is essential to understand the recommended time frames for discontinuing specific drugs before surgery to reduce perioperative risks like bleeding, hypoglycemia, or severe drug interactions.

questions.text: A patient presents with hip pain and true shortening of the limb which was diagnosed as tuberculosis of the hip. Which stage of the disease is he currently in?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Stage of advanced arthritis

 

  • Extensive bone and cartilage destruction. 
  • Joint subluxation or dislocation is common. 
  • Muscle contractures and deformities are severe. 
  • True shortening of the limb is a hallmark of this stage. 
  • Cold abscesses may develop.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Stage of Early Arthritis: The infection spreads to the cartilage and bone. Pain intensifies, and muscle spasm becomes more pronounced. There may be some joint effusion. Early bone destruction may begin, but true shortening is not usually present.

 

Option B. Stage of Synovitis: This is the initial stage. The infection primarily affects the synovial membrane. Symptoms include mild pain, limited movement, and possibly a low-grade fever. There is usually no significant bone destruction or limb shortening at this stage.

 

Option D. Stage of Arthritis Without Subluxation: Significant bone destruction occurs. Joint space narrowing is evident. Pain and limitation of movement are severe. Some deformity may start, but subluxation has not yet occurred. True shortening may begin to be noticed.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Stage of advanced arthritis is the correct stage given the symptoms of hip pain, true shortening of the limb, and severe deformities

questions.text:
A 21-year-old man presents to the emergency department in Hyderabad with sudden-onset breathlessness for the past 30 minutes. He is a known asthmatic on salbutamol and beclomethasone inhalers. On examination, his pulse is 126 bpm, respiratory rate is 28/min, and he is unable to complete full sentences in one breath. 

CXR shows subcutaneous air. What will be the expected PEF?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. 33%–50%

 

Explanation:

 

According to the BTS/SIGN guidelines, acute severe asthma is defined by any one of the following features: PEF 33–50% of predicted or best, heart rate ≥110/min, respiratory rate ≥25/min, or inability to complete full sentences in one breath. This patient clearly meets all of these criteria and thus fits into the category of acute severe asthma. The most likely expected PEF is 33%–50%.

.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 0%–17% – Incorrect. This value is extremely low and is not a standard classification cutoff in the guidelines.

 

Option B. 17%–33% – This implies life-threatening asthma, which is associated with features such as cyanosis, altered consciousness, poor respiratory effort, or silent chest, none of which are present here.

 

Option D. 50%–75% – This range is seen in moderate asthma where severe signs are absent. The presence of tachypnea, tachycardia, and difficulty speaking full sentences indicates a more severe exacerbation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In asthma assessment, clinical severity should align with defined guideline thresholds. According to BTS/SIGN guidelines, a patient with heart rate ≥110, respiratory rate ≥25, and inability to complete full sentences is categorized as having acute severe asthma. The expected PEF in such cases is 33%–50%. Life-threatening asthma requires more critical features such as PEF <30%, cyanosis, or altered mental status.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with fatigue, weight gain, and cold intolerance. Laboratory findings reveal low T3 and T4 levels with low TSH. Dysfunction of which of the following cell types is most likely responsible for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Basophilic cells

 

  • Basophilic cells in the anterior pituitary secrete TSH, ACTH, FSH, and LH.
    • TSH (thyroid-stimulating hormone) stimulates the thyroid gland to produce T3 and T4.
    • Low TSH, T3, and T4 indicate a central hypothyroidism due to anterior pituitary dysfunction affecting basophilic cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acidophilic cells: Secrete growth hormone (GH) and prolactin (PRL) but are not involved in thyroid function.

 

Option C. Chromophobe cells: These do not actively secrete hormones and serve as undifferentiated cells.

 

Option D. Parafollicular cells: These are found in the thyroid gland and secrete calcitonin, which regulates calcium metabolism but has no role in TSH production.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Basophilic cells of the anterior pituitary secrete TSH, ACTH, FSH, and LH, with TSH being crucial for thyroid hormone production.

choices.text: ACTH binds directly to melanocytes, stimulating melanin production.
ACTH is derived from POMC, which also produces melanocyte-stimulating hormone (MSH).
ACTH upregulates melanin synthesis by increasing tyrosinase activity in melanocytes.
ACTH stimulates beta-endorphin production, leading to darkened skin.

questions.text: A 38-year-old female presents with progressive fatigue, weight loss, and skin hyperpigmentation. Laboratory investigations reveal hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and elevated ACTH levels. Which of the following best explains the reason for this patient’s hyperpigmentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) ACTH is derived from POMC, which also produces melanocyte-stimulating hormone (MSH).

 

  • ACTH is derived from POMC (Pro-opiomelanocortin), which also produces MSH (melanocyte-stimulating hormone).
  • In conditions of ACTH overproduction (e.g., primary adrenal insufficiency/Addison’s disease), increased MSH levels stimulate melanotropin-1 receptors, leading to generalized hyperpigmentation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ACTH binds directly to melanocytes, stimulating melanin production: Incorrect: ACTH does not directly bind to melanocytes; instead, MSH stimulates melanocytes to increase melanin production.

 

Option C. ACTH upregulates melanin synthesis by increasing tyrosinase activity in melanocytes: Incorrect: MSH, not ACTH, upregulates tyrosinase, the enzyme responsible for melanin synthesis.

 

Option D. ACTH stimulates beta-endorphin production, leading to darkened skin: Incorrect: Beta-endorphins are also POMC derivatives but do not contribute to hyperpigmentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hyperpigmentation in ACTH overproduction occurs due to increased MSH levels, a byproduct of POMC-derived ACTH synthesis.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents to the clinic with skin blisters as shown below. He reports that the blisters are fragile and rupture easily. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pemphigus vulgaris

 

  • Autoimmune blistering disorder caused by autoantibodies against desmogleins (components of desmosomes that facilitate cell-to-cell adhesion in the epidermis).
  • Presents with painful mucosal ulcers (especially in the oral cavity) and flaccid blisters on the skin that rupture easily, leading to erosions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pemphigus foliaceus:

 

  • A milder form of pemphigus that affects only the superficial skin layers.
  • Does not involve mucosal surfaces and presents with crusted, erythematous lesions with predominant scaling.

 

Option C. Dermatitis herpetiformis:

 

  • Chronic blistering skin condition associated with gluten sensitivity and celiac disease.
  • Pruritic vesicles and papules appear on the elbows, knees, and buttocks.
  • Does not typically involve mucosal ulcers.

 

Option D. Pemphigoid:

 

  • Includes bullous pemphigoid and mucous membrane pemphigoid.
  • Tense blisters with intact epidermis, unlike flaccid blisters in pemphigus vulgaris.
  • More common in elderly individuals.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Differentiating Blistering Disorders

choices.text: Initiate hemodialysis to remove excess orotic acid
Provide carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I (CPSI) replacement therapy

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with recurrent infections and failure to thrive. Laboratory tests show megaloblastic anemia unresponsive to vitamin B12/folate and increased urinary orotic acid. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Start uridine supplementation

 

  • Uridine supplementation provides an alternative source of UMP, bypassing the UMP synthase defect and restoring normal pyrimidine metabolism.
  • This corrects the megaloblastic anemia and failure to thrive associated with orotic aciduria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Initiate Hemodialysis to remove excess orotic acido: Incorrect. Orotic acid is not toxic, and dialysis is not necessary.

 

Option B. Administer Vitamin B12 injections: Incorrect. The anemia in orotic aciduria is not caused by vitamin B12 or folate deficiency.

 

Option D. Provide CPSI replacement therapy: Incorrect. CPSI is not deficient in orotic aciduria, but in urea cycle disorders.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Uridine supplementation is the treatment of choice for orotic aciduria, as it bypasses the metabolic block in UMP synthase deficiency.

questions.text: Which of the following instruments is used specifically for measuring the residual chlorine level in water?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Chloroscope

 

  • Chloroscope is the instrument specifically designed for measuring the residual chlorine level in water.
  • Other instruments have different functions in chlorination:
    • Horrock’s Apparatus → Estimates chlorine demand.
    • Chlorinator → Regulates the chlorine dose.
    • Colorimeter → Measures color intensity, but not specifically chlorine residual.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chlorination and Free Residual Chlorine

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents for her first-trimester ultrasound at 12 weeks of gestation. The ultrasound reveals an image as shown below. Identify the condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dichorionic twins

 

  • The twin peak sign or lambda sign is an ultrasound finding that suggests the presence of a dichorionic twin pregnancy, meaning each twin has its own chorion and placenta. 
  • This sign appears as a triangular projection of tissue between the two gestational sacs, and it indicates the presence of two separate placentas.
  • Dichorionic twin pregnancies can occur in both monozygotic (identical) and dizygotic (fraternal) twins. 
  • In monozygotic twins, dichorionicity occurs when the fertilized egg splits early (within the first 3 days after fertilization), while in dizygotic twins, two separate eggs are fertilized, leading to two separate chorions and placentas.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Monochorionic twins: Incorrect. These twins share a single placenta and do not show the twin peak sign.

 

Option B. All monozygotic twins: Incorrect. Not all monozygotic twins are dichorionic. It depends on the timing of the zygote division.

 

Option D. Conjoined twins: Incorrect. Conjoined twins are a rare type of monozygotic twins where the embryo divides very late, and they share body structures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The twin peak sign is a key ultrasound feature that indicates a dichorionic twin pregnancy, typically seen in cases where each twin has its own chorion and placenta, whether the twins are monozygotic or dizygotic.

questions.text: Spinal injury with no radiological finding is commonly seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Children

 

SCIWORA

 

  • Spinal Cord Injury Without Obvious Radiological Abnormality is seen in children due to flexibility of spine.
  • SCIWORA is used to describe a spinal cord injury that does not show any radiographic abnormalities on imaging studies like X-ray or CT scans.
  • Mechanism: It mainly occurs due to hyperflexion or hyperextension of the spinal cord without any accompanying fractures or dislocations of the vertebrae.
  • Age group: It mainly occurs in children (particularly in less than 8 years of age).
  • Best Investigation to pick up SCIWORA – MRI.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Older men: Older men, like older women, are more prone to degenerative changes in the spine, such as osteoarthritis and spinal stenosis. These conditions can make them more susceptible to spinal injuries, but these injuries are often associated with radiological findings. Osteoporosis also makes fractures more likely in older men.

 

Option C. Older women: Older women are particularly susceptible to osteoporotic fractures, which are easily visible on radiological imaging. Therefore, a spinal injury without radiological findings is less common in this population. Osteoporosis makes vertebral compression fractures a more common occurrence.

 

Option D. In middle-aged: While spinal injuries can occur in middle-aged individuals, SCIWORA is less common in this age group compared to children. Middle aged individuals have a more mature skeletal system, making ligamentous injury without bony injury less common.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Spinal cord injuries without any radiological finding are commonly seen in children < 8 years of age. 
  • Clinical symptoms of traumatic myelopathy with no radiographic or computed tomographic features of spinal fracture or instability. 
  • Such injury requires high suspicion and should be evaluated with MRI with associated clinical symptoms.

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reason are correct, and Reason is the correct explanation.
Both Assertion and Reason are correct, but Reason is not the correct explanation.
Assertion is correct, but Reason is incorrect.
Assertion is incorrect, but Reason is correct.

questions.text:
Assertion: Renal tubular acidosis (RTA) Type 4 is associated with hyperkalemia.


Reason: RTA Type 4 results from excess aldosterone, leading to increased potassium excretion.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Assertion is correct, but Reason is incorrect.

 

Assertion (Correct): RTA Type 4 is associated with hyperkalemia due to aldosterone deficiency or resistance, which leads to reduced potassium and hydrogen ion excretion.

 

Reason (Incorrect): The cause is not excess aldosterone but rather aldosterone deficiency (as seen in hyporeninemic hypoaldosteronism or Addison’s disease). Excess aldosterone would lead to hypokalemia, not hyperkalemia.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • RTA Type 4 is due to aldosterone deficiency or resistance, leading to impaired potassium and acid excretion, resulting in hyperkalemia.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with a 40-pack-year smoking history and chronic alcohol use presents to the ENT clinic with a one-year history of progressively worsening hoarseness. He denies sore throat, dysphagia, hemoptysis, or unintentional weight loss. He mentions that his symptoms fluctuate, worsening after prolonged speaking. He has a history of night-time acid reflux but has never sought treatment. On examination, his voice is noticeably hoarse. Laryngoscopy reveals thickened, hyperkeratotic lesions on the posterior part of the vocal cords, near interarytenoid area. The rest of the examination is unremarkable. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pachydermia Laryngis

 

  • Pachydermia laryngis is characterized by thickened, hyperkeratotic lesions on the vocal cords, often associated with chronic irritation such as smoking and alcohol abuse. 
  • This patient's long history of heavy smoking and drinking, along with the laryngoscopic findings, support this diagnosis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Laryngeal Papillomatosis: Laryngeal papillomatosis typically presents in younger patients and is associated with Human Papilloma Virus (HPV) infection. It is characterized by multiple papillary growths on the vocal cords and other parts of the larynx.

 

 

Option B. Vocal Cord Nodules: Vocal cord nodules are benign lesions typically seen in individuals who strain their voices, such as singers or teachers. They present with hoarseness but are not associated with smoking or alcohol use.

 

 

Option D. Laryngeal Carcinoma: Laryngeal carcinoma should be considered, especially given the patient's smoking history. However, the absence of symptoms like dysphagia, weight loss, and the specific laryngoscopic findings of hyperkeratotic lesions lean more towards pachydermia laryngis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A newborn with failure to thrive and hepatomegaly is diagnosed with classical galactosemia (galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase deficiency). Which dietary restriction is most appropriate to prevent further complications?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lactose and galactose

 

  • This is about Classical Galactosemia due to Galactose-1-Phosphate Uridyltransferase (GALT) deficiency — an autosomal recessive disorder.
  • In Classical Galactosemia, the enzyme Galactose-1-Phosphate Uridyltransferase (GALT) is deficient, which blocks the metabolism of galactose-1-phosphate into glucose-1-phosphate.

 

What happens?

 

  • Galactose (from diet) → Galactose-1-Phosphate (toxic)
  • Accumulation of:
    • Galactose-1-phosphate → Hepatomegaly, Jaundice
    • Galactitol (via aldose reductase) → Cataracts
    • Galactose in urine → Positive Benedict's test (Reducing substances)
  • Lactose (glucose + galactose) must be avoided because galactose cannot be metabolized in classical galactosemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fructose and sucrose: Incorrect. Fructose metabolism is unaffected in galactosemia.

 

Option C. Glucose and galactose: Incorrect. Glucose metabolism remains intact.

 

Option D. Sucrose and maltose: Incorrect. Maltose (glucose + glucose) is safe in galactosemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For examination and clinical purposes, remember that the management of classical galactosemia involves eliminating dietary lactose and galactose to prevent the complications associated with galactose accumulation, such as liver damage and developmental issues.

questions.text:
Which of the following organisms can be effectively isolated using NNN (Novy-MacNeal-Nicolle) medium?

 

  1. Leishmania donovani 
  2. Giardia 
  3. E. histolytica 
  4. Trichomonas vaginalis 
  5. Trypanosoma cruzi
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1 and 5

 

  • NNN (Novy-MacNeal-Nicolle) medium is a specialized biphasic culture medium designed specifically for hemoflagellates, including Leishmania donovani and Trypanosoma cruzi. It is used for the isolation of these organisms from blood or tissue aspirates.

 

1. Leishmania donovani: The causative agent of visceral leishmaniasis (Kala-azar). It exists as amastigotes (intracellular form) inside macrophages in human tissue but transforms into promastigotes (extracellular flagellated form) when cultured on NNN medium.

 

5. Trypanosoma cruzi: The causative agent of Chagas disease. It exists as trypomastigotes in human blood, but in culture, it transforms into epimastigotes, which can multiply in NNN medium.

 

Thus, Leishmania donovani and Trypanosoma cruzi are the only organisms that grow on NNN medium, making Option C (1 and 5) the correct answer.

 

Other Options:

 

2. Giardia lamblia (Incorrect): This intestinal protozoan does not grow on NNN medium; it requires TYI-S-33 (Trypticase-Yeast-Iron) medium.

 

3. Entamoeba histolytica (Incorrect): This intestinal protozoan does not grow on NNN medium; it is best cultured using Boeck & Drbohlav’s medium or Robinson’s medium.

 

4. Trichomonas vaginalis (Incorrect): This urogenital parasite does not grow on NNN medium; it is best cultured using Diamond’s medium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • NNN medium is used for isolating hemoflagellates like Leishmania spp. and Trypanosoma cruzi.
  • Leishmania donovani (Kala-azar) exists as intracellular amastigotes in human tissue but transforms into motile promastigotes in NNN culture.
  • Trypanosoma cruzi (Chagas disease) grows as epimastigotes in NNN culture.
  • Giardia lamblia, Entamoeba histolytica, and Trichomonas vaginalis require different culture media and do not grow on NNN medium.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman with a history of asthma and multiple allergies is undergoing a coronary CT angiography. She is at increased risk for contrast-induced reactions. Which of the following contrast agents has the highest risk of causing an allergic reaction?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Diatrizoate

 

  • Diatrizoate is a high-osmolar ionic contrast agent (HOCM), which has the highest risk of contrast-induced allergic reactions.
  • Low-osmolar (LOCM) and isosmolar contrast agents have lower risk and are preferred in high-risk patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Iodixanol: Incorrect. An isosmolar agent, has the lowest risk of allergic reactions.

 

Option B. Ioxaglate: Incorrect. A low-osmolar ionic contrast agent with moderate risk.

 

Option C. Iohexol: Incorrect. A low-osmolar non-ionic agent, safer than high-osmolar agents.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • High-osmolar contrast agents (e.g., diatrizoate) have the highest risk of allergic reactions, while low-osmolar and isosmolar agents are safer alternatives.

choices.text: Acetazolamide IV followed by topical beta-blockers

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents with sudden, severe ocular pain radiating along the trigeminal nerve, nausea, vomiting, and photophobia. Examination shows marked conjunctival congestion, corneal edema, a mid-dilated non-reactive pupil, and an IOP of 55 mmHg. What is the most immediate step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Acetazolamide IV followed by topical beta-blockers

 

  • The patient has acute congestive (angle-closure) glaucoma, characterized by sudden, severe eye pain, nausea, vomiting, and a fixed, mid-dilated pupil. 
  • Immediate IOP reduction is crucial to prevent optic nerve damage. 
  • IV acetazolamide (a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor) rapidly reduces aqueous humor production, and topical beta-blockers help lower IOP further.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Laser peripheral iridotomy: Definitive treatment but should be done only after initial IOP reduction, as extreme IOP can cause further optic nerve damage.

 

Option B. Prostaglandin analogues: Work too slowly to be useful in an acute crisis.

 

Option C. Trabeculectomy: Indicated in chronic glaucoma, not in an acute attack.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Acute congestive glaucoma is a medical emergency requiring immediate IOP reduction with IV acetazolamide and topical beta-blockers. 
  • Laser peripheral iridotomy is the definitive treatment but should only be done after initial pressure control.

 

Note – 

 

Stages and Features of Primary Angle-Closure Glaucoma

questions.text: The graph compares the arterial anesthetic tension over time for nitrous oxide and a new anesthetic agent (Drug A). Compared to nitrous oxide, Drug A exhibits a slower rise in arterial tension. Which of the following best describes the properties of Drug A?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) High blood: gas partition coefficient

 

  • The blood: gas partition coefficient describes the solubility of an inhaled anesthetic in the blood.
  • Anesthetic agents with a high blood: gas partition coefficient (i.e., more soluble in blood) have a slower onset of action because they require more time to saturate the blood before equilibrating with the brain.
  • In the graph, Drug A has a slower rise in arterial tension compared to nitrous oxide, indicating that it dissolves more in blood, delaying equilibrium with the brain.
  • Thus, Drug A has a high blood: gas partition coefficient, making it more soluble in blood and resulting in a slower onset of action.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Low solubility in blood:

 

  • Drugs with low blood solubility (e.g., nitrous oxide, desflurane) reach equilibrium quickly, leading to a rapid rise in arterial tension.
  • The graph shows Drug A has a slower rise in arterial tension, meaning it is more soluble in blood, not less.

 

Option C. Rapid onset of action:

 

  • Drugs with high blood solubility have a slow onset of action.
  • Nitrous oxide has a rapid onset due to its low solubility in blood. Drug A, in contrast, has a slower rise, indicating a slower onset.

 

Option D. Low potency:

 

  • Potency of an anesthetic is measured by its minimum alveolar concentration (MAC), not by its blood solubility.
  • The graph does not provide information about potency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A high blood: gas partition coefficient indicates high blood solubility, leading to slower equilibration with the brain and delayed anesthetic onset. 
  • Drugs with high solubility in blood (e.g., halothane) have slower induction times compared to drugs with low solubility (e.g., nitrous oxide, desflurane).

questions.text: A pregnant woman presents for antenatal evaluation. On vaginal examination, the vertex is felt as the presenting part, and the fetal attitude is noted as complete flexion. Which presenting diameter is most likely to be engaged during labor?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sub-occipitobregmatic diameter (9.5 cm)

 

  • In complete flexion, the vertex is the presenting part, and the sub-occipitobregmatic diameter (9.5 cm) is the presenting diameter. 
  • This is the optimal position for vaginal delivery as it provides the smallest diameter.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Occipito-frontal diameter (11.5 cm): Occipito-frontal diameter (11.5 cm) is associated with deflexion/military attitude, which is less favorable for vaginal delivery.

 

Option C. Vertico-mental diameter (14 cm): Vertico-mental diameter (14 cm) is associated with partial extension (brow presentation), which may cause obstructed labor.

 

Option D. Sub-mento-bregmatic diameter (9.5 cm): Sub-mento-bregmatic diameter (9.5 cm) is associated with complete extension (face presentation) and is less common.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The sub-occipitobregmatic diameter (9.5 cm) is the presenting diameter in vertex presentation with complete flexion, facilitating normal vaginal delivery.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man with hyperlipidemia is started on a medication that inhibits hepatic cholesterol synthesis. One month later, his lipid panel shows a significant decrease in LDL cholesterol levels and a mild increase in HDL cholesterol. This drug also upregulates LDL receptors in the liver to facilitate cholesterol clearance. Which of the following best describes the primary enzyme inhibited by this drug?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) HMG-CoA reductase

 

  • Statins work by inhibiting HMG-CoA reductase, the rate-limiting enzyme in cholesterol synthesis. 
  • By blocking this enzyme, hepatic cholesterol production is decreased, leading to increased LDL receptor expression, which facilitates greater LDL clearance from the bloodstream. 
  • This lowers serum LDL cholesterol levels, contributing to statins' cardiovascular benefits.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HMG-CoA synthase: Incorrect. This enzyme is involved in the ketogenesis pathway, not cholesterol synthesis.

 

Option C. Acyl-CoA:cholesterol acyltransferase (ACAT): Incorrect. ACAT is responsible for intracellular cholesterol esterification and storage rather than regulating plasma cholesterol levels.

 

Option D. Intestinal cholesterol transporter: Incorrect. Ezetimibe works by inhibiting NPC1L1, the intestinal cholesterol transporter, but has minimal impact on LDL receptor expression.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Statins lower LDL cholesterol by inhibiting HMG-CoA reductase, leading to increased LDL receptor expression and enhanced hepatic clearance of circulating cholesterol.

choices.text: Carriers are less important than active cases in spreading the infection
Penicillin eradicates the carrier state effectively
Carriers can have asymptomatic colonization for an average of 10 months
The highest carrier rate occurs in infants and young children

questions.text: A 25-year-old medical student is diagnosed as a temporary carrier of Neisseria meningitidis. Which of the following statements regarding meningococcal carriers is most accurate?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Carriers can have asymptomatic colonization for an average of 10 months

 

  • Carriers of Neisseria meningitidis are more important sources of infection than symptomatic cases because they spread the bacteria without showing symptoms.
  • The average duration of temporary carriers is ~10 months.
  • Penicillin does not eradicate the carrier state, requiring rifampicin for treatment.
  • Adolescents and young adults (not infants) have the highest carrier rates, especially in crowded places like dormitories and military camps.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Carriers are less important than active cases in spreading the infection: Carriers are the primary source of transmission in meningococcal disease.

 

Option B. Penicillin eradicates the carrier state effectively: Penicillin treats active cases but does not clear the carrier state.

 

Option D. The highest carrier rate occurs in infants and young children: Adolescents and young adults have the highest carrier rates.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Carriers of N. meningitidis play a crucial role in disease transmission, with asymptomatic colonization lasting around 10 months. Rifampicin, not penicillin, is used to eliminate the carrier state.

 

Meningococcal Meningitis

questions.text: Mr. Rohan, a 33-year-old man from Delhi, presents with recurrent episodes of sudden breathlessness and wheezing, particularly worsening in cold weather. He has a history of atopic dermatitis, managed with topical hydrocortisone. He denies fever, weight loss, or night sweats. On examination, there is a bilateral expiratory wheeze on chest auscultation. Investigations reveal fractional exhaled nitric oxide (FeNO) of 45 ppb (>40). What is the most appropriate next investigation?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Postbronchodilator spirometry

 

  • The patient's episodic breathlessness, wheezing, and elevated FeNO (>40 ppb) suggest airway inflammation, likely due to asthma. 
  • Postbronchodilator spirometry is the gold standard test for diagnosing asthma, demonstrating reversible airway obstruction (FEV1 increase by ≥12% and 200 mL post-bronchodilator).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chest X-ray: Helpful in ruling out pneumonia or structural lung disease but not required for diagnosing asthma.

 

Option B. CT chest: Used for interstitial lung disease or bronchiectasis, not first-line for asthma.

 

Option C. Polysomnography: Indicated for obstructive sleep apnea, but does not assess airway hyperresponsiveness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Postbronchodilator spirometry is the gold standard for diagnosing asthma, demonstrating reversible airway obstruction. 
  • FeNO >40 ppb supports airway inflammation, but spirometry confirms the diagnosis.

choices.text: Inhibition of receptor activator of nuclear factor-kappa B ligand (RANKL) to reduce osteoclast activation
Activation of the calcium-sensing receptor to reduce parathyroid hormone (PTH) secretion
Stimulation of osteoblast differentiation while inhibiting osteoclast function
Induction of intermittent parathyroid hormone (PTH) signaling to promote bone formation

questions.text: A 67-year-old postmenopausal woman with osteoporosis presents with a history of recurrent fractures despite adequate calcium and vitamin D supplementation. She is started on a new monoclonal antibody that inhibits sclerostin. After 6 months of treatment, her bone mineral density (BMD) improves significantly. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of this medication?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Stimulation of osteoblast differentiation while inhibiting osteoclast function

 

  • The patient is receiving romosozumab, a monoclonal antibody that inhibits sclerostin, a protein that suppresses bone formation. 
  • By blocking sclerostin, romosozumab stimulates osteoblasts to form new bone while also inhibiting osteoclast-mediated bone resorption, leading to increased bone density.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Inhibition of RANKL to reduce osteoclast activation: Incorrect. Denosumab inhibits RANKL, which reduces osteoclast formation and function. However, it does not stimulate osteoblast activity, unlike romosozumab.

 

Option B. Activation of calcium-sensing receptors to reduce parathyroid hormone (PTH) secretion: Incorrect. Cinacalcet lowers PTH secretion but does not directly increase bone formation or affect osteoclast activity.

 

Option D. Induction of intermittent parathyroid hormone (PTH) signaling to promote bone formation: Incorrect. Teriparatide is a recombinant PTH analog that stimulates osteoblasts, but it does not inhibit osteoclasts like romosozumab.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Romosozumab is a monoclonal antibody that inhibits sclerostin, leading to both increased bone formation and decreased bone resorption, making it effective for osteoporosis management.

choices.text: OR is an exact measure of risk, while RR is an approximation
OR is more accurate than RR in all study designs
OR overestimates RR when the disease is common
RR and OR are interchangeable in cohort studies

questions.text: Which of the following statements correctly differentiates Odds Ratio (OR) from Relative Risk (RR)?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) OR overestimates RR when the disease is common

 

  • Odds Ratio (OR) is an estimate of Relative Risk (RR) in case-control studies, but when a disease is common (prevalence >10%), OR tends to overestimate the actual RR.
  • In rare diseases, OR approximates RR closely.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. OR is an exact measure of risk, while RR is an approximation: OR is an estimate, while RR is a direct measure in cohort studies.

 

Option B. OR is more accurate than RR in all study designs: OR is less accurate in cohort studies.

 

Option D. RR and OR are interchangeable in cohort studies: They are not interchangeable in common diseases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Odds Ratio (OR) tends to overestimate Relative Risk (RR) when the disease is common, but they are similar when the disease is rare.

 

RR vs. OR

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding endolymph and perilymph in the inner ear are correct? 

 

  1. Endolymph is found within the membranous labyrinth, while perilymph is located between the membranous labyrinth and the bony labyrinth.
  2. Endolymph is rich in potassium ions, resembling intracellular fluid, whereas perilymph is rich in sodium and chloride ions, resembling extracellular fluid.
  3. Endolymph transmits sound waves to hair cells, while perilymph transmits sound waves to the endolymph.
  4. Perilymph has a more positive electric potential compared to endolymph.
  5. Endolymph and perilymph are functionally important for both hearing and balance.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 3 and 5

 

Statement 1: Endolymph is contained in the membranous labyrinth, whereas perilymph surrounds the membranous labyrinth and fills the space between it and the bony labyrinth.

 

Statement 2: Endolymph is rich in potassium ions (K⁺) and resembles intracellular fluid, while perilymph is rich in sodium (Na⁺) and chloride (Cl⁻), resembling extracellular fluid.

 

Statement 3: Perilymph transmits sound vibrations to the endolymph, which then stimulates the hair cells in the cochlea for hearing.

 

Statement 5: Both endolymph and perilymph are critical for hearing and balance. The cochlea relies on these fluids for sound transmission, while the semicircular canals and otolithic organs (utricle & saccule) use endolymph for balance detection.

 

Other Option: 

 

Statement 4: Incorrect – Perilymph does not have a more positive electric potential than endolymph.

 

  • Endolymph has a more positive electric potential due to its high K⁺ concentration (~80 mV).
  • Perilymph has a less positive electric potential (~0-5 mV), making the endocochlear potential crucial for hair cell activation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Endolymph is rich in potassium, found in the membranous labyrinth, and has a more positive electric potential, whereas perilymph is sodium-rich, found between the membranous and bony labyrinths, and transmits sound waves to the endolymph. 
  • Both are essential for hearing and balance.

choices.text: Halibut Liver Oil – Vitamin A and D

questions.text: Which of the following incorrectly pairs a food item with the vitamin it is richest in?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ragi (Millet) – Vitamin B1 (Thiamine)

 

  • Ragi is a rich source of calcium, not thiamine (Vitamin B1).
  • The richest sources of specific vitamins include:
    • Vitamin A & D – Halibut Liver Oil
    • Vitamin C – Indian Gooseberry (Amla)
    • Vitamin B2 – Sheep liver
    • Vitamin B1 – Gingelly seeds (not Ragi)

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ragi is rich in calcium, but the richest source of Vitamin B1 (Thiamine) is Gingelly seeds, not Ragi.

 

Food Sources of Nutrients

questions.text:
Match the following urinary buffers with their functions:

 

Column A (Urinary Buffer)

  1. Bicarbonate (HCO₃⁻)
  2. Ammonia (NH₃)
  3. Phosphate (PO₄³⁻)

 

Column B (Function)

  1. Acts as the main titratable buffer in the collecting duct
  2. Primary buffer in the renal tubular system
  3. Inducible buffer that increases in response to acid load
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-B, 2-C, 3-A

 

1-B: Bicarbonate (HCO₃⁻) is the main urinary buffer in normal conditions, responsible for maintaining acid-base balance.

 

2-C: Ammonia (NH₃) is an inducible buffer, meaning its production increases in response to acid load.

 

3-A: Phosphate (PO₄³⁻) acts as the main titratable buffer in the collecting duct, playing a role in fixed acid excretion.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • The kidney maintains acid-base balance using three main urinary buffers—bicarbonate (primary buffer), ammonia (inducible buffer), and phosphate (titratable buffer).

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida has a prepregnancy BMI of 30 kg/m². She is concerned about her weight gain during pregnancy and asks for guidance regarding the recommended weight gain. What is the recommended weight gain for her during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 5-7 kg

 

  • For women with a prepregnancy BMI ≥30 kg/m² (obese), the recommended total weight gain during a singleton pregnancy is 5–7 kg. 
  • This range minimizes the risks of pregnancy complications such as gestational diabetes, hypertension, and macrosomia while supporting fetal growth.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 8-11 kg: This weight gain range is recommended for women who are overweight (BMI 25–29.9 kg/m²), not for those with obesity.

 

Option C. 10-13 kg: This weight gain range is appropriate for women with a normal prepregnancy BMI (18.5–24.9 kg/m²).

 

Option D. 14-16 kg: This weight gain range is recommended for women who are underweight (BMI <18.5 kg/m²).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The recommended weight gain during pregnancy depends on prepregnancy BMI. For women with obesity (BMI ≥30 kg/m²), the recommended weight gain is 5-7 kg for optimal maternal and fetal outcomes.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male undergoing evaluation for gastrointestinal symptoms undergoes a series of diagnostic tests to assess the acidity levels of various digestive tract secretions. Which of the following secretions is expected to have the lowest pH?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gastric secretion

 

  • Gastric secretions have the lowest pH (1.0-3.5), making them the most acidic secretion in the GI tract.
  • Hydrochloric acid (HCl) is secreted by parietal cells, which maintains the acidic environment necessary for pepsin activation and protein digestion.
  • Chronic NSAID use inhibits prostaglandins, which reduces mucosal protection, leading to gastric ulcers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Salivary secretion (pH 6.0-7.0): Saliva is near-neutral and its primary function includes lubrication and initial digestion of carbohydrates, not acidification.

 

Option C. Pancreatic secretion (pH 8.0-8.3): Pancreatic secretions are alkaline, helping neutralize gastric acid in the duodenum.

 

Option D. Brunner’s gland secretion (pH 8.0-10): The most alkaline secretion, secreted by duodenal glands to protect against gastric acid.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Gastric secretions (pH 1.0-3.5) are the most acidic in the GI tract, primarily due to hydrochloric acid (HCl) from parietal cells, playing a key role in digestion and ulcer formation.

questions.text: A patient with hyper-IgE syndrome is found to have impaired antibody class switching due to a cytokine deficiency. Which of the following cytokines is most likely deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) IL-4

 

  • IL-4 is critical for IgE class switching and is responsible for promoting IgG1, IgE, and IgG4 production. Hyper-IgE syndrome (Job's syndrome) is caused by IL-4 overactivity leading to excessive IgE production.
  • Patients with IL-4 deficiency fail to undergo IgE class switching, leading to impaired Th2 responses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IFN-γ: IFN-γ is associated with IgG2a or IgG3 switching, primarily involved in Th1 responses.

 

Option B. IL-2: IL-2 promotes T-cell proliferation but does not directly influence class switching.

 

Option D. IL-5: IL-5 is responsible for IgA switching and eosinophil activation, not IgE production.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • IL-4 is essential for IgE class switching and plays a crucial role in the differentiation of Th2 cells, which mediate humoral immunity.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman who is 5 weeks pregnant presents to the emergency department with acute abdominal pain and signs of shock. She reports that her last menstrual period was 7 weeks ago. On physical examination, she has tenderness in the lower abdomen, particularly in the right adnexal region. A Doppler ultrasound shows the following appearance in the right adnexa. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tubal gestation

 

  • The Doppler ultrasound image presented in the question is consistent with a tubal ectopic pregnancy, where a fertilized egg implants outside the uterus, typically in the fallopian tube. 
  • The "ring of fire" sign on Doppler ultrasound, which is a hypervascular ring around the gestational sac, is a hallmark of tubal gestation. 
  • This condition often presents with abdominal pain, adnexal tenderness, and signs of internal bleeding or shock if the tube ruptures.
    • Clinical clues: The patient's early pregnancy (4 weeks), shock, abdominal pain, and Doppler findings strongly suggest an ectopic pregnancy.
    • Doppler findings: The hypervascular flow seen on Doppler imaging around the ectopic pregnancy is typical of the "ring of fire" appearance, which supports the diagnosis of tubal gestation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Theca lutein cyst: Theca lutein cysts are often seen in the setting of high hCG levels, such as in molar pregnancies or multiple gestations. They are generally not associated with acute abdominal pain or shock and do not present with the "ring of fire" appearance on Doppler ultrasound.

 

Option C. Torsion of ovarian cyst: Ovarian torsion involves the twisting of the ovary, leading to compromised blood flow and acute pain. However, the Doppler findings in ovarian torsion would show decreased or absent blood flow rather than the hypervascular "ring of fire" sign.

 

Option D. Red degeneration of fibroid: Red degeneration is a complication of fibroids during pregnancy, often presenting with localized pain but is not associated with the Doppler "ring of fire" appearance or adnexal masses typical of ectopic pregnancies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The "ring of fire" sign on Doppler ultrasound, in the setting of early pregnancy with acute abdominal pain and shock, is highly suggestive of tubal ectopic pregnancy. 
  • This condition requires urgent diagnosis and management to prevent complications such as tubal rupture and hemorrhagic shock.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman with rheumatoid arthritis presents with fatigue and pallor. Her laboratory results show:

  • Hemoglobin: 10.1 g/dL
  • MCV: 75 fL
  • RBC count: 3.2 million/µL
  • Serum ferritin: Elevated
  • Serum iron: Low
  • Total iron-binding capacity: Low

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anemia of chronic disease

 

  • This patient has microcytic anemia (MCV <80 fL) with high ferritin and low iron levels, consistent with anemia of chronic disease (ACD).
    • The Mentzer index is >13, which rules out thalassemia.
    • Ferritin is elevated, distinguishing ACD from iron deficiency anemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. β-thalassemia minor: Incorrect. Thalassemia has a Mentzer index <13 and normal iron studies.

 

Option B. Sideroblastic anemia: Incorrect. Sideroblastic anemia presents with ringed sideroblasts and is usually normocytic.

 

Option D. Iron deficiency anemia: Incorrect. Iron deficiency presents with low ferritin and high TIBC, not low TIBC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Anemia of chronic disease presents with a high Mentzer index, normal or high ferritin, and low iron levels.

choices.text: Restoring normal anatomy at the earliest
Restoring normal physiology in the ICU

questions.text: A young man suffered multiple severe injuries after a road traffic accident. On examination- Pulse- 120/min, BP- 84/60 mm Hg, which remains deranged despite 1 liter of bolus fluids. He is diagnosed with a pelvic fracture, tibial shaft fracture, and an intra-abdominal bleed.  In such a severe trauma case, Damage Control Surgery (DCS) was considered. Which of the following is not a goal of DCS?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Restoring normal anatomy at the earliest

 

  • Damage Control Surgery (DCS) is a strategy used in the management of critically injured patients, particularly those with severe trauma who are at risk for the lethal triad of hypothermia, acidosis, and coagulopathy. 
  • Restoring normal anatomy at the earliest is not the immediate goal of DCS. While eventual restoration of normal anatomy is a goal, the initial focus of DCS is on stabilization, not immediate definitive repair.

 

Other Options:

 

  • The primary goal is to prioritize the patient's physiological status over anatomical repair to increase survival rates. The goals of DCS include:

 

Option B. Stopping any active surgical bleed: Immediate control of hemorrhage is crucial to prevent further deterioration of the patient's condition.

 

Option C. Controlling contamination: This includes controlling spillage from gastrointestinal injuries or other sources of contamination.

 

Option D. Restoring normal physiology in the ICU: Before definitive surgical repair, the priority is to stabilize the patient's physiological parameters in the ICU, correcting hypothermia, acidosis, and coagulopathy.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • To understand the principles and goals of Damage Control Surgery in the context of severe trauma. DCS prioritizes the stabilization of the patient's physiological state and control of life-threatening conditions over immediate anatomical reconstruction.

choices.text: Cryoprecipitate contains all clotting factors, whereas FFP does not
Cryoprecipitate is rich in fibrinogen and provides rapid correction of hypofibrinogenemia
Cryoprecipitate has a longer half-life than FFP
Cryoprecipitate corrects thrombocytopenia more effectively than FFP

questions.text:
A 27-year-old woman presents with features of amniotic fluid embolism and develops severe postpartum hemorrhage. Laboratory tests show:

  • PT: Prolonged
  • aPTT: Prolonged
  • INR: 3.0
  • Fibrinogen: 50 mg/dL (Normal: 200-400 mg/dL)
  • Platelets: 90,000/µL
  • D-dimer: Elevated

Which of the following best explains why cryoprecipitate is preferred over fresh frozen plasma (FFP) in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cryoprecipitate is rich in fibrinogen and provides rapid correction of hypofibrinogenemia

 

  • This patient has severe postpartum hemorrhage with DIC, leading to critical hypofibrinogenemia (<100 mg/dL). 
  • Cryoprecipitate is preferred over FFP in DIC because it contains concentrated fibrinogen, von Willebrand factor, and factor XIII, providing rapid hemostasis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cryoprecipitate contains all clotting factors, whereas FFP does not: Cryoprecipitate contains all clotting factors, whereas FFP does not – Incorrect. FFP contains all clotting factors, but cryoprecipitate is richer in fibrinogen, vWF, and factor XIII.

 

Option C. Cryoprecipitate has a longer half-life than FFP: Incorrect. FFP and cryoprecipitate have similar half-lives, but cryoprecipitate has a higher concentration of fibrinogen per unit.

 

Option D. Cryoprecipitate corrects thrombocytopenia more effectively than FFP: Incorrect. Neither cryoprecipitate nor FFP correct thrombocytopenia; platelet transfusion is required for that.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In DIC with severe hypofibrinogenemia, cryoprecipitate is preferred over FFP due to its high fibrinogen concentration, ensuring rapid hemostasis.

questions.text: A CTG tracing reveals fetal tachycardia (>160 bpm), no decelerations, and variability of 20 bpm. What is the most likely clinical implication of this finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Maternal fever or dehydration

 

  • Fetal tachycardia with preserved variability and no decelerations is often caused by maternal conditions such as fever, dehydration, or infections like chorioamnionitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fetal hypoxia: Hypoxia usually reduces variability and may cause decelerations, neither of which are present here.

 

Option B. Fetal well-being: While variability is reassuring, fetal tachycardia suggests an underlying maternal or fetal issue.

 

Option D. Umbilical cord prolapse: This would typically cause bradycardia or variable decelerations, not tachycardia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Fetal tachycardia with preserved variability and no decelerations often indicates maternal factors like fever or dehydration and requires maternal evaluation and management.

questions.text: A 50-year-old diver develops severe otitis externa and conjunctivitis after diving in warm coastal waters. Culture of the external ear discharge grows a halophilic, oxidase-positive, Gram-negative rod that tolerates >10% NaCl concentration. Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for his infection?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vibrio alginolyticus

 

  • Vibrio alginolyticus is the most salt-tolerant Vibrio (>10% NaCl) and is associated with eye, ear, and wound infections in individuals exposed to marine environments.
  • Common in divers, fishermen, and those with water-related trauma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vibrio vulnificus: Causes wound infections leading to necrotizing fasciitis and sepsis, but is not associated with otitis externa.

 

Option B. Vibrio cholerae: Causes cholera (profuse watery diarrhea) but is not associated with otitis or conjunctivitis.

 

Option D. Vibrio parahaemolyticus: Primarily causes gastroenteritis, not external infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Vibrio alginolyticus is the most salt-tolerant Vibrio and commonly causes otitis externa and conjunctivitis in marine-exposed individuals.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents to the clinic with concerns about spots as shown below. He states that these spots have been present for several years and have remained unchanged. On examination, these lesions are asymptomatic and non-tender. What do these spots most likely represent?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ectopic sebaceous glands

 

  • These small, painless, pale yellow spots on the mucosal surfaces represent Fordyce spots, which are ectopic sebaceous glands.
  • Normally, sebaceous glands are found in association with hair follicles, but in Fordyce spots, they appear in mucosal areas without hair follicles, making them ectopic.
  • Common sites include the inner lips, buccal mucosa, and genitalia.
  • Benign condition, no treatment required.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ectopic mucosal glands:

 

  • Mucosal glands secrete mucus and are found in various mucous membranes.
  • They do not present as pale yellow spots like Fordyce spots.

 

Option C. Ectopic apocrine glands:

 

  • Apocrine sweat glands are found in axillae, areola, and genital areas.
  • They do not appear as pale yellow spots on mucosal surfaces.

 

Option D. Ectopic eccrine glands:

 

  • Eccrine glands are widely distributed sweat glands involved in thermoregulation.
  • They do not form visible mucosal spots, distinguishing them from Fordyce spots.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Fordyce Spots and Ectopic Sebaceous Glands

choices.text: Steri-Strips; to close small cuts or incisions
Hydrocolloid dressing; to promote moist wound healing
Antimicrobial dressing; to prevent infection at the site

questions.text: What is the device shown in the image called and what is their primary purpose?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Steri-Strips; to close small cuts or incisions

 

  • The device shown in the image are Steri-Strips, which are adhesive skin closure strips used primarily for closing small cuts, lacerations, or surgical incisions. 
  • They provide wound support and increase the tensile strength of the wound, while reducing the need for sutures or staples, thus minimizing scarring.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Compression bandage; to control bleeding: Incorrect because compression bandages are used to apply pressure to larger areas and are not adhesive strips.

 

Option C. Hydrocolloid dressing; to promote moist wound healing: Incorrect as hydrocolloid dressings are opaque and gel-forming, used to treat uninfected wounds by creating a moist environment.

 

Option D. Antimicrobial dressing; to prevent infection at the site: Incorrect because antimicrobial dressings are designed to reduce the risk of infection and are typically embedded with substances like silver or iodine.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Steri-Strips are adhesive strips used to close and support small wounds, reducing the need for sutures and minimizing scarring.

questions.text: A study is conducted to compare the median fasting glucose levels between three groups: patients with Type 1 diabetes, Type 2 diabetes, and healthy controls. The data is not normally distributed. Which statistical test is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Kruskal-Wallis test

 

  • The Kruskal-Wallis test is a non-parametric alternative to ANOVA, used when comparing three or more independent groups with non-normally distributed data. 
  • Since the study involves comparing fasting glucose levels among three groups with non-normal distribution, Kruskal-Wallis is the best choice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ANOVA test: Used when comparing means across three groups, but this study involves non-normal data, requiring a non-parametric alternative.

 

Option C. Paired t-test: Used for paired data, not multiple independent groups.

 

Option D. Wilcoxon signed-rank test: Used for paired non-parametric data, but this study compares three independent groups.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Kruskal-Wallis test is a non-parametric alternative to ANOVA, used for comparing three or more independent groups with non-normally distributed data.

 

Key Concepts:

questions.text: The figure illustrates the mechanisms of action of various antiviral drugs targeting different stages of the influenza virus lifecycle. Baloxavir marboxil, an antiviral used to treat influenza, specifically inhibits a key enzyme required for viral mRNA synthesis. Which labeled step (A, B, C, or D) in the figure corresponds to the mechanism of action of baloxavir marboxil?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) C

 

  • Baloxavir marboxil inhibits cap-dependent endonuclease, a critical enzyme that allows the influenza virus to "cap-snatch" host mRNA and initiate viral transcription.
  • Step C in the figure represents the inhibition of cap-dependent endonuclease, which blocks viral mRNA synthesis and prevents replication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Viral entry inhibition:

 

  • Represents viral attachment and entry into the host cell.
  • Drugs that act here: Amantadine, Enfuvirtide (HIV fusion inhibitor).

 

Option B. Viral uncoating inhibition:

 

  • Represents viral genome release after entry.
  • Drugs that act here: Amantadine, Rimantadine (M2 ion channel blockers, rarely used due to resistance).

 

Option D. Viral release inhibition:

 

  • Represents viral budding and release from the host cell.
  • Drugs that act here: Oseltamivir, Zanamivir (neuraminidase inhibitors).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Baloxavir marboxil targets cap-dependent endonuclease, blocking influenza virus mRNA transcription and replication. 
  • Unlike neuraminidase inhibitors (oseltamivir) that prevent viral release, baloxavir stops viral replication at an earlier stage.

questions.text: An 84-year-old man presents with confusion for 3 hours. He has a history of asthma, managed with salbutamol and beclomethasone inhalers. His temperature is 29.8°C, and his Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) is 12. He is noticeably shivering and is disoriented to time and place. What is the most likely change seen on this man’s ECG?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) J waves

 

The patient presents with features of hypothermia:

 

  • Core temperature 29.8°C (consistent with mild hypothermia, defined as 28–32°C)
  • Confusion and reduced GCS (12) (common in hypothermia due to cerebral dysfunction)
  • Shivering (a classic compensatory response in mild hypothermia)

 

ECG Finding in Hypothermia:

 

The hallmark ECG change in hypothermia is the presence of J waves (Osborn waves), which appear as a positive deflection at the junction of the QRS complex and the ST segment.

 

Why J Waves Occur in Hypothermia:

 

  • Hypothermia leads to:
    • Delayed repolarization due to exaggerated outward potassium currents
    • This causes a characteristic J wave (Osborn wave) on the ECG.
  • More severe hypothermia can also cause:
    • Bradycardia
    • Prolonged PR, QRS, and QT intervals
    • Atrial fibrillation or ventricular fibrillation (in severe cases)

 

What Are J Waves (Osborn Waves)?

 

  • Definition: A distinct positive deflection occurring at the J-point (where the QRS complex meets the ST segment).
  • Shape: Rounded or notched appearance, best seen in leads V3–V6.
  • Significance: A classic marker of hypothermia, but can also be seen in:
    • Hypercalcemia
    • Brain injury (e.g., subarachnoid hemorrhage)
    • Sepsis or other metabolic disturbances

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Shortened QT interval: More typical of hypercalcemia, not hypothermia.

 

Option C. ST depression: Can occur in myocardial ischemia, digoxin effect, or hypokalemia, but is not specific for hypothermia.

 

Option D. Tented T-waves: Suggestive of hyperkalemia, commonly due to renal failure or acidosis, not hypothermia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hypothermia (28–32°C) Causes:
    • J waves (Osborn waves) (most characteristic finding)
    • Bradycardia and prolonged intervals (PR, QRS, QT)
    • Arrhythmias (e.g., atrial fibrillation, ventricular fibrillation)
  • Management:
    • Rewarming (active or passive): Warmed IV fluids, blankets, or heated humidified air
    • Correction of electrolyte imbalances
    • Cardiac monitoring (risk of arrhythmias during rewarming)

choices.text: Hallucinations can occur in any sensory modality, including auditory, visual, olfactory, gustatory, and tactile.
Hypnagogic hallucinations occur while falling asleep and are commonly associated with narcolepsy.
Hallucinations always indicate the presence of a psychiatric disorder and are never seen in medical conditions.
Charles Bonnet syndrome is characterized by visual hallucinations in patients with significant vision loss.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding hallucinations is not true?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hallucinations always indicate the presence of a psychiatric disorder and are never seen in medical conditions.

 

  • Hallucinations are perceptions without an external stimulus and can occur in various conditions, including psychiatric disorders (e.g., schizophrenia), neurological disorders, and medical conditions. 
  • They are not exclusive to psychiatric illnesses. Medical causes of hallucinations include delirium, Parkinson’s disease, Lewy body dementia, and intoxication or withdrawal from substances.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hallucinations can occur in any sensory modality, including auditory, visual, olfactory, gustatory, and tactile: True. Hallucinations can affect any sensory modality, with auditory hallucinations being the most common in psychiatric disorders (e.g., schizophrenia), and visual hallucinations more common in neurological conditions.

 

Option B. Hypnagogic hallucinations occur while falling asleep and are commonly associated with narcolepsy: True. Hypnagogic hallucinations (while falling asleep) and hypnopompic hallucinations (while waking up) are seen in narcolepsy and can also occur in healthy individuals.

 

Option D. Charles Bonnet syndrome is characterized by visual hallucinations in patients with significant vision loss: True. Charles Bonnet syndrome refers to visual hallucinations in individuals with severe visual impairment (e.g., macular degeneration).
