These hallucinations are usually non-threatening and occur due to deafferentation of the visual cortex.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hallucinations can occur in both psychiatric and medical conditions. 

 

  • The most common type of hallucination, overall: Auditory
  • The most common type of hallucination associated with organic mental disorders is visual hallucination. 
  • Cocaine intoxication: Tactile hallucination 
  • Olfactory and gustatory hallucination- Temporal lobe disorders (like temporal lobe epilepsy)

questions.text: A 21-year-old male was brought to ER after slipping while catching a ball in a cricket match. Upon further investigation, there is tibial torsion secondary to fall. Which of the following will be seen in this patient ?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lateral patellar subluxation

 

  • Lateral patellar subluxation means the patella shifts outward.
  • External tibial torsion increases the Q angle, which is the angle between the quadriceps muscle and the patellar tendon. 
  • An increased Q angle predisposes the patella to lateral subluxation.
  • Lateral patellar subluxation is the most common form of patellar instability, especially in cases with rotational abnormalities of the lower limb.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Medial patellar subluxation: Medial patellar subluxation means the patella shifts inward. While less common, it can occur in certain situations, but it's not the typical result of tibial torsion. Medial patellar subluxation is less likely to be caused by tibial torsion.

 

Option C. Superior patellar subluxation: Superior patellar subluxation is not commonly used in clinical practice. Patellar movement is usually described in terms of medial/lateral or anterior/posterior displacement. This is not a recognized form of patellar subluxation.

 

Option D. Interior patellar subluxation:  Similarly, interior patellar subluxation is not standard medical terminology. Patellar movement is not described in this way. This is also not a recognized form of patellar subluxation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • External tibial torsion alters the biomechanics of the knee, increasing the lateral forces acting on the patella. 
  • This makes lateral patellar subluxation the most likely consequence.

choices.text: NH₃ buffering is constitutive and does not increase with acid load.
Bicarbonate (HCO₃⁻) is the only urinary buffer.
Phosphate (PO₄³⁻) is a titratable acid that helps in acid excretion.
The distal tubule is the primary site of NH₃ production.

questions.text: Which of the following statement regarding urinary acid excretion is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Phosphate (PO₄³⁻) is a titratable acid that helps in acid excretion.

 

  • Phosphate (PO₄³⁻) acts as a titratable acid, meaning it binds to hydrogen ions in the urine, aiding in acid excretion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. NH₃ buffering is constitutive and does not increase with acid load: NH₃ (ammonia) production increases in response to acid load as an adaptive mechanism.

 

Option B. Bicarbonate (HCO₃⁻) is the only urinary buffer: While bicarbonate is an important buffer, it is not the only urinary buffer—NH₃ and phosphate also play significant roles.

 

Option D. The distal tubule is the primary site of NH₃ production: NH₃ is primarily produced in the proximal tubule, not the distal tubule.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Urinary acid excretion relies on three buffers—bicarbonate, ammonia, and phosphate (titratable acid), with phosphate playing a key role in titratable acid excretion.

questions.text: A 19-year-old male with cystic fibrosis presents with recurrent pulmonary infections. Despite prolonged antibiotic therapy, his respiratory cultures consistently grow Pseudomonas aeruginosa. The strain isolated from his sputum is found to have a mucoid appearance on culture. Which of the following is the most significant characteristic of this mucoid strain that contributes to its persistence and pathogenicity?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Produces biofilms

 

  • Mucoid strains of Pseudomonas aeruginosa produce a thick extracellular polysaccharide matrix (alginate biofilm), which enhances adherence to surfaces and protects against host immune responses and antibiotics.
  • Biofilm formation is a key virulence factor in chronic infections, particularly in cystic fibrosis (CF) patients, leading to persistent lung colonization, increased antibiotic tolerance, and worsening lung function.
  • Alginate production also enhances resistance to phagocytosis, making these infections difficult to clear.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Exhibits more drug resistance: 

 

  • Biofilm formation contributes indirectly to antibiotic resistance by limiting drug penetration, but mucoid strains themselves do not inherently exhibit more genetic drug resistance compared to non-mucoid strains.
  • Some non-mucoid strains may develop multidrug resistance (MDR) via efflux pumps or β-lactamase production.

 

Option C. Secretes more toxins: 

 

  • Pseudomonas aeruginosa secretes multiple virulence factors (e.g., exotoxin A, elastase, pyocyanin), but these are not increased specifically due to the mucoid phenotype.
  • Non-mucoid strains can also be highly toxigenic and aggressive in acute infections.

 

Option D. Produces more bacteriocins: 

 

  • Bacteriocins are antimicrobial peptides that kill competing bacterial strains.
  • They play a role in microbial competition but are not a key factor in chronic infections or biofilm-related persistence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Mucoid strains of Pseudomonas aeruginosa produce an extracellular alginate biofilm, which promotes chronic infections by increasing adhesion, resisting phagocytosis, and reducing antibiotic penetration. 
  • This biofilm formation is particularly significant in cystic fibrosis patients, where it leads to persistent lung infections and progressive pulmonary decline.

questions.text: A 22-year-old female presents with lesions on her back as shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pityriasis rosea

 

  • A self-limiting skin condition that typically begins with a single larger "herald patch", followed by the eruption of multiple annular erythematous lesions with a collarette of scales.
  • Lesions are symmetrically distributed on the trunk in a characteristic "Christmas tree" pattern.
  • The exact cause is unknown, but it is believed to be viral in origin (linked to HHV-6 and HHV-7).
  • Resolves spontaneously within 6-12 weeks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pityriasis Versicolor:

 

  • Fungal infection (Malassezia species) presenting as hypo- or hyperpigmented macules and patches.
  • Lacks annular lesions with collarette scaling seen in pityriasis rosea.

 

Option B. Pityriasis Rubra Pilaris:

 

  • Characterized by follicular papules, erythematous plaques, and scaling, often on the scalp, face, and extremities.
  • Does not have annular lesions or collarette of scales.

 

Option D. Pityriasis Lichenoides Chronica:

 

  • Presents as chronic, scaly, recurrent papules and plaques, primarily on the trunk and extremities.
  • Lacks the annular distribution and herald patch characteristic of pityriasis rosea.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Pityriasis Rosea Diagnosis and Features

choices.text: Patient can be admitted involuntarily only if a court order is obtained.
Consent from a legal guardian/nominated representative is needed for admission.
Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) without anesthesia is permitted for this patient.

questions.text: A 17-year-old male with schizophrenia is brought to the emergency department by his family due to aggressive behavior and refusal to take medications. On mental status examination, he has paranoid delusions and auditory hallucinations, with poor insight into his condition. Despite attempts at verbal de-escalation, he refuses all treatment and poses a risk to himself and others. The psychiatrist decides to admit him involuntarily under the provisions of the Mental Healthcare Act (MHCA), 2017. Which of the following statements regarding MHCA, 2017 is correct in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Consent from a legal guardian/nominated representative is needed for admission.

 

  • Under the Mental Healthcare Act (MHCA), 2017, a minor (under 18 years) cannot make independent healthcare decisions, including voluntary or supported (involuntary) admission.
  • Since the patient in this case is 17 years old, their nominated representative (NR) or legal guardian must provide consent for admission.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Patient can be admitted involuntarily only if a court order is obtained: A court order is not required for involuntary admission. Instead, certification by psychiatrists and consent from the nominated representative/legal guardian are sufficient.

 

Option C. Advance directive is applicable here: Advance directives do not apply to minors under MHCA 2017. Only adults (18+ years) can create an advance directive regarding their mental healthcare preferences.

 

Option D. Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) without anesthesia is permitted for this patient: ECT without anesthesia is banned under MHCA 2017. Additionally, ECT in minors is prohibited unless approved by the MHRB and performed under strict medical supervision.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For minors (under 18 years), admission requires certification by psychiatrists and consent from a nominated representative or legal guardian.
  • Advance directives do not apply to minors, and ECT without anesthesia is prohibited.
  • The MHRB must be informed within 72 hours of admission for women and minors, ensuring their rights are protected under MHCA, 2017.

choices.text: It involves removal of the brain first, which allows for better preservation of the cranial contents in cases of congenital abnormalities.
It helps to preserve relationship between organs as they are found in situ, making it easier to identify anomalies in malformations without disturbing anatomical arrangement.
It allows opening the chest and abdominal cavities in sequence, which helps to better identify congenital anomalies, as compared to Ghon's, Virchow's, or Rokitansky's.
It involves the dissection of the spinal cord first, which is particularly useful for infants with congenital malformations.

questions.text: Which is the most important reason for preferring Letulle’s technique of autopsy in infants, particularly when congenital anomalies are suspected?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It helps to preserve the relationship between the organs as they are found in situ, making it easier to identify anomalies without disturbing anatomical arrangement.

 

  • Letulle's technique is commonly used in infants, because it emphasizes preserving the anatomical relationships of the organs during the autopsy process. 
  • The key feature of this technique is Preservation of organ positioning. The relative positions of the organs are not disturbed. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It involves removal of the brain first, which allows for better preservation of the cranial contents in cases of congenital abnormalities: It involves removal of the brain first, which allows for better preservation of the cranial contents in cases of congenital abnormalities. Incorrect. The removal of the brain is not the primary reason for letulle technique use in congenital anomaly cases.

 

Option C. It allows opening the chest and abdominal cavities in sequence, which helps to better identify congenital anomalies, as compared to Ghon's, Virchow's, or Rokitansky's: It allows opening the chest and abdominal cavities in sequence, which helps to better identify congenital anomalies, as compared to Ghons, Virchows, or Rokitansy. Incorrect. The sequence of opening the chest and abdominal cavities isn't the central advantage of Letulle's technique. The key feature is the preservation of organ relationships and the careful dissection that allows for detailed examination of any malformations.

 

Option D. It involves the dissection of the spinal cord first, which is particularly useful for infants with congenital malformations: It involves the dissection of the spinal cord first, which is particularly useful for infants with congenital malformations. Incorrect. The Letulle technique does not prioritize dissection of the spinal cord first. Instead, it focuses on the careful preservation of organ relationships and is more concerned with the overall anatomical layout.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Learn the advantages of Letulle’s autopsy technique in infants, particularly for examining congenital anomalies. 
  • This method is preferred due to its ability to preserve the anatomical relationships between organs, allowing for an undisturbed and comprehensive evaluation of organ positioning and structural malformations, crucial for accurate diagnosis and understanding of congenital conditions.

questions.text: A scientist is studying a mutation affecting transcription. The mutation changes the DNA template strand from GATCTAC to GATGTAC. What will be the corresponding mRNA sequence after transcription?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 5'-GUACAUC-3'

 

To determine the corresponding mRNA sequence from a DNA template strand, we need to follow the rules of transcription:

 

1. Identify the DNA template strand: The mutated DNA template strand is given as GATGTAC. Unless otherwise specified, DNA sequences are typically written in the 5' to 3' direction. So, we assume the template strand is 5'-GATGTAC-3'.

 

2. Recall the direction of reading: During transcription, RNA polymerase reads the template strand in the 3' to 5' direction. Therefore, to transcribe the 5'-GATGTAC-3' template, we must read it in reverse, which is 3'-CATGTAG-5'.

 

3. Apply base-pairing rules: The mRNA sequence will be complementary to this 3' to 5' template strand, with uracil (U) replacing thymine (T) in RNA. The mRNA is synthesized with a 5' to 3' polarity.

 

Let's transcribe the 3'-CATGTAG-5' DNA template:

 

  • Template C pairs with mRNA G
  • Template A pairs with mRNA U
  • Template T pairs with mRNA A
  • Template G pairs with mRNA C
  • Template T pairs with mRNA A
  • Template A pairs with mRNA U
  • Template G pairs with mRNA C

 

Combining these, the resulting mRNA sequence, read in the 5' to 3' direction, is 5'-GUACAUC-3'.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding fetal circulation are true? 

 

  1. The inferior vena cava (IVC) has a higher oxygen concentration compared to the superior vena cava (SVC).
  2. The umbilical vein carries highly oxygenated blood from the placenta to the fetus.
  3. Pressures in the right and left ventricles are unequal in the fetal circulation.
  4. The liver receives blood with lower oxygen saturation compared to the brain.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2 and 4

 

Statement 1. The inferior vena cava (IVC) has a higher oxygen concentration compared to the superior vena cava (SVC): True.

 

  • The IVC has a higher oxygen concentration than the SVC because it receives blood from the umbilical vein, which carries oxygenated blood from the placenta.
  • The SVC carries deoxygenated blood from the upper body of the fetus, leading to a lower oxygen concentration.

 

Statement 2. The umbilical vein carries highly oxygenated blood from the placenta to the fetus: True.

 

  • The umbilical vein carries oxygen-rich blood from the placenta.
  • 50% of this blood enters the liver, while the rest bypasses the liver via the ductus venosus, reaching the IVC.

 

Statement 4. The liver receives blood with lower oxygen saturation compared to the brain: True.

 

  • The brain receives more oxygenated blood compared to the liver.
  • Blood from the IVC is preferentially directed to the foramen ovale, ensuring more oxygenated blood reaches the brain and upper body

 

Other Option:

 

Statement 3. Pressures in the right and left ventricles are unequal in the fetal circulation: False.

 

  • In fetal circulation, the right and left ventricular pressures are EQUAL due to the presence of shunts (foramen ovale and ductus arteriosus), which reduce pressure differences.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: What anatomical structure does A represent in the given image?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Surgical neck of humerus

 

  • The surgical neck of the humerus is the junction between the expanded upper end and the shaft of the humerus. 
  • It forms the lateral boundary of the quadrangular space, through which the axillary nerve and posterior circumflex humeral artery pass.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anatomical neck of the humerus: A narrow constriction immediately distal to the head of the humerus.

 

Option B. Shaft of the humerus: Contains the radial groove on its posterior surface and forms the lateral boundary of the lower triangular space.

 

Option D. Deltoid tuberosity of the humerus: A V-shaped area on the anterolateral surface of the humeral shaft where the deltoid muscle inserts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The surgical neck of the humerus is a common site for fractures and forms the lateral boundary of the quadrangular space.

choices.text: hRIG is significantly more effective than eRIG
eRIG requires skin testing before administration due to hypersensitivity risk
eRIG is more cost-effective and has similar clinical outcomes as hRIG
eRIG is contraindicated in immunocompromised individuals

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with a Category III dog bite and requires Rabies Immunoglobulin (RIG). The hospital has equine RIG (eRIG) and human RIG (hRIG) available. Which of the following statements is correct regarding these immunoglobulins?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) eRIG is more cost-effective and has similar clinical outcomes as hRIG

 

  • Both equine RIG (eRIG) and human RIG (hRIG) have demonstrated similar clinical effectiveness in preventing rabies.
  • eRIG is less expensive and widely available, making it the preferred choice in resource-limited settings.
  • Highly purified eRIG products do not require prior skin testing, as the risk of hypersensitivity is low.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. hRIG is significantly more effective than eRIG: Both have similar efficacy in preventing rabies.

 

Option B. eRIG requires skin testing before administration due to hypersensitivity risk: Modern eRIG formulations are highly purified, eliminating the need for skin testing.

 

Option D. eRIG is contraindicated in immunocompromised individuals: eRIG is safe for use in immunocompromised individuals.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Equine Rabies Immunoglobulin (eRIG) is more cost-effective and has similar clinical outcomes as Human Rabies Immunoglobulin (hRIG). 
  • Modern eRIG does not require prior skin testing.

choices.text: Cases occur continuously beyond the longest incubation period

questions.text: A large-scale foodborne outbreak occurs at a wedding where multiple guests consume contaminated food. Which of the following characteristics best describes this type of outbreak?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Explosive

 

  • A single exposure common vehicle outbreak occurs when a large number of people are exposed to a contaminated source (e.g., food, water) at the same time, leading to an explosive increase in cases within a short incubation period.
  • No secondary transmission occurs, meaning cases do not continue beyond the expected incubation period of the pathogen.
  • A classic example is foodborne outbreaks, such as Salmonella or Staphylococcus aureus toxin exposure, where symptoms appear suddenly and peak rapidly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Frequent secondary cases:

 

  • A common vehicle outbreak does not cause frequent secondary transmission because all cases originate from a single exposure.
  • Secondary cases are more typical of person-to-person transmitted diseases (e.g., measles, influenza).

 

Option B. Severity increases with increasing age:

 

  • While older individuals may be more vulnerable to infections, this is not a defining characteristic of common vehicle outbreaks.
  • Severity by age is more relevant in infections like influenza or varicella, where older adults and immunocompromised individuals are at higher risk of complications.

 

Option D. Cases occur continuously beyond the longest incubation period:

 

  • In single exposure outbreaks, new cases do not continue beyond the incubation period of the pathogen.
  • Continuous cases would suggest an ongoing exposure or a propagated outbreak (e.g., tuberculosis, COVID-19, hepatitis A outbreaks).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A single exposure common vehicle outbreak is characterized by an "explosive" increase in cases within a short incubation period, with no secondary transmission and no cases occurring beyond the expected incubation period of the pathogen.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with postmenopausal osteoporosis is started on zoledronate for fracture prevention. Which of the following is the most serious adverse effect associated with zoledronate?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acute renal failure

 

  • Zoledronate (zoledronic acid) is an intravenous bisphosphonate used for osteoporosis, Paget’s disease, and hypercalcemia of malignancy.
  • A serious adverse effect of zoledronate is acute kidney injury (AKI) due to nephrotoxicity.
  • Bisphosphonates, especially IV forms, can cause renal tubular damage and renal failure, particularly in patients with pre-existing kidney disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ventricular fibrillation: Zoledronate does not cause arrhythmias.

 

Option C. Peptic ulcer: Oral bisphosphonates (e.g., alendronate) can cause esophagitis, but zoledronate is given IV and does not cause peptic ulcers.

 

Option D. Anterior uveitis: Zoledronate has been associated with ocular inflammation (e.g., scleritis, uveitis), but this is rare compared to nephrotoxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Zoledronate can cause acute renal failure due to nephrotoxicity, particularly in patients with pre-existing kidney disease. 
  • Renal function should be monitored before and after infusion.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man with chronic kidney disease (CKD) is undergoing blood work. His physician orders:

  1. Serum electrolytes (sodium, potassium, chloride, bicarbonate)
  2. Renal function tests (BUN, creatinine)
  3. Glucose levels
  4. PT/aPTT

Which of the following tubes should be avoided for potassium measurement due to the risk of false hyperkalemia?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lavender 

 

  • EDTA contains potassium-based anticoagulants, leading to false hyperkalemia if used for electrolyte testing.
  • Potassium should be measured using a serum tube (red), not an EDTA tube.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Red (Serum tube): Correct for electrolyte testing.

 

Option B. Light blue (Citrate tube): Used for coagulation studies, not electrolytes.

 

Option D. Yellow: Yellow useful for electrolyte testing

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • EDTA (lavender tube) contains potassium and should not be used for potassium measurements due to the risk of false hyperkalemia.

questions.text: A scientist is designing a drug that can reduce oxidative damage in cells by maintaining proteins in a reduced state. The drug primarily acts by increasing the intracellular concentration of a key antioxidant. Which of the following molecules is most likely enhanced by this drug?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Glutathione

 

  • Glutathione (GSH) is a major intracellular antioxidant that maintains proteins in a reduced state by preventing unwanted disulfide bond formation.
  • It is synthesized from cysteine, glutamate, and glycine and is crucial for protecting cells from oxidative stress.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Homocysteine: Incorrect. Homocysteine is a precursor in methionine metabolism but does not act as a primary antioxidant.

 

Option C. Methionine: Incorrect. Methionine is involved in methylation but does not function as an antioxidant.

 

Option D. Cystine: Incorrect. Cystine is the oxidized form of cysteine but does not serve as a major antioxidant.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glutathione is a key intracellular antioxidant that maintains protein sulfhydryl groups in a reduced state, protecting cells from oxidative stress.

questions.text: According to the latest CPR guidelines, what is the recommended depth of chest compressions for an infant during CPR?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1.5 inches

 

  • For infants (0 to 1 year), the recommended depth of chest compressions is about 1.5 inches (4 cm). 
  • This depth ensures effective circulation while minimizing the risk of injury.

 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • For infants (0 to 1 year), the recommended depth of chest compressions is about 1.5 inches (4 cm).

questions.text: Identify the correct labelling of the ulcer in the given image.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Edge

 

Parts of an ulcer are clearly defined:

 


 

Edge: Junction between floor and skin 

 

Floor: Visible surface of ulcer that can be seen

 

Base: Tissue on which floor rests (not visible but can be palpated)

 

Margin: Where edge merges with surrounding healthy skin

 

Key characteristics:

 

Edge provides important diagnostic clues:

 

  • Punched out in trophic ulcer
  • Undermined in tuberculous ulcer
  • Everted in malignant ulcer
  • Sloping in healing ulcer

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Edge of an ulcer is the junction between floor and surrounding skin, and its characteristics provide important diagnostic clues.

questions.text: Which of the following genetic control techniques is most commonly used in large-scale mosquito population suppression programs?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sterile male technique

 

  • Sterile Male Technique (SMT) is a genetic control method where radiation is used to sterilize male mosquitoes before releasing them into the wild.
  • These sterile males compete with wild males for mating, leading to a reduction in viable offspring and gradual population decline.
  • This method has been successful in controlling Anopheles and Aedes mosquito species.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pyrethrum fumigation: A chemical method, not a genetic control strategy.

 

Option C. Use of predator insects: Part of biological control, not genetic modification.

 

Option D. Introduction of hormonal growth regulators: This method alters development, but does not involve genetic modifications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Sterile Male Technique (SMT) is a widely used genetic method in vector control programs to reduce mosquito populations by preventing reproduction.

choices.text: Plecanatide increases chloride secretion via CFTR, while lubiprostone activates type 2 chloride channels (CIC-2)
Plecanatide is used for opioid-induced constipation, while lubiprostone is used for diarrhea-predominant IBS
Plecanatide works via serotonin receptors, while lubiprostone blocks dopamine receptors
Plecanatide slows gastric emptying, while lubiprostone accelerates it

questions.text: Which of the following best differentiates plecanatide from lubiprostone?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Plecanatide increases chloride secretion via CFTR, while lubiprostone activates type 2 chloride channels (CIC-2)

 

  • Plecanatide activates guanylate cyclase C, increasing CFTR activity, which promotes chloride and bicarbonate secretion.
  • Lubiprostone directly activates type 2 chloride channels (CIC-2) on intestinal epithelial cells, leading to increased intestinal fluid secretion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Plecanatide is used for opioid-induced constipation, while lubiprostone is used for diarrhea-predominant IBS: Incorrect → Both drugs treat constipation, not diarrhea-predominant IBS.

 

Option C. Plecanatide works via serotonin receptors, while lubiprostone blocks dopamine receptors: Incorrect → Neither drug affects serotonin or dopamine receptors.

 

Option D. Plecanatide slows gastric emptying, while lubiprostone accelerates it: Incorrect → Both drugs enhance intestinal secretion but do not significantly affect gastric emptying.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Plecanatide increases chloride secretion via CFTR (guanylate cyclase C activation), while lubiprostone directly activates type 2 chloride channels (CIC-2) to enhance fluid secretion and motility.

choices.text: The Classic LMA is designed with an additional channel for gastric drainage to reduce the risk of aspiration.
The LMA Supreme combines features of the ProSeal LMA with a built-in bite block and improved cuff design for a better seal and easier insertion.
The LMA Fastrach is primarily used for general anesthesia and airway management without the ability to facilitate tracheal intubation.
The ProSeal LMA is designed to facilitate blind or fiberoptic-guided tracheal intubation.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the different types of Laryngeal Mask Airways (LMAs)?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The LMA Supreme combines features of the ProSeal LMA with a built-in bite block and improved cuff design for a better seal and easier insertion.

 

  • The LMA Supreme combines the features of the ProSeal LMA, such as the additional gastric drainage channel to reduce the risk of aspiration, with a built-in bite block and an improved cuff design. 
  • These features enhance the seal and make insertion easier, offering better performance in airway management.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The Classic LMA is designed with an additional channel for gastric drainage to reduce the risk of aspiration: This is incorrect because the Classic LMA does not have an additional channel for gastric drainage. That feature is characteristic of the ProSeal LMA.

 

Option C. The LMA Fastrach is primarily used for general anesthesia and airway management without the ability to facilitate tracheal intubation: This is incorrect because the LMA Fastrach is designed specifically for facilitating tracheal intubation (either blind or fiberoptic-guided), not for general anesthesia or simple airway management.

 

Option D. The ProSeal LMA is designed to facilitate blind or fiberoptic-guided tracheal intubation: This is incorrect because the ProSeal LMA is designed with an additional channel for gastric drainage, not for facilitating tracheal intubation. The LMA Fastrach is the device intended for facilitating intubation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Different types of Laryngeal Mask Airways (LMAs) have distinct features designed to address specific airway management needs. 
  • The LMA Supreme combines the features of the ProSeal with added improvements for better performance. The ProSeal LMA reduces aspiration risk through a gastric drainage channel, while the LMA Fastrach facilitates tracheal intubation. 
  • Understanding these differences is crucial for selecting the appropriate LMA based on clinical requirements.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with persistent gastrointestinal symptoms, including diarrhea and weight loss. Stool microscopy is performed to identify potential helminthic eggs. A flotation method using saturated salt solution is used for detection. All of the following helminth eggs float in the solution except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Eggs of Taenia solium

 

  • Taenia solium eggs are dense and do not float in saturated salt solution.
  • The flotation method works by using the principle that helminth eggs with lower specific gravity than the solution will float, while heavier eggs remain at the bottom.
  • Taenia solium eggs have a thick shell and high specific gravity, causing them to sink instead of floating.
  • Diagnosis of Taenia solium infection relies on direct sedimentation techniques or stool concentration methods, rather than salt flotation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Eggs of Necator americanus:

 

  • Necator americanus (hookworm) eggs are lighter and float in saturated salt solution.
  • Hookworm eggs are oval, thin-shelled, and have a lower specific gravity, making them suitable for flotation techniques.

 

Option B. Eggs of Enterobius vermicularis:

 

  • Enterobius vermicularis (pinworm) eggs are light and readily float in salt solutions.
  • They are detected using Scotch tape test rather than stool microscopy, but in flotation methods, they float due to their lower density.

 

Option C. Eggs of Hymenolepis nana:

 

  • Hymenolepis nana (dwarf tapeworm) eggs are also light and float in salt solutions.
  • These eggs are round or oval with thin outer shells, making them less dense.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Eggs of Taenia solium do not float in saturated salt solution due to their high specific gravity and thick shell.
  • Flotation methods are useful for detecting eggs of Necator americanus, Enterobius vermicularis, and Hymenolepis nana.
  • Taenia solium eggs require sedimentation techniques for accurate detection.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old dairy farmer presents with prolonged fever, malaise, and night sweats. He reports consuming unpasteurized milk from his farm regularly. Which of the following diseases can be transmitted through contaminated milk? 

 

1. Salmonellosis 

2. E. coli 

3. Streptococcus 

4. Mycobacterium

5. Q fever
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 3, 4 and 5

 

  • Milk-borne diseases are infections that can be transmitted through the consumption of raw (unpasteurized) milk or dairy products contaminated with bacteria. 
  • The following diseases are commonly associated with milk transmission:

 

  1. Salmonellosis (Salmonella spp.)
    • Salmonella can contaminate milk due to poor handling, infected dairy cattle, or contaminated water.
    • Symptoms include diarrhea, abdominal cramps, fever, and vomiting.
  2. E. coli (Escherichia coli, including pathogenic strains like EHEC, ETEC, and EPEC)
    • E. coli can be transmitted through raw milk, leading to gastroenteritis or severe complications like Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS) in EHEC infections.
    • Symptoms: Severe diarrhea, hemorrhagic colitis, hemolysis, and renal failure (HUS).
  3. Streptococcus (Streptococcus spp., especially S. agalactiae and S. pyogenes)
    • Contaminated milk can harbor Group A and Group B Streptococcus, leading to pharyngitis, mastitis, scarlet fever, and septicemia.
  4. Mycobacterium bovis, Mycobacterium tuberculosis
    • M. bovis is a causative agent of bovine tuberculosis, which can be transmitted through raw milk from infected cows.
    • Symptoms: Chronic cough, weight loss, night sweats, and lymphadenopathy.
    • Pasteurization effectively kills M. bovis, reducing the risk of transmission.
  5. Q fever (Coxiella burnetii)
    • C. burnetii is highly resistant to environmental conditions and can be transmitted through raw milk, aerosols, and direct contact with infected animals.
    • Symptoms: Fever, pneumonia, hepatitis, and endocarditis.
    • Highly infectious even in small doses (Bioterrorism potential).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Milk-borne diseases include bacterial infections like Salmonellosis, E. coli, Streptococcus, Tuberculosis, and Q fever.
  • Raw milk is a major vehicle of transmission for these pathogens, making pasteurization an essential public health measure.
  • Q fever, caused by Coxiella burnetii, is one of the most infectious zoonotic pathogens and can be transmitted through unpasteurized dairy products or aerosols.

questions.text: A farmer from India presents with difficulty swallowing, hydrophobia, and aerophobia after being bitten by a bat. He develops spasms, agitation, and coma, eventually succumbing to respiratory failure. Histopathological examination of his brain is shown in the image. Which of the following best describes the viral genome of the pathogen?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Single-stranded RNA, negative-sense, enveloped

 

  • Rabies virus belongs to the Rhabdoviridae family and has the following characteristics:
    • Single-stranded RNA (ssRNA)
    • Negative-sense
    • Enveloped
    • Bullet-shaped virion morphology
  • These properties allow the virus to infect neurons and spread retrogradely to the CNS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Double-stranded DNA, enveloped: Incorrect, because this describes herpesviruses (HSV, VZV, CMV, EBV).

 

Option B. Single-stranded RNA, positive-sense, enveloped: Incorrect, as this describes Flaviviruses (e.g., Dengue, West Nile, Hepatitis C) and Coronaviruses.

 

Option D. Single-stranded RNA, segmented, non-enveloped: Incorrect, because segmented RNA viruses include Influenza virus (Orthomyxoviridae).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Rabies virus is a bullet-shaped, enveloped, single-stranded, negative-sense RNA virus that belongs to the Rhabdoviridae family. 
  • Understanding viral structure is essential for diagnosing and differentiating it from other CNS infections.

questions.text: Match the following RCC subtypes with their associated genetic mutations
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A–3, B-4, C-1, D-2

 

A. Clear cell RCC and VHL mutation (3): Clear cell RCC is the most common subtype of RCC and is predominantly associated with mutations in the VHL gene located on chromosome 3p. The VHL gene acts as a tumor suppressor, and its inactivation leads to the accumulation of hypoxia-inducible factors (HIFs). This accumulation results in increased vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) and platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF) which promote angiogenesis, a hallmark of clear cell RCC.

 

B. Papillary RCC (Type 1) and MET mutation (4): Type 1 Papillary RCC is often linked with mutations in the MET gene, a proto-oncogene on chromosome 7. MET encodes for a receptor tyrosine kinase that is activated by hepatocyte growth factor (HGF). Mutations in MET lead to increased cell proliferation, migration, and survival, contributing to the development and progression of papillary RCC.

 

C. Chromophobe RCC and multiple chromosomal losses (1): Chromophobe RCC typically exhibits multiple chromosomal losses, including chromosomes 1, 2, 6, 10, 13, 17, and 21. This subtype arises from intercalated cells of the collecting ducts. The loss of multiple chromosomes leads to hypodiploidy, which is thought to contribute to the tumor suppressive environment limiting tumor progression.

 

D. Translocation-associated RCC and TFE3 translocation (2): Translocation-associated RCCs, particularly those involving the TFE3 gene translocation on Xp11, are characterized by fusions involving the TFE3 transcription factor gene. This subtype often appears in younger individuals and is marked by a distinctive clear cytoplasm and papillary architecture. The gene fusions involving TFE3 lead to overexpression of the transcription factor, which drives the tumorigenesis process.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Clear cell RCC → VHL mutation; VHL loss leads to HIF accumulation, VEGF upregulation, and angiogenesis, contributing to the highly vascular nature of clear cell RCC.
  • Papillary RCC (Type 1) → MET mutation; MET (a proto-oncogene on chromosome 7) encodes a tyrosine kinase receptor for hepatocyte growth factor (HGF), driving papillary RCC proliferation.
  • (Chromophobe RCC → Multiple chromosomal losses); Chromophobe RCC arises from intercalated cells of the collecting duct and shows hypodiploidy with losses of multiple chromosomes.
  • (Translocation-associated RCC → TFE3 translocation (Xp11); This rare RCC subtype, seen in young adults, is driven by TFE3 translocations and shows clear cytoplasm with papillary architecture.

questions.text: A new screening test for colorectal cancer is developed. When compared to colonoscopy, it correctly detects 95% of patients with cancer but misses 40% of healthy individuals, leading to unnecessary follow-ups. Which type of validity is best represented by this comparison?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Criterion validity

 

  • Criterion validity refers to a test’s ability to match results with a gold standard.  
  • Since colonoscopy is the gold standard for colorectal cancer, the screening test’s sensitivity and specificity compared to colonoscopy reflect its criterion validity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Content validity: Incorrect, as content validity measures whether a test includes all aspects of a variable.

 

Option C. Face validity: Incorrect, as face validity refers to whether a test appears logical at face value.

 

Option D. Discriminant validity: Incorrect, as discriminant validity ensures that two unrelated constructs do not correlate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Criterion validity measures how well a test correlates with a gold standard. It is usually expressed as sensitivity and specificity.

 

Key Concepts:

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with irregular vaginal bleeding and a significantly elevated serum beta-hCG level. A pelvic ultrasound reveals a "snowstorm" pattern and bilateral ovarian cystic masses are noted. During surgery, ovaries are as shown below in the image. What type of cyst is most likely present in association with this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Theca lutein cyst

 

  • Theca lutein cysts are commonly associated with high levels of human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG), such as in molar pregnancies, choriocarcinoma, or multiple gestations. 
  • These cysts are typically bilateral and appear as large, multicystic ovarian masses due to excessive hCG stimulation. 
  • In the context of a hydatidiform mole, the elevated hCG stimulates the ovarian theca cells, leading to the formation of these cysts. 
  • They are usually asymptomatic but may cause abdominal pain or ovarian torsion in severe cases. 
  • The images provided show characteristic features of theca lutein cysts in association with a hydatidiform mole.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Granulosa cyst: Granulosa cysts are generally smaller, non-functional cysts related to normal follicular development. They are not associated with elevated hCG levels or hydatidiform moles, and their appearance is unlike the large, multicystic structures seen in the images.

 

Option B. Dermoid cyst: Dermoid cysts, also known as mature cystic teratomas, are benign ovarian tumors that contain various tissue types, such as hair, teeth, and fat. They have a distinct appearance on ultrasound and are not linked to hCG levels or molar pregnancies.

 

Option D. Dysgerminoma: Dysgerminomas are malignant germ cell tumors of the ovary. They typically present as solid masses rather than cystic ones and are not associated with the elevated hCG levels seen in molar pregnancies. Their presentation and imaging appearance differ significantly from the theca lutein cysts shown.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Theca lutein cysts are large, multicystic ovarian masses associated with elevated hCG levels, commonly seen in molar pregnancies such as hydatidiform moles.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy was brought to the ER with complaints of melena. The child had intermittent pain in the right iliac region. On surgical exploration, the following was found. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Meckel’s Diverticulum

 

Meckel’s Diverticulum:

 

  • Congenital anomaly resulting from incomplete obliteration of the vitelline duct.
  • Rule of 2’s:
    • Found in 2% of the population.
    • 2 feet from the ileocecal valve.
    • 2 inches long.
    • 2 types of ectopic mucosa (gastric & pancreatic).
    • 2:1 male predominance.
  • Complications:
    • Bleeding (painless hematochezia/melena) due to acid secretion from ectopic gastric mucosa, leading to ulceration.
    • Intestinal obstruction (due to volvulus or intussusception).
    • Diverticulitis, mimicking appendicitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Obstructed Bowel Loops

 

  • Would present with bilious vomiting, abdominal distension, and absent bowel sounds.
  • No mention of melena or ectopic gastric tissue.

 

Option C. Appendicitis:

 

  • While pain is in the right iliac fossa, melena is not a feature of appendicitis.
  • Would present with fever, localized tenderness, rebound tenderness, and leukocytosis.

 

Option D. Appendicular Mucocele:

 

  • A mucocele is a mucus-filled dilatation of the appendix, usually seen in adults.
  • Presents as a mass in the right iliac fossa, but not with melena.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • It presents with painless lower gastrointestinal bleeding due to ectopic gastric mucosa, mimicking appendicitis. 
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by Meckel’s scan, and treatment is surgical resection in symptomatic cases.

questions.text: A patient with a history of hematochezia undergoes a procedure using the device shown in the image. Identify the device:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pile banding kit

 

The image shows Barron's band ligator:

 

  • Used for rubber band ligation of internal hemorrhoids
  • Has bands loaded that are deployed around hemorrhoid base
  • Causes strangulation of hemorrhoid tissue
  • Most commonly used for grade II hemorrhoids
  • Done as outpatient procedure

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Stapler for haemorrhoids: Incorrect as a stapler is a circular device used for stapled hemorrhoidopexy (PPH procedure)

 

Option C. Hemorrhoidectomy kit: Incorrect as this would include surgical instruments for excision

 

Option D. Fistula surgery kit: Incorrect as this would include instruments for fistula surgery like probes, curettes and scissors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A Pile Banding Kit is used in rubber band ligation for treating Grade II and III hemorrhoids. It applies a rubber band at the base of the hemorrhoid, leading to necrosis and sloughing.

questions.text: A 12-month-old infant presents with a 3-day history of high fever, irritability, and mild lymphadenopathy. The fever resolves, but within 24 hours, a pink maculopapular rash appears on the trunk and spreads to the face. The child is otherwise well-appearing. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Roseola infantum

 

  • Key Diagnostic Clues for Roseola:
    • High fever for 3–5 days.
    • Abrupt defervescence (fever disappears suddenly).
    • Rash appears AFTER fever subsides, starting on the trunk.
    • Child remains well-appearing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Measles: Rash appears with fever, starts on the face, and involves Koplik spots.

 

Option B. Rubella: Rash appears with mild fever, but posterior auricular lymphadenopathy is a key feature.

 

Option D. Scarlet fever: Characterized by sandpaper-like rash and strawberry tongue.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Presence of a negative-sense RNA genome
Replication occurs entirely in the cytoplasm
The virus is pleomorphic and contains hemagglutinin but lacks neuraminidase

questions.text: A 45-year-old immunocompromised patient is diagnosed with viral pneumonia caused by an RNA virus. The physician explains that the virus is highly capable of frequent pandemics. Which of the following features differentiates this virus from Paramyxoviruses?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Segmented genome allowing genetic reassortment

 

  • Influenza virus (Orthomyxoviridae) has a segmented RNA genome (8 segments), allowing antigenic shift (reassortment), leading to pandemics.
  • Paramyxoviruses have a single, non-segmented genome and cannot undergo genetic reassortment.
  • Orthomyxoviruses replicate in the nucleus, whereas Paramyxoviruses replicate in the cytoplasm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Presence of a negative-sense RNA genome: Incorrect because both Orthomyxoviridae and Paramyxoviridae have negative-sense RNA.

 

Option C. Replication occurs entirely in the cytoplasm: Incorrect because Influenza virus replicates in the nucleus, while Paramyxoviruses replicate in the cytoplasm.

 

Option D. The virus is pleomorphic and contains hemagglutinin but lacks neuraminidase: Incorrect because both Orthomyxoviruses and Paramyxoviruses have HA, but NA is present in both except for Measles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The key distinguishing feature between Orthomyxoviruses (Influenza) and Paramyxoviruses is that Orthomyxoviruses have a segmented genome and undergo genetic reassortment, while Paramyxoviruses have a single-stranded genome and do not.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man with MEN1 syndrome presents for routine follow-up. He has a history of primary hyperparathyroidism requiring subtotal parathyroidectomy and a pituitary adenoma. Which of the following additional findings is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pancreatic gastrinoma

 

MEN1 is caused by mutations in the MEN1 gene and is characterized by:

 

  • Parathyroid hyperplasia (primary hyperparathyroidism)
  • Pituitary tumors (prolactinoma, GH-secreting tumors)
  • Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors (gastrinoma, insulinoma, VIPoma)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mucosal neuromas: Incorrect. Seen in MEN2B, not MEN1.

 

Option B. Medullary thyroid carcinoma: Incorrect. Seen in MEN2A/2B (RET mutations), not MEN1.

 

Option D. Marfanoid habitus: Incorrect. Found in MEN2B, not MEN1.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • MEN1 is characterized by parathyroid hyperplasia, pituitary tumors, and pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors (gastrinomas, insulinomas).

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with heart failure and atrial fibrillation is started on digoxin for rate control. One month later, he presents with nausea, dizziness, and episodes of lightheadedness. Which of the following adverse effects is least likely to be caused by digoxin?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mobitz type II heart block

 

  • Digoxin inhibits the Na⁺/K⁺ ATPase, increasing vagal tone and decreasing AV nodal conduction.
  • This leads to bradycardia and AV conduction abnormalities, including Mobitz type I (Wenckebach) heart block.
  • Digoxin toxicity can also cause yellow-tinged vision (xanthopsia).
  • However, Mobitz type II heart block is caused by structural His-Purkinje system disease and is not a known digoxin-induced arrhythmia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mobitz type I heart block: Digoxin slows AV conduction, causing progressively lengthening PR intervals before a dropped QRS (Wenckebach phenomenon).

 

Option C. Yellow vision: Xanthopsia (yellow-tinged vision) is a classic finding of digoxin toxicity.

 

Option D. Bradycardia: Digoxin increases vagal tone, leading to bradycardia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Digoxin toxicity causes bradycardia, Mobitz type I AV block (Wenckebach), and yellow-tinged vision. 
  • Mobitz type II heart block is not associated with digoxin and usually results from structural conduction system disease.

questions.text: In a child presenting with a feature as shown in the image below, all of the following diagnoses are correct except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cystic fibrosis

 

  • A simian crease (single transverse palmar crease) is a common finding in certain genetic syndromes but is not associated with cystic fibrosis.

 

Conditions associated with a simian crease include:

 

  • Down syndrome (Trisomy 21)
  • Trisomy 13 (Patau syndrome)
  • Cri du chat syndrome
  • Fetal alcohol syndrome

 

However, cystic fibrosis is a genetic disorder affecting the respiratory and gastrointestinal systems and does not cause a simian crease.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Uniparental disomy involving increased expression of maternal genes
Imprinting defect with silencing of the maternal allele
Loss of function of a normally active maternal allele
Uniparental disomy involving increased expression of paternal genes

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy presents with hypotonia, poor feeding, and failure to thrive since birth. Over the past year, his parents noticed excessive appetite and rapid weight gain. He has mild developmental delay and almond-shaped eyes with a thin upper lip. Genetic testing reveals a microdeletion on chromosome 15 of paternal origin. Which of the following best explains the underlying pathophysiology of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Imprinting defect with silencing of the maternal allele

 

  • This patient has Prader-Willi syndrome (PWS), caused by loss of the paternally inherited 15q11-q13 region. 
  • The maternal allele in this region is normally imprinted (silenced), meaning that when the paternal allele is deleted or lost, no functional copy remains, leading to disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uniparental disomy involving increased expression of maternal genes: Incorrect. Maternal uniparental disomy (UPD) can cause PWS, but it results in loss of paternal gene expression, not over expression of maternal genes.

 

Option C. Loss of function of a normally active maternal allele: Incorrect. In PWS, the maternal allele is already silenced, so disease results from paternal gene loss.

 

Option D. Uniparental disomy involving increased expression of paternal genes: Incorrect. Paternal UPD would not cause PWS; it would prevent PWS and could cause Angelman syndrome if maternal genes were lost.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Prader-Willi syndrome is caused by loss of paternal gene expression in the 15q11-q13 region due to a deletion, imprinting defect, or maternal uniparental disomy.

questions.text:
Arrange the following stages of lung development in order from the earliest stage to the latest stage. 

 

  1. Canalicular stage
  2. Alveolar stage
  3. Pseudoglandular stage
  4. Saccular stage
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 3-1-4-2

 

Lung development occurs in distinct stages:

 

3. Pseudoglandular stage (Week 5-17) – Branching of the bronchial tree, formation of terminal bronchioles.

 

1. Canalicular stage (Week 16-25) – Formation of respiratory bronchioles, vascularization begins.

 

4. Saccular stage (Week 24-40) – Terminal sacs (primitive alveoli) develop, surfactant production starts.

 

2. Alveolar stage (Week 36 to childhood) – Alveoli mature, increasing gas exchange capacity.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Converts unconjugated bilirubin into water-soluble isomers

questions.text: A newborn is exclusively breastfed and presents with jaundice. What is the primary mechanism of action of phototherapy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Converts unconjugated bilirubin into water-soluble isomers

 

  • Phototherapy works by converting unconjugated bilirubin into water-soluble photoisomers, allowing it to be excreted in urine without liver conjugation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Promotes conjugation of bilirubin: This is incorrect as phototherapy does not enhance liver conjugation.

 

Option B. Increases hepatic clearance of bilirubin: This is incorrect as phototherapy does not directly affect hepatic clearance.

 

Option D. Decreases bilirubin production: This is incorrect as bilirubin production remains unchanged.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phototherapy Converts bilirubin into water-soluble isomers

questions.text: Which of the following is the least common site of involvement in psoriasis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CNS involvement

 

  • Psoriasis is a chronic inflammatory skin disease that primarily affects the skin and joints.
  • It does NOT affect the central nervous system (CNS), making CNS involvement the least common site.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Scalp involvement:

 

  • Very common in psoriasis and can present with thick, scaly plaques.

 

Option B. Nail involvement:

 

  • Nail psoriasis is common and presents with pitting, onycholysis, and subungual hyperkeratosis.

 

Option D. Arthritis:

 

  • Psoriatic arthritis is a well-recognized comorbidity of psoriasis, affecting 5-30% of patients.
  • Causes joint pain, stiffness, and swelling.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Psoriasis Site Involvement

choices.text: Excessive cerebral vasodilation leading to cerebral hyperperfusion syndrome
Systemic hypotension due to peripheral arterial vasodilation
Increased intracranial pressure due to impaired CSF resorption
Nimodipine-induced reflex bradycardia and reduced cardiac output

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman with subarachnoid hemorrhage is started on nimodipine to prevent vasospasm. Three days later, she develops dizziness, lightheadedness, and a blood pressure of 85/60 mmHg. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Systemic hypotension due to peripheral arterial vasodilation

 

  • Nimodipine, like other dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers, causes systemic arterial vasodilation, leading to hypotension.
  • This can be problematic in SAH patients, as excessive hypotension may worsen cerebral perfusion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Excessive cerebral vasodilation leading to cerebral hyperperfusion syndrome: Nimodipine prevents vasospasm but does not cause excessive cerebral hyperperfusion.

 

Option C. Increased intracranial pressure due to impaired CSF resorption: Nimodipine does not affect CSF drainage or increase ICP.

 

Option D. Nimodipine-induced reflex bradycardia and reduced cardiac output: Unlike non-dihydropyridine CCBs (e.g., diltiazem, verapamil), nimodipine does not cause significant bradycardia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Nimodipine can cause systemic hypotension due to arterial vasodilation, which may compromise cerebral perfusion in patients with subarachnoid hemorrhage. 
  • Blood pressure should be monitored closely.

choices.text: Fifteen serovars have been identified as human pathogens
Mode of transmission is by the airborne bird excreta
The Cytoplasmic inclusions present in the sputum specimen are rich in glycogen
The group specific antigen is responsible for the production of complement fixing antibodies

questions.text: Which one of the following statements is true regarding Chlamydia pneumoniae?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The group-specific antigen is responsible for the production of complement-fixing antibodies

 

  • Chlamydia pneumoniae is an obligate intracellular bacterium that causes respiratory tract infections such as community-acquired pneumonia, bronchitis, and pharyngitis.
  • A major distinguishing feature of Chlamydia pneumoniae is that it has a group-specific antigen that stimulates the production of complement-fixing antibodies, which are used in serodiagnosis.
  • The microimmunofluorescence (MIF) test is the gold standard for detecting these species-specific antibodies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fifteen serovars have been identified as human pathogens:

 

  • Chlamydia pneumoniae has only one serovar (TWAR strain), unlike Chlamydia trachomatis, which has multiple serovars (A-L3 for different infections such as trachoma and STIs).

 

Option B. Mode of transmission is by the airborne bird excreta:

 

  • Chlamydia psittaci (not Chlamydia pneumoniae) is transmitted through bird excreta and causes psittacosis (ornithosis), a zoonotic infection that presents as atypical pneumonia.
  • C. pneumoniae is transmitted via respiratory droplets from human-to-human contact.

 

Option C. The Cytoplasmic inclusions present in the sputum specimen are rich in glycogen: 

 

  • The cytoplasmic inclusions of Chlamydia trachomatis (not C. pneumoniae) are rich in glycogen, which can be detected by iodine staining.
  • In C. pneumoniae, the inclusions do not stain with iodine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Chlamydia pneumoniae is transmitted via respiratory droplets, causes atypical pneumonia, and is diagnosed by detecting complement-fixing antibodies against its group-specific antigen. 
  • Unlike C. trachomatis, it has only one serovar and does not form glycogen-rich inclusions.

questions.text: A patient in a persistent vegetative state without a living will is on life support. The family is divided on whether to continue life-sustaining treatment. Which category of euthanasia would be considered if the doctors decide to withdraw life support based on the family's decision?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Non-voluntary passive euthanasia

 

  • Non-voluntary passive euthanasia involves withdrawing or withholding life-sustaining treatment from a patient who cannot give consent due to their medical condition, and no advance directive exists to guide the decision. 
  • In the scenario described, the patient is in a persistent vegetative state and lacks the capacity to make decisions or express wishes regarding their medical treatment. 
  • The family's decision to withdraw life support, despite being divided, falls under non-voluntary passive euthanasia as it involves acting without the direct consent of the patient due to their incapacity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Voluntary passive euthanasia: This would require the patient's prior explicit consent to withdraw life support, typically given through a living will or advance directive, specifying their wishes in such circumstances. This is not applicable here as the patient did not provide such consent or directive.

 

Option B. Involuntary passive euthanasia: It implies that the action is against the known wishes of the patient. If the patient had previously expressed a desire not to have life support withdrawn, and the doctors and family decided to do so anyway, it would constitute involuntary passive euthanasia. There's no indication that the patient's preferences were known and opposed in this scenario.

 

Option D. Involuntary active euthanasia: It involves actively causing the death of a patient against their will. This typically includes actions like administering a lethal dose of medication. Since the scenario involves withdrawing support rather than actively ending life, and there's no indication that the patient opposed such measures, this option does not apply.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Non-voluntary passive euthanasia occurs when life-sustaining treatment is withdrawn from a patient who is incapable of giving consent (e.g., due to being in a vegetative state) and there is no prior directive. 
  • The decision is made without the patient's input, based on the judgment of family members or medical personnel.

questions.text: A patient presents six months after an abdominal hysterectomy with a swelling at the scar site. Initially reducible, the swelling has now become irreducible and tender. The rest of the abdomen is normal on palpation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bowel strangulation

 

This is a case of strangulated incisional hernia because:

 

  • History of previous surgery (hysterectomy) leading to incisional hernia
  • Initially reducible swelling suggests hernia
  • Progression to irreducibility with tenderness indicates strangulation
  • Strangulation occurs when blood supply to herniated bowel is compromised
  • Requires urgent surgical intervention to prevent bowel gangrene

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Paralytic ileus:

 

  • Presents with generalized abdominal distention, not localized swelling
  • No history of recent surgery or precipitating factors
  • Usually associated with absent bowel sounds
  • Does not present as reducible turning irreducible swelling

 

Option B. Perforation peritonitis:

 

  • Presents with generalized abdominal pain and distention
  • Associated with severe systemic symptoms
  • Shows signs of peritonitis all over abdomen
  • Not localized to surgical scar

 

Option D. Ascites:

 

  • Causes generalized abdominal distention
  • Fluid collects in dependent areas
  • Shows shifting dullness
  • Not localized to surgical scar

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A previously reducible hernia becoming irreducible with tenderness indicates strangulation, which is a surgical emergency requiring immediate intervention.

questions.text: A community health worker is conducting a session on health programs under the Integrated Child Development Services (ICDS). She mentions a scheme focusing on nutritional health, self-development, and family life education for girls. Which of the following age groups is primarily covered under Kishori Shakti Yojana (KSY)?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 11 – 18 years

 

  • Kishori Shakti Yojana (KSY) is an adolescent health program under ICDS that covers girls aged 11 – 18 years.
  • It is divided into two schemes:
    • Scheme-I: "Girl-to-girl Approach" for 11 – 15 years old girls.
    • Scheme-II: "Balika Mandals" for 11 – 18 years old girls.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kishori Shakti Yojana (KSY)

questions.text:
A 58-year-old man with alcoholic cirrhosis presents with increasing abdominal distension and bilateral lower extremity edema. Examination reveals tense ascites and shifting dullness. Laboratory tests show:

 

  • Serum sodium: 130 mEq/L (Low)
  • Serum potassium: 4.2 mEq/L (Normal)
  • Serum creatinine: 1.1 mg/dL (Normal)
  • Serum albumin: 2.4 g/dL (Low)
  • Ascitic fluid analysis: SAAG >1.1 g/dL, no infection

 

Which of the following is the preferred initial diuretic for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Spironolactone

 

  • Spironolactone is the preferred diuretic for cirrhotic ascites because it counteracts the hyperaldosteronism that occurs in cirrhosis.
  • In cirrhosis, portal hypertension leads to splanchnic vasodilation, activating the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS).
  • This results in sodium and water retention, worsening ascites.
  • Spironolactone (an aldosterone antagonist) effectively reduces ascites while preventing hypokalemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Furosemide:

 

  • Furosemide is not first-line because it can cause hypokalemia and worsen hepatic encephalopathy.
  • It is often added later in combination with spironolactone (in a 100:40 mg ratio) for better fluid removal.

 

Option B. Acetazolamide:

 

  • A carbonic anhydrase inhibitor, primarily used for metabolic alkalosis and glaucoma, but not effective for cirrhotic ascites.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Spironolactone is the preferred diuretic for cirrhotic ascites due to its ability to counteract secondary hyperaldosteronism. 
  • Furosemide may be added later if additional diuresis is needed, but it should not be used alone due to the risk of hypokalemia and worsening encephalopathy.

questions.text: Which is not an absolute contraindication to fibrinolytic therapy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Recent (>2 weeks) surgical procedure

 

  • Surgical procedures within the past 2 weeks are a relative contraindication to fibrinolysis due to an increased risk of bleeding.
  • Decisions on fibrinolysis in such cases should be based on risk-benefit analysis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Active internal bleeding: Absolute contraindication due to high risk of fatal hemorrhage.

 

Option B. History of hemorrhagic stroke: Absolute contraindication.

 

Option D. Aortic dissection: Absolute contraindication because fibrinolysis worsens dissection and increases mortality.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Recent (>2 weeks) surgery is a relative contraindication to fibrinolysis, whereas active bleeding, aortic dissection, and hemorrhagic stroke are absolute contraindications.

questions.text: Match column A with column B
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-D, 2-C, 3-A, 4-B

 

  • 1-D: The Basilar Membrane vibrates in response to sound frequencies. It is wider and more flexible at the apex (responding to low frequencies) and narrower and stiffer at the base (for high frequencies).
  • 2-C: Reissner's Membrane separates the cochlear duct (scala media) from the scala vestibuli. It is vital for maintaining the ionic composition of the endolymphatic fluid.
  • 3-A: The Stria Vascularis is a specialized epithelium lining the cochlear duct. It produces endolymph and is crucial for maintaining the ionic composition and endolymphatic potential necessary for normal auditory function.
  • 4-B: The Macula contains sensory hair cells and is a structure in the vestibular system. It is responsible for detecting linear acceleration and changes in head position relative to gravity.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Basilar Membrane vibrates in response to sound frequencies. 
  • Reissner's Membrane separates the cochlear duct (scala media) from the scala vestibuli. 
  • The Stria Vascularis is a specialized epithelium lining the cochlear duct. 
  • The Macula contains sensory hair cells and is a structure in the vestibular system.

questions.text: A country’s government is planning a nationwide poverty alleviation program and needs to assess socioeconomic indicators to identify vulnerable populations. Which of the following is not a recognized socioeconomic indicator?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Life expectancy at birth

 

  • Socioeconomic indicators are measures used to assess the economic and social well-being of a population.
  • Common socioeconomic indicators include:
    • Literacy rate → Reflects educational attainment
    • Family size → Indicates population demographics and economic stability
    • Housing conditions → Reflects living standards and economic capacity
  • Life expectancy at birth, however, is a health indicator, not a socioeconomic indicator. It reflects overall health status and healthcare access, rather than economic or social conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Literacy rate: Education level is a key socioeconomic indicator, as it impacts employment, income, and quality of life.

 

Option B. Family size: Family size influences resource distribution, economic dependency, and household income, making it a valid socioeconomic indicator.

 

Option C. Housing: Housing reflects living conditions and socioeconomic status, making it an important indicator of economic well-being.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Socioeconomic indicators assess economic and social well-being. Life expectancy at birth is a health indicator, while literacy rate, family size, and housing conditions are socioeconomic indicators.

 

Socio-economic Indicators [Mnemonic: He FLAGGED]

 

  • Housing
  • Family size
  • Literacy rate
  • Availability per capita calorie
  • GNP per capita
  • Growth rate
  • UnEmployment level
  • Dependency ratio

questions.text: In a discussion about optimizing chemotherapy for a 60-year-old male with newly diagnosed acute lymphoblastic leukemia, the oncologist considers adding a drug that specifically targets cells during the DNA synthesis phase. Which drug would be most appropriate for targeting cells in the S-phase of the cell cycle?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cytarabine

 

  • Cytarabine is specifically effective during the S-phase of the cell cycle, where it inhibits DNA polymerase, crucial for DNA replication. 
  • Its incorporation into DNA strands results in chain termination during DNA synthesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vincristine: Incorrect as it inhibits microtubule formation necessary for mitotic spindle assembly, acting primarily during the M phase.

 

Option B. Cyclophosphamide: Incorrect because it is an alkylating agent that cross-links DNA at any phase of the cell cycle, not specifically during the S-phase.

 

Option D. Vinblastine: Incorrect as it also targets microtubules similar to vincristine and acts during the M phase, not the S-phase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cytarabine is a key drug in targeting the S-phase of the cell cycle in hematological malignancies, emphasizing its specificity for inhibiting DNA synthesis.

choices.text: Signs of atropinization occur more slowly when pralidoxime is used compared to atropine alone
It can be used for chlorinated pesticides
It should not be used for nerve gases used in chemical warfare
Therapy with pralidoxime should ideally be monitored by measuring blood cholinesterase concentration

questions.text: Which of the following statements about 2-PAM is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Therapy with pralidoxime should ideally be monitored by measuring blood cholinesterase concentration

 

  • Pralidoxime (2-PAM) is an acetylcholinesterase reactivator used in organophosphate poisoning.
  • It works by cleaving the phosphoryl group bound to acetylcholinesterase, restoring enzyme activity and reversing neuromuscular paralysis.
  • The effectiveness of pralidoxime therapy can be monitored by measuring blood cholinesterase levels, which should increase as the enzyme is reactivated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Signs of atropinization occur more slowly when pralidoxime is used compared to atropine alone:

 

  • Atropinization (reversal of muscarinic symptoms) depends on atropine, not pralidoxime.
  • Pralidoxime mainly reverses nicotinic effects (e.g., muscle weakness, paralysis).

 

Option B. It can be used for chlorinated pesticides:

 

  • Chlorinated pesticides (e.g., DDT) do not inhibit acetylcholinesterase and do not respond to pralidoxime.

 

Option C. It should not be used for nerve gases used in chemical warfare:

 

  • Pralidoxime is used in nerve gas poisoning (e.g., sarin, VX) because these agents irreversibly inhibit acetylcholinesterase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pralidoxime (2-PAM) reactivates acetylcholinesterase by removing the phosphoryl group from the enzyme's active site. 
  • Therapy effectiveness is best monitored by measuring blood cholinesterase levels.

questions.text: A 25-year-old pregnant woman at 16 weeks of gestation undergoes screening for Down syndrome using a triple test. What does the triple test include?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Maternal AFP + hCG + Estradiol

 

The triple test is a combined biochemical test that includes:

 

  1. Maternal Serum Alpha-Fetoprotein (MSAFP)
  2. Human Chorionic Gonadotropin (hCG)
  3. Unconjugated Estradiol (UE3)

 

It is used as a screening tool for Down syndrome during the second trimester (15–18 weeks).

 

In pregnancies affected by Down syndrome:

 

  • MSAFP: Decreased
  • UE3: Decreased
  • hCG: Increased

 

The test provides a risk ratio, and if the result is positive (risk ≥1:250), further confirmation with amniocentesis is recommended.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Maternal AFP + hCG + PAPP-A: Incorrect. PAPP-A (Pregnancy-Associated Plasma Protein A) is part of the first-trimester screening, not the triple test.

 

Option C. Maternal AFP + PAPP-A + Estradiol: Incorrect. PAPP-A is not included in the triple test.

 

Option D. TSH + hCG + Estradiol: Incorrect. TSH is not part of the triple test.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The triple test is a second-trimester screening tool that includes MSAFP, hCG, and unconjugated estradiol. It evaluates the risk of chromosomal abnormalities like Down syndrome.

questions.text:
A 21-year-old woman who is 30 weeks pregnant presents with severe abdominal pain for one day. She has yellowing of the sclera and right upper quadrant pain.

 

Investigations: (Liver Function Tests - LFTs)

 

  • Alanine transaminase (ALT): 524 U/L 
  • Aspartate transaminase (AST): 300 U/L 
  • Total Bilirubin: 4.5 mg/dL 
  • Direct Bilirubin: 3.1 mg/dL 
  • Alkaline phosphatase (ALP): 650 U/L 
  • Prothrombin Time (PT): 16 sec 
  • INR: 1.7 
  • Albumin: 2.8 g/dL 

 

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acute fatty liver of pregnancy (AFLP)

 

  • The patient's clinical presentation—severe abdominal pain, scleral icterus, and right upper quadrant pain—along with elevated liver enzymes (ALT > 500 U/L), suggests acute fatty liver of pregnancy (AFLP). 
  • AFLP typically occurs in the third trimester of pregnancy and is associated with elevated liver enzymes, jaundice, and abdominal pain. 
  • It is a serious condition that requires prompt recognition and delivery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Budd-Chiari syndrome: Budd-Chiari syndrome is characterized by hepatic venous outflow obstruction, often presenting with symptoms such as ascites, hepatomegaly, and abdominal pain. However, it typically does not cause elevated ALT and AST levels as high as those seen in AFLP, and it is not specifically linked to pregnancy.

 

Option C. HELLP syndrome: HELLP syndrome (Hemolysis, Elevated Liver enzymes, and Low Platelets) can cause elevated liver enzymes, but it also presents with thrombocytopenia and hemolysis. Unlike AFLP, it is typically associated with preeclampsia and hypertension and does not present with isolated severe abdominal pain and jaundice as seen in this case.

 

Option D. Obstetric cholestasis: Obstetric cholestasis usually presents with itching, especially on the palms and soles, and is associated with elevated bile acids, not ALT and AST. It does not typically cause severe abdominal pain or jaundice with such elevated liver enzymes as seen here.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Acute fatty liver of pregnancy (AFLP) is a rare but serious condition that typically presents in the third trimester with symptoms such as abdominal pain, jaundice, and elevated liver enzymes. 
  • It is important to differentiate AFLP from other pregnancy-related liver conditions, as it requires urgent management, usually including early delivery.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents with a generalized dull ache in the lower abdomen, along with nonbloody vomiting and loss of appetite lasting for 3 hours. She has a temperature of 38.4°C. On examination, she has rebound tenderness and guarding in the lower abdomen. Her blood work shows neutrophils at 9.2 x 109/L  (reference range: 1.5–7.0). What’s the likely cause of the patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acute appendicitis

 

  • The presentation of generalized lower abdominal pain, nonbloody vomiting, low-grade fever, tenderness, and neutrophilia is highly suggestive of acute appendicitis. 
  • The physical examination finding of rebound tenderness and guarding further supports this diagnosis. 
  • The Alvarado score, a 10-point score, is commonly used to help diagnose acute appendicitis, and a score of 5 or 6 is compatible with acute appendicitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acute cholecystitis: Acute cholecystitis typically presents with right upper quadrant pain and is often associated with nausea, vomiting, and sometimes jaundice. It doesn’t usually cause generalized lower abdominal pain or a fever as prominent as in appendicitis.

 

Option C. Ectopic pregnancy: Ectopic pregnancy can cause lower abdominal pain in women, but it typically presents with other signs such as amenorrhea or vaginal bleeding. Additionally, it doesn’t usually cause a fever or neutrophilia unless complications like rupture or hemorrhage occur.

 

Option D. Mesenteric adenitis: Mesenteric adenitis is often seen in children and presents with right lower quadrant pain, sometimes mimicking appendicitis. However, it is typically associated with viral infections and a lack of rebound tenderness or guarding. Neutrophilia is also less common.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Acute appendicitis is a common cause of acute abdominal pain and can present with generalized lower abdominal pain, vomiting, fever, rebound tenderness, and neutrophilia. 
  • Early recognition and treatment are crucial to prevent complications, and imaging, such as an ultrasound or CT scan, can help confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text: Which of the following statistical measures is most likely to have more than one value?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mode

 

  • Mode is the most frequently occurring value in a dataset. Unlike the mean and median, the mode can have multiple values, leading to bimodal (two modes), trimodal (three modes), or multimodal distributions.
  • In the case described, two different blood pressure values appear most frequently, making this a bimodal distribution and confirming that the mode can have more than one value.

 

Other Options:
