Option A. Mean: Incorrect. The mean (average) is a single computed value, calculated by summing all observations and dividing by the number of data points. It does not have multiple values.

 

Option B. Median: Incorrect. The median represents the middle value in an ordered dataset and is always a single value, even in skewed distributions.

 

Option D. Standard deviation: Incorrect. Standard deviation measures dispersion (spread of data points) and is always a single numerical value, never multiple values.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The mode is the only central tendency measure that can have multiple values, leading to bimodal, trimodal, or multimodal distributions. 
  • Unlike the mean and median, which always yield a single result, the mode identifies the most frequently occurring values.

questions.text: A British naval officer in the 18th century noticed that many sailors on long voyages developed weakness, gum bleeding, and poor wound healing. A scientist later discovered that adding citrus fruits to the diet prevented this condition. Who made this discovery?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) James Lind

 

  • James Lind conducted one of the first controlled clinical trials in 1753, proving that citrus fruits like lemons and oranges prevent scurvy.
  • His discovery led to mandatory citrus supplementation for sailors, dramatically improving naval health.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Alexander Fleming: He discovered penicillin, the first antibiotic, not scurvy prevention.

 

Option C. Joseph Lister: Lister developed antiseptic techniques in surgery.

 

Option D. Ignaz Semmelweis: Semmelweis promoted handwashing to prevent puerperal fever, not vitamin C deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • James Lind discovered that citrus fruits prevent scurvy, leading to their inclusion in naval diets and significantly reducing sailor mortality.

questions.text: A silver impregnation stain of a blood sample reveals the organisms seen in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Leptospira interrogans

 

  • The image shows tightly coiled spirochetes with characteristic hooked ends, which is highly suggestive of Leptospira interrogans.
  • Leptospira interrogans is a spirochete that causes Leptospirosis, a zoonotic disease transmitted through contaminated water, particularly in flood-prone areas.
  • The organism can be identified using silver impregnation stains, dark-field microscopy, or Giemsa stain.
  • Clinical presentation includes fever, myalgia, conjunctival suffusion, jaundice, renal failure (Weil’s disease), and aseptic meningitis.
  • It is commonly associated with occupational exposure (e.g., farmers, sewage workers) or recreational exposure (e.g., water sports in contaminated lakes or rivers).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Borrelia burgdorferi: 

 

  • Borrelia burgdorferi is the causative agent of Lyme disease, presenting with erythema migrans, arthritis, and neurological symptoms.
  • It is a larger spirochete with loose coils and is better detected using Giemsa or Wright stains, not silver impregnation.

 

Option C. Treponema pallidum:

 

  • Treponema pallidum causes syphilis, presenting with painless genital ulcers (primary syphilis) or rash and systemic symptoms (secondary syphilis).
  • It lacks hooked ends and has fewer, looser spirals compared to Leptospira.
  • It is best identified using dark-field microscopy or Warthin-Starry silver stain.

 

Option D. Ehrlichia chaffeensis: 

 

  • Ehrlichia chaffeensis causes human monocytic ehrlichiosis (HME), a tick-borne infection presenting with fever, thrombocytopenia, and leukopenia.
  • It is an intracellular bacterium, not a spirochete, and is best detected with Giemsa or Wright stain, not silver impregnation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Leptospira interrogans is a tightly coiled spirochete with characteristic hooked ends, best visualized using silver impregnation stains or dark-field microscopy. 
  • It causes leptospirosis, a zoonotic disease transmitted via water contaminated with animal urine, and presents with fever, conjunctival suffusion, myalgia, and, in severe cases, Weil’s disease (jaundice, renal failure, hemorrhage).

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a history of smoking and hypertension presents with rest pain, especially when his legs are elevated. On examination, you notice ulcers on his foot and gangrene of one toe. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Critical Limb Ischemia

 

  • Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI) is characterized by severe arterial occlusive disease, where resting blood flow cannot meet the basal nutritional needs of tissues. 
  • Patients often present with ischemic symptoms such as rest pain that worsens when legs are elevated, along with ischemic ulcers and gangrene, all of which are noted in this patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Venous Insufficiency: Incorrect. Typically presents with edema, varicose veins, and stasis dermatitis, but not with rest pain or gangrene.

 

Option C. Diabetic Neuropathy: Incorrect. While it can cause foot ulcers, it is not associated with arterial occlusive disease and the ischemic complications seen in CLI.

 

Option D. Deep Vein Thrombosis: Incorrect. Characterized by pain and swelling due to venous obstruction, but does not cause ischemic ulcers or gangrene from arterial insufficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Critical Limb Ischemia is based on clinical presentation and distinguish it from other conditions with similar symptoms. 
  • Diagnosis relies on a combination of clinical findings and diagnostic measures like the Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI), which is notably low in CLI cases.

questions.text: The following image shows the chest X-ray of a preterm neonate who was admitted to the NICU due to severe respiratory distress shortly after birth. The baby was delivered at 28 weeks of gestation to a mother with gestational diabetes. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Neonatal respiratory distress syndrome

 

  • Neonatal Respiratory Distress Syndrome (NRDS), also known as Hyaline Membrane Disease (HMD), occurs due to surfactant deficiency, leading to alveolar collapse (atelectasis) and impaired gas exchange.
  • It primarily affects preterm neonates (< 34 weeks gestation) and is more common in infants of diabetic mothers due to delayed lung maturity.
  • Key clinical features:
    • Tachypnea, grunting, nasal flaring, intercostal retractions
    • Cyanosis (in severe cases)
  • Chest X-ray findings of NRDS:
    • Ground-glass opacities (reticulogranular pattern)
    • Air bronchograms
    • Loss of lung volume ("white-out" lung in severe cases)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transient Tachypnea of the Newborn:

 

  • Occurs in term or near-term neonates due to delayed clearance of lung fluid.
  • CXR: Hyperinflation with prominent vascular markings and fluid in fissures.

 

Option B. Neonatal Pneumonia:

 

  • Presents with fever, respiratory distress, and leukocytosis.
  • CXR: Patchy or lobar consolidations, not a reticulogranular pattern.

 

Option C. Meconium Aspiration Syndrome:

 

  • Occurs in term or post-term neonates with stained amniotic fluid.
  • CXR: Patchy infiltrates, hyperinflation, pneumothorax risk.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which artery can be palpated by gently pressing your fingers as shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dorsalis pedis artery

 

  • The dorsalis pedis artery is a continuation of the anterior tibial artery and is the primary artery supplying the dorsum of the foot. 
  • It can be palpated by placing fingers on the dorsum of the foot, just lateral to the extensor hallucis longus tendon. 
  • The location is between the first and second metatarsal bones. 
  • The palpability of the dorsalis pedis artery is clinically significant for assessing peripheral circulation, particularly in conditions like peripheral artery disease (PAD). 
  • A weak or absent dorsalis pedis pulse may indicate arterial occlusion or vascular insufficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anterior tibial artery: The anterior tibial artery runs along the anterior compartment of the leg but terminates as the dorsalis pedis artery at the level of the ankle joint. It is not directly palpable on the dorsum of the foot but rather in the leg.

 

Option B. Posterior tibial artery: This artery is located posterior to the medial malleolus and can be palpated at the tarsal tunnel. It supplies the posterior compartment of the leg and plantar aspect of the foot but is not the artery being palpated in the given image.

 

Option D. Popliteal artery: The popliteal artery is a continuation of the femoral artery and is located behind the knee in the popliteal fossa. It is palpated with deep pressure while the knee is slightly flexed. It does not supply the dorsum of the foot directly and is not the correct answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The dorsalis pedis artery is an important pulse point located on the dorsum of the foot, lateral to the extensor hallucis longus tendon. It is clinically assessed for vascular integrity, particularly in peripheral artery disease. Its absence or weak pulse may indicate an arterial blockage or systemic circulatory disorders.

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman presents with weight gain despite maintaining a balanced diet and regular exercise for 6 months. She also reports muscle weakness and easy bruising. On examination, her blood pressure (BP) is 154/102 mmHg, the image of her abdomen is shown below. Which is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cushing syndrome

 

  • The patient's presentation is highly suggestive of Cushing syndrome, which results from chronic exposure to excess glucocorticoids (cortisol). 
  • The key features pointing to this diagnosis are:
    • Weight gain (especially central/abdominal obesity)
    • Muscle weakness (proximal myopathy, common in Cushing syndrome)
    • Easy bruising (due to protein catabolism and fragile capillaries)
    • Purple striae (wide, >1 cm) – A hallmark feature of Cushing syndrome due to skin thinning and collagen breakdown
    • Hypertension (BP 154/102 mmHg) – Common due to cortisol-induced sodium retention

 

Pathophysiology of Cushing Syndrome:

 

  • Excess cortisol leads to:
    • Protein catabolism: Muscle weakness and skin thinning (causing striae and bruising)
    • Increased gluconeogenesis and insulin resistance: Central obesity
    • Fluid retention and vasoconstriction: Hypertension
    • Immune suppression: Increased risk of infections
  • Causes of Cushing Syndrome:
    • Exogenous: Long-term use of glucocorticoid medications (most common)
    • Endogenous:
      • Cushing disease: Pituitary tumor producing ACTH (most common endogenous cause)
      • Adrenal adenoma or carcinoma (primary cortisol overproduction)
      • Ectopic ACTH syndrome (e.g., from a small-cell lung carcinoma)

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Acromegaly:

 

  • Associated with enlarged hands, feet, and facial features (e.g., frontal bossing, prognathism) rather than purple striae or easy bruising.
  • Typically causes insulin resistance and sweating, not significant bruising or striae.

 

Option B. Addison disease:

 

  • Associated with weight loss, hyperpigmentation, and hypotension, not weight gain, purple striae, or hypertension.
  • Opposite clinical features to Cushing syndrome.

 

Option D. Hashimoto thyroiditis:

 

  • Associated with hypothyroidism symptoms such as weight gain, fatigue, and cold intolerance, but it does not cause purple striae, easy bruising, or hypertension.
  • Typically presents with a goitre or thyroid enlargement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cushing Syndrome Classic Features:
    • Central obesity, buffalo hump, moon facies
    • Purple striae (>1 cm, usually on the abdomen)
    • Proximal muscle weakness (due to protein catabolism)
    • Easy bruising (due to skin thinning and capillary fragility)
    • Hypertension and insulin resistance (diabetes)
  • Causes of Cushing Syndrome:
    • Exogenous steroids (most common overall)
    • Pituitary adenoma (Cushing disease – most common endogenous)
    • Adrenal tumor (adenoma or carcinoma)
    • Ectopic ACTH syndrome (e.g., from small-cell lung cancer)

 

Next Investigations:

 

  • Overnight dexamethasone suppression test: Failure to suppress cortisol confirms Cushing syndrome.
  • 24-hour urinary free cortisol (UFC): Elevated in Cushing syndrome.
  • Late-night salivary cortisol: Elevated levels indicate loss of diurnal cortisol rhythm.
  • ACTH measurement:
    • Low ACTH: Suggests adrenal cause (primary Cushing syndrome)
    • High ACTH: Suggests Cushing disease (pituitary) or ectopic ACTH syndrome

 

Management Approach for Cushing Syndrome:

 

  • Exogenous cause: Taper and stop steroids gradually if possible.
  • Cushing disease (pituitary adenoma): Transsphenoidal surgery.
  • Adrenal adenoma/carcinoma: Adrenalectomy.
  • Ectopic ACTH syndrome: Treat underlying tumor (e.g., resect lung cancer).

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient with a known family history of malignant hyperthermia is scheduled for elective surgery. Which anesthetic agent should be selected?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Thiopentone

 

Thiopentone (thiopental) is a barbiturate intravenous anesthetic agent and is not associated with triggering malignant hyperthermia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Isoflurane: Incorrect, as isoflurane is a potent inhalational anesthetic agent known to trigger malignant hyperthermia in susceptible individuals.

 

Option B. Halothane: Incorrect, halothane is also a well-known trigger for malignant hyperthermia due to its action as an inhalational anesthetic.

 

Option C. Suxamethonium: Incorrect, suxamethonium (succinylcholine) is a muscle relaxant that can trigger malignant hyperthermia in genetically susceptible patients.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • In patients with a known risk of malignant hyperthermia, intravenous anesthetics like thiopentone are preferred over inhalational agents like isoflurane and halothane, and muscle relaxants such as suxamethonium, as they do not trigger this condition.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman at 30 weeks gestation undergoes a fetal middle cerebral artery (MCA) Doppler ultrasound to assess for fetal anemia. The Doppler shows an increased peak systolic velocity. What is the most likely underlying etiology?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rh isoimmunization

 

  • Fetal anemia leads to increased cardiac output and decreased blood viscosity, causing an elevated MCA peak systolic velocity.
  • Rh isoimmunization is a common cause due to hemolysis of fetal RBCs by maternal anti-D antibodies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Congenital diaphragmatic hernia: Incorrect. Does not cause fetal anemia.

 

Option C. Fetal growth restriction (IUGR): Incorrect. IUGR is assessed using umbilical artery Doppler, not MCA Doppler.

 

Option D. Placental abruption: Incorrect. Causes acute fetal distress but does not specifically elevate MCA velocity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • MCA Doppler is used to detect fetal anemia, commonly due to Rh isoimmunization, by measuring increased peak systolic velocity.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old man presents with persistent flank pain and recurrent calcium oxalate kidney stones. An abdominal X-ray reveals:

 

 

Which of the following imaging studies would best confirm the underlying renal pathology?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Non-contrast CT scan

 

  • Non-contrast CT is the best imaging modality for detecting renal calcifications, including nephrocalcinosis.
  • It provides high-resolution visualization of medullary and cortical calcifications and can differentiate nephrocalcinosis from nephrolithiasis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Renal ultrasound: Incorrect. Can detect nephrocalcinosis but is less sensitive than CT.

 

Option C. Intravenous pyelogram (IVP): Incorrect. Rarely used for nephrocalcinosis, primarily for urinary tract obstruction.

 

Option D. 99mTc-DMSA renal scan: Incorrect. Used for evaluating renal cortical function, not nephrocalcinosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Non-contrast CT is the most sensitive imaging modality for detecting and characterizing nephrocalcinosis.

questions.text:
A 69-year-old woman presents with:

 

  • Bone pain and difficulty mobilizing for 8 months.
  • Multiple falls.
  • Loss of 4 cm in height since her last appointment.

 

A dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry (DEXA) scan is requested.

 

Which of the following T-score ranges is associated with the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) < -2.5

 

  • This presentation is highly suggestive of osteoporosis, a systemic skeletal disorder characterized by low bone mass, fragility fractures, and height loss due to vertebral compression fractures.

 

Key Features of Osteoporosis:

 

Chronic bone pain and difficulty mobilizing → Due to reduced bone density.
 

Recurrent falls → Suggests increased fracture risk.
 

Loss of height → A sign of vertebral compression fractures.

 

DEXA Scan T-Scores and Interpretation:

 

 

A T-score of < -2.5 confirms osteoporosis and justifies anti-resorptive therapy (e.g., bisphosphonates).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. >2.5: Indicates high bone density, which is not associated with osteoporosis.

 

Option B. 0.5 to 2.0: A normal range; does not indicate osteoporosis.

 

Option C. 1.0 to 0.5: Falls within osteopenia but not osteoporosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A T-score < -2.5 on a DEXA scan confirms osteoporosis, which is characterized by bone fragility, recurrent falls, and height loss due to vertebral compression fractures. 
  • Bisphosphonates are first-line treatment to reduce fracture risk.

choices.text: Culture the organism on Sabouraud agar
Use Direct Fluorescent Antibody (DFA) staining with monoclonal antibodies
Perform Giemsa staining for intracellular parasites
Check for trophozoites using saline wet mount microscopy

questions.text: A veterinary epidemiologist investigating an outbreak of waterborne diarrhea in a community performs acid-fast staining on stool samples but detects only a few Cryptosporidium oocysts despite clinical suspicion. Which of the following is the most appropriate next diagnostic step to improve diagnostic sensitivity?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Use Direct Fluorescent Antibody (DFA) staining with monoclonal antibodies

 

  • Cryptosporidium is an intracellular, coccidian parasite that causes waterborne diarrhea. 
  • Acid-fast staining is a traditional method for Cryptosporidium detection, but it has low sensitivity and requires a high oocyst burden (>50,000 oocysts/mL of stool) for detection. 
  • This makes it prone to false-negative results, especially in cases with low parasite loads.
  • To improve diagnostic accuracy, Direct Fluorescent Antibody (DFA) staining is the gold standard test. 
  • It uses fluorescent-labeled monoclonal antibodies that bind specifically to Cryptosporidium oocyst wall antigens, making it highly sensitive and specific. DFA is 10 times more sensitive than acid-fast staining and can detect Cryptosporidium oocysts even in environmental samples such as water.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Culture the organism on Sabouraud agar: Cryptosporidium is an obligate intracellular parasite, meaning it cannot be cultured on artificial media like Sabouraud agar, which is typically used for fungi. Since Cryptosporidium must be inside a host cell to complete its life cycle, in vitro culture is not a viable diagnostic method.

 

Option C. Perform Giemsa staining for intracellular parasites: Giemsa stain is commonly used for detecting intracellular parasites such as Plasmodium (malaria), Babesia, Trypanosoma, and Leishmania. However, Cryptosporidium oocysts are extracellular in stool samples and do not stain well with Giemsa. This makes it ineffective for routine diagnosis.

 

Option D. Check for trophozoites using saline wet mount microscopy: Saline wet mount microscopy is useful for detecting motile trophozoites of organisms like Giardia lamblia, Entamoeba histolytica, and Trichomonas vaginalis. However, Cryptosporidium exists only as oocysts in stool samples, and these are non-motile. Wet mount microscopy cannot differentiate Cryptosporidium oocysts from other fecal debris, leading to poor diagnostic sensitivity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Acid-fast staining is useful for detecting Cryptosporidium oocysts, but it has low sensitivity.
  • Direct Fluorescent Antibody (DFA) staining is the gold standard for Cryptosporidium detection, being 10 times more sensitive than acid-fast staining.
  • DFA uses monoclonal antibodies specific to Cryptosporidium oocyst wall antigens, making it highly specific.
  • Cryptosporidium cannot be cultured on artificial media like Sabouraud agar because it is an obligate intracellular parasite.
  • Giemsa stain and wet mount microscopy are ineffective for Cryptosporidium detection.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old woman has a hypertension review and is taking amlodipine.

 

Investigations:

 

  • Serum urea: 7.2 mmol/L (elevated, normal: 2.5–7.0)
  • Serum creatinine: 115 µmol/L (slightly elevated, normal: 60–110)
  • Estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR):84 mL/min/1.73 m² (mildly reduced, normal: >90)

 

What stage of chronic kidney disease (CKD) does this woman have?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Stage 2 CKD

 

  • Chronic kidney disease (CKD) is classified based on eGFR values:

 

CKD Staging by eGFR (mL/min/1.73 m²)

 

 

Why Stage 2 CKD?

 

  • eGFR is 84 mL/min/1.73 m² (within the 60–89 range for Stage 2).
  • Elevated urea and creatinine suggest kidney damage.
  • CKD is diagnosed when there is evidence of kidney damage (e.g., abnormal U+Es, proteinuria, or imaging abnormalities), even if eGFR is >60.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Stage 1 CKD: Requires normal eGFR (≥90) with kidney damage. This patient’s eGFR is 84, so Stage 2 is correct.

 

Option C. Stage 3 CKD: Defined as eGFR <60, but this patient has eGFR of 84.

 

Option D. Stage 4 CKD: Severe kidney disease, eGFR <30, which is much lower than this patient’s level.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Stage 2 CKD is defined as an eGFR of 60–89 mL/min/1.73 m² with evidence of kidney damage (elevated creatinine, urea, proteinuria, or imaging abnormalities). 
  • This patient’s eGFR of 84 and abnormal U+Es place her in Stage 2 CKD.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with poorly controlled diabetes mellitus presents to the emergency department with progressive altered mental status, fever, and vomiting over the past week. Physical examination reveals nuchal rigidity and confusion. A lumbar puncture is performed, and India ink stain of the CSF findings is shown in the image. Which of the following is the primary virulence factor responsible for the pathogenicity of this organism?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Capsular polysaccharide

 

  • The India ink stain highlights a halo-like clearing around round yeast cells, which is characteristic of Cryptococcus neoformans.
  • Cryptococcus neoformans is an encapsulated yeast that primarily causes cryptococcal meningitis, particularly in immunocompromised individuals, including those with HIV/AIDS, diabetes, and organ transplant recipients.
  • The major virulence factor of Cryptococcus neoformans is its capsular polysaccharide, which:
    • Inhibits phagocytosis by macrophages.
    • Suppresses host immune response by interfering with antigen presentation.
    • Contributes to CNS invasion by crossing the blood-brain barrier.
  • India ink stain is used to visualize the thick polysaccharide capsule, appearing as a clear halo around the yeast cells. This capsule plays a critical role in the pathogenesis of cryptococcal meningitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Melanin synthesis:

 

  • Cryptococcus neoformans produces melanin via the enzyme laccase, which:
    • Protects against oxidative stress and host immune response.
    • Enhances survival within macrophages.
  • While melanin contributes to virulence, it is not the primary pathogenic factor.

 

Option C. Urease production: 

 

  • Cryptococcus is urease-positive, which helps in:
    • Facilitating CNS invasion by altering the blood-brain barrier permeability.
    • Aiding dissemination from the lungs to the brain.
  • Although urease is an important virulence factor, the polysaccharide capsule is more critical in immune evasion and pathogenesis.

 

Option D. Mannoproteins:

 

  • Mannoproteins play a role in:
    • Adhesion to host cells.
    • Inducing inflammation and modulating immune response.
  • While significant, they are not the key virulence factor responsible for immune evasion and disease progression.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cryptococcus neoformans is an encapsulated yeast that causes cryptococcal meningitis, especially in immunocompromised patients.
  • The India ink stain demonstrates encapsulated yeast cells with a halo appearance.
  • The primary virulence factor is the polysaccharide capsule, which inhibits phagocytosis, immune activation, and antigen presentation.
  • First-line treatment includes Amphotericin B + Flucytosine, followed by Fluconazole maintenance therapy.

choices.text: Increased GLUT-2 expression in muscle cells
Exercise-induced GLUT-4 translocation to the plasma membrane
Compensatory increase in fructose transport via GLUT-5

questions.text: A 26-year-old competitive athlete follows a ketogenic diet that limits carbohydrate intake. His muscles still manage to take up glucose after meals, despite low circulating insulin levels. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for his continued glucose uptake in skeletal muscle?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Exercise-induced GLUT-4 translocation to the plasma membrane

 

  • GLUT-4 translocation occurs in skeletal muscle independently of insulin during exercise.
  • This allows for continued glucose uptake despite low insulin levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Upregulation of GLUT-1: Incorrect. GLUT-1 mediates basal glucose uptake in RBCs and BBB, not insulin-independent muscle uptake.

 

Option B. Increased GLUT-2 expression in muscle cells: Incorrect. GLUT-2 is found in liver, pancreas, and intestines, not skeletal muscle.

 

Option D. Compensatory increase in fructose transport via GLUT-5: Incorrect. GLUT-5 transports fructose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Exercise induces GLUT-4 translocation in muscle via AMPK activation, allowing glucose uptake independent of insulin.

 

GLUT Transporters

questions.text: Match the Following: Nerve Injuries and associated Clinical Findings
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-C, 2-B, 3-A, 4-D

 

  • Long thoracic nerve injury (1-C): This injury leads to paralysis of the serratus anterior muscle. The clinical manifestation is a winged scapula, where the scapula protrudes abnormally from the back when pushing against resistance.
  • Suprascapular nerve injury (2-B): This injury affects the supraspinatus and infraspinatus muscles, leading to loss of shoulder external rotation and weakness in the supraspinatus muscle, which is crucial for the initial phase of arm abduction.
  • Axillary nerve injury (3-A): Damage to this nerve primarily impacts the deltoid muscle, leading to weakness and difficulty in abducting the arm beyond 15 degrees, a fundamental action performed by the deltoid.
  • Thoracodorsal nerve injury (4-D): This nerve innervates the latissimus dorsi muscle. Injury here results in weakness in arm extension and adduction, movements primarily facilitated by the latissimus dorsi.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Long thoracic nerve injury → Causes winged scapula due to paralysis of the serratus anterior muscle.
  • Suprascapular nerve injury → Leads to loss of external rotation and weakness in supraspinatus, affecting initial arm abduction.
  • Axillary nerve injury → Results in deltoid weakness, causing difficulty in arm abduction beyond 15°.
  • Thoracodorsal nerve injury → Leads to latissimus dorsi weakness, affecting arm extension and adduction.

choices.text: Excessive amplification of non-specific DNA fragments
Inability of DNA ligase to join Okazaki fragments

questions.text: A researcher is conducting a polymerase chain reaction (PCR) experiment and mistakenly omits magnesium ions (Mg²⁺) from the reaction mixture. Which of the following is the most likely consequence?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Inhibition of Taq polymerase activity

 

  • Magnesium ions (Mg²⁺) are essential cofactors for DNA polymerases, including Taq polymerase, the enzyme responsible for DNA synthesis in PCR.
  • Without Mg²⁺, Taq polymerase cannot catalyze nucleotide addition, leading to complete failure of DNA amplification.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Failure of primer annealing: Incorrect. Primer annealing depends on temperature and primer design, not Mg²⁺.

 

Option C. Excessive amplification of non-specific DNA fragments: Incorrect. Low Mg²⁺ leads to reduced enzyme activity, not excessive amplification.

 

Option D. Inability of DNA ligase to join Okazaki fragments: Incorrect. DNA ligase is not involved in PCR, as PCR does not require DNA fragment joining.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Magnesium ions (Mg²⁺) are essential cofactors for Taq polymerase, and their absence leads to the complete failure of PCR amplification.

questions.text: Identify the condition that does not lead to bilateral hydronephrosis:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Retrocaval ureter

 

  • Retrocaval ureter does not lead to bilateral hydronephrosis. Only right side is affected.

 

Other Options: 

 

  • Other 3 options blocks at bladder neck or urethral level will lead to bilateral hydronephrosis like phimosis, urethral stricture and posterior urethral valve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

  • Circumcaval or retrocaval ureter is a developmental anomaly of the inferior vena cava (IC). 
  • There is a persistent right posterior cardinal vein that ends up passing in front of the ureter. 
  • The anomaly always occurs on the right side, as this is the side of the normal IVC. 
  • This will typically compress only the right ureter, leading to right hydronephrosis.

questions.text:
A 79-year-old woman presents with:

  • Shortness of breath and reduced urine output
  • Post-operative status: Knee replacement surgery (3 days ago)
  • Given ibuprofen for postoperative pain relief
  • Signs of dehydration: Reduced skin turgor, dry mucous membranes

Investigations:

Serum Urea: 46.8 mg/dL

Serum Creatinine: 2.66 mg/dL

Which is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Stop ibuprofen

 

  • This patient has acute kidney injury (AKI) secondary to NSAID-induced nephrotoxicity, likely due to acute tubular necrosis (ATN) or acute interstitial nephritis (AIN).

 

Key Features Suggesting NSAID-Induced AKI:

 

Recent ibuprofen use (NSAIDs are nephrotoxic)


Postoperative dehydration (increased risk of AKI)


Elevated creatinine and urea (AKI)


Reduced urine output (oliguria)

 

NSAIDs cause kidney damage by inhibiting renal prostaglandins, which leads to:

 

  • Reduced renal blood flow (especially in volume-depleted patients, like post-surgery)
  • Increased risk of ischemic acute tubular necrosis (ATN)
  • Acute interstitial nephritis (AIN) in some cases

 

Management:

 

First step: STOP the nephrotoxic drug (ibuprofen)
Hydration may be needed after stopping NSAIDs

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. 500 mL Hartmann solution:

 

  • IV fluids are useful if the patient is dehydrated (as suggested by reduced skin turgor and dry mucous membranes).
  • However, the priority is to stop the NSAID first.
  • If hypovolemia is suspected, IV fluids may be added after stopping ibuprofen.

 

Option B. Blood transfusion:

 

  • Used in severe anemia or significant blood loss.
  • No evidence of bleeding or low hemoglobin here.

 

Option C. Furosemide:

 

  • Used for fluid overload, not for NSAID-induced AKI.
  • Can worsen kidney function if given inappropriately in AKI.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • NSAIDs (e.g., ibuprofen) are nephrotoxic and can cause AKI by reducing renal blood flow. 
  • The first step in management is to stop the offending drug. If dehydration is present, IV fluids (e.g., Hartmann’s solution) can be considered.

choices.text: To prevent progressive lens hardening, which makes surgery more difficult
To allow proper foveal reflex development and prevent amblyopia
To prevent secondary glaucoma due to lens-induced angle closure
To enhance retinal contrast sensitivity before 1 year of age

questions.text: A 4-month-old infant is diagnosed with unilateral congenital cataract. The ophthalmologist recommends urgent surgery to prevent long-term visual impairment. What is the primary reason for early intervention in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) To allow proper foveal reflex development and prevent amblyopia

 

  • Early treatment of congenital cataract is essential to prevent amblyopia, as the foveal reflex and fixation reflex develop at 5-6 months of age. 
  • If a cataract blocks visual input, the brain fails to develop proper visual fixation, leading to permanent amblyopia. Unilateral congenital cataracts are more harmful than bilateral ones because they cause both stimulation deprivation and anisometropic amblyopia, making timely intervention even more critical.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. To prevent progressive lens hardening, which makes surgery more difficult: While lens changes occur with time, this is not the primary reason for urgent surgery in an infant.

 

Option C. To prevent secondary glaucoma due to lens-induced angle closure: Lens-induced glaucoma (C): Not a primary concern in congenital cataract, though certain cataracts can cause secondary glaucoma later.

 

Option D. To enhance retinal contrast sensitivity before 1 year of age: Visual development depends more on binocular vision and fixation reflex formation, not just contrast sensitivity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Congenital cataracts must be treated as early as possible to prevent amblyopia. Unilateral cataracts pose a higher risk due to both stimulation deprivation and anisometropic amblyopia.

 

Congenital Cataract Management

questions.text:
A 78-year-old woman presents with progressively worsening intermittent headaches, confusion, and difficulty walking for 3 days. She had a fall 2 weeks ago and has a history of hypertension (on amlodipine) and mild cognitive impairment.

 

Investigations:

 

  • CT Head:

 

 

What’s the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chronic subdural hematoma (SDH)

 

  • This patient's gradual onset of headache, confusion, and gait disturbance following a minor fall weeks ago is highly suggestive of chronic subdural hematoma (SDH).

 

Key Features of Chronic SDH:

 

  • Progressive symptoms over weeks (headache, cognitive impairment, gait disturbance)
  • Common in the elderly (due to cerebral atrophy and fragile bridging veins)
  • History of head trauma (even minor falls)
  • CT shows a hypodense (dark) crescentic collection due to slow venous bleeding

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute subdural hematoma: Typically presents immediately after trauma with rapid neurological deterioration. CT shows a hyperdense (bright) crescentic collection, unlike the hypodense collection seen here.

 

Option C. Extradural hematoma: Usually caused by arterial bleeding (middle meningeal artery) after temporal bone fractures. Presents with lucid interval followed by rapid deterioration. CT shows a biconvex (lentiform) hyperdense collection, unlike the crescentic shape of SDH.

 

Option D. Normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH): Causes the classic triad of gait disturbance, urinary incontinence, and cognitive impairment, but does not cause headaches or show a subdural collection on CT.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Chronic subdural hematoma presents with gradual neurological decline (headache, cognitive impairment, and gait disturbance) weeks after minor head trauma. 
  • CT shows a hypodense crescentic collection. Treatment includes surgical drainage if symptomatic.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with progressively worsening blurred vision in both eyes over the past several years. Fundoscopy reveals a tigroid fundus, and fluorescein angiography shows lacquer cracks in Bruch’s membrane with evidence of subretinal neovascularization. Which of the following complications is most likely to develop in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rhegmatogenous retinal detachment

 

  • Pathological myopia is characterized by excessive elongation of the eyeball, leading to progressive stretching of the sclera, choroid, and retina. 
  • One of the major complications is peripheral retinal degeneration (e.g., lattice degeneration), which predisposes to the formation of retinal holes and eventual rhegmatogenous retinal detachment. 
  • Additionally, lacquer cracks in Bruch’s membrane can allow the growth of a choroidal neovascular membrane (CNVM), further worsening vision.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Optic disc drusen: Calcified deposits within the optic disc, unrelated to myopic stretching.

 

Option C. Vogt-Koyanagi-Harada syndrome: An inflammatory disorder causing bilateral granulomatous uveitis, often with exudative retinal detachment, not rhegmatogenous.

 

Option D. Retinitis pigmentosa: Causes progressive peripheral vision loss due to rod photoreceptor degeneration, but it is not associated with pathological myopia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pathological Myopia and its Features

questions.text: A 67-year-old man with myelodysplastic syndrome is scheduled for an allogeneic stem cell transplant. His oncologist orders a specific type of red blood cell modification to prevent graft-versus-host disease (GVHD). Which of the following blood product modifications is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gamma irradiation

 

  • Gamma irradiation is used to inactivate donor lymphocytes, preventing graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) in immunocompromised patients, particularly those undergoing bone marrow or stem cell transplants.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Leukoreduction: Incorrect. Reduces febrile reactions but does not eliminate GVHD risk.

 

Option C. Washing with saline: Incorrect. Used to prevent severe allergic transfusion reactions, not GVHD.

 

Option D. Platelet pooling: Incorrect. Used to increase platelet volume for transfusion, not to prevent GVHD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Gamma irradiation prevents transfusion-associated GVHD by inactivating donor lymphocytes.

questions.text: A 35-year-old pregnant woman at 28 weeks gestation presents for screening of gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM). She undergoes a DIPSI test (75 g glucose challenge, plasma glucose measured after 2 hours). Which of the following glucose values confirms gestational diabetes mellitus according to Indian guidelines?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) ≥140 mg/dL

 

  • The DIPSI (Diabetes in Pregnancy Study Group India) test defines GDM as a 2-hour plasma glucose level of ≥140 mg/dL after a 75 g glucose challenge, irrespective of fasting or prandial state.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ≥120 mg/dL: Incorrect. A glucose level of 120 mg/dL indicates decreased glucose tolerance but does not confirm GDM.

 

Option C. ≥153 mg/dL: Incorrect. This value is used in other OGTT protocols, not DIPSI.

 

Option D. ≥200 mg/dL: Incorrect. A glucose level of ≥200 mg/dL indicates overt diabetes, not GDM.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The DIPSI test is widely used in India for GDM screening, with a 2-hour post-glucose threshold of ≥140 mg/dL for diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman presents with a non-productive cough and pleuritic chest pain. She had a Coxsackie B virus infection one month ago, which resolved. Her temperature is 38.7°C.

 

Investigations:

 

  • ECG: 

 

 

Which is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) NSAID + colchicine

 

This patient has acute pericarditis, which is confirmed by:

 

  • Pleuritic chest pain (worsens with inspiration, improves when sitting up and leaning forward).
  • Recent viral infection (Coxsackie B virus is a common cause of viral pericarditis).
  • Fever (suggests inflammation).
  • ECG findings:
    • Widespread concave ST elevation
    • PR depression (specific for pericarditis)

 

Management of Acute Pericarditis:

 

  • First-line treatment: NSAIDs (e.g., ibuprofen) + colchicine to reduce inflammation and prevent recurrence.
  • Colchicine lowers recurrence rates significantly.
  • Steroids are reserved for refractory cases or contraindications to NSAIDs.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD): Used for ventricular arrhythmias or severe heart failure, not acute pericarditis.

 

Option C. Pericardiectomy: Reserved for constrictive pericarditis, a chronic condition, not acute pericarditis.

 

Option D. Pericardiocentesis: Only indicated if cardiac tamponade develops (Beck’s triad: hypotension, JVP elevation, muffled heart sounds).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Acute pericarditis, often post-viral, presents with pleuritic chest pain, widespread concave ST elevation, and PR depression. 
  • First-line treatment is NSAIDs + colchicine to relieve inflammation and prevent recurrence.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is on theophylline therapy for bronchodilation. He develops nausea, vomiting, tachycardia, and tremors after being prescribed an antibiotic for a respiratory infection. Laboratory results show elevated theophylline levels. Which of the following antibiotics is least likely to cause theophylline toxicity?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Amoxicillin

 

  • Theophylline is metabolized by cytochrome P450 (CYP1A2, CYP3A4).
  • Drugs that inhibit these enzymes (e.g., ciprofloxacin, erythromycin, cimetidine) can reduce theophylline clearance, leading to toxicity.
  • Amoxicillin does not inhibit CYP enzymes and does not interact with theophylline metabolism, making it the safest choice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ciprofloxacin: A potent CYP1A2 inhibitor, reduces theophylline metabolism, increasing toxicity risk.

 

Option C. Erythromycin: Inhibits CYP3A4, leading to decreased theophylline clearance and increased toxicity.

 

Option D. Cimetidine: A strong CYP1A2 and CYP3A4 inhibitor, known to significantly increase theophylline levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ciprofloxacin, erythromycin, and cimetidine inhibit the metabolism of theophylline, increasing its toxicity risk. 
  • Amoxicillin does not affect CYP enzymes and is the safest antibiotic for patients on theophylline therapy.

questions.text: A placenta is examined after delivery, and the pathology shown in the provided image is identified. What is the most likely diagnosis of this placental pathology?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Circumvallate placenta

 

  • Circumvallate placenta is a placental abnormality characterized by a thickened, opaque, gray-white circular ridge on the maternal side. 
  • This ridge is composed of a double fold of chorion and amnion, leading to a raised and rolled margin. 
  • It is associated with adverse outcomes, including vaginal bleeding, preterm delivery, and intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Battledore placenta: In battledore placenta, the umbilical cord is attached to the placental margin, resembling the shape of a badminton racket. This condition is not associated with a thickened ridge or rolled margin.

 

 

Option C. Circummarginate placenta: Circummarginate placenta is a less severe form of circumvallate placenta, where the chorion and amnion do not form a raised ridge but lie flat over the placenta.

 

 

Option D. Velamentous placenta: Velamentous placenta involves insertion of the umbilical cord into the membranes instead of directly into the placental disk, resulting in unprotected vessels traversing the membranes. This is unrelated to the features shown in the image.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Circumvallate placenta is characterized by a thickened, raised margin formed by a double fold of chorion and amnion, and it is associated with adverse pregnancy outcomes such as vaginal bleeding and preterm delivery.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman in her second trimester of pregnancy presents for a routine prenatal visit. Her blood test reveals a hemoglobin level of 8.5 g/dL. According to the WHO classification, how is this anemia categorized in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Moderate anemia

 

  • According to the WHO classification of anemia in pregnancy, a hemoglobin level between 7 and 9.9 g/dL is defined as moderate anemia. 
  • This range is specifically set to identify pregnant women who may require more intensive monitoring or intervention to manage their anemia and minimize risks to both the mother and the fetus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mild Anemia: Incorrect as mild anemia in pregnancy is defined by a hemoglobin level between 10 and 10.9 g/dL.

 

Option C. Severe anemia: Incorrect because severe anemia is categorized by a hemoglobin level less than 7 g/dL.

 

Option D. Not classified as anemia: Incorrect as a hemoglobin level of 8.5 g/dL is clearly within the range classified as anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Moderate anemia, defined by hemoglobin levels between 7 and 9.9 g/dL, typically requires closer monitoring and possibly intervention to ensure maternal and fetal health.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man with mantle cell lymphoma (MCL) undergoes bone marrow biopsy, which shows interstitial and nodular lymphoid infiltrates. He has worsening fatigue and progressive cytopenias. His laboratory results show:

  • Hemoglobin: 8.9 g/dL
  • Platelets: 75,000/µL
  • WBC count: 9,500/µL
  • LDH: Elevated

Which of the following most strongly predicts a poor prognosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) High Ki-67 proliferation index

 

  • A high Ki-67 index (>30-40%) in MCL indicates a highly proliferative and aggressive variant known as blastoid or pleomorphic MCL, which has a worse prognosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Presence of t(14;18) translocation: Incorrect. Seen in follicular lymphoma, not MCL.

 

Option C. CD23 expression: Incorrect. CD23 is negative in MCL but positive in CLL/SLL, helping to differentiate the two.

 

Option D. Peripheral blood smudge cells: Incorrect. Smudge cells are a feature of CLL, not MCL.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A high Ki-67 proliferation index in mantle cell lymphoma correlates with a more aggressive disease course and worse prognosis.

questions.text: Match the Following Question
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-B, 2-D, 3-C, 4-E, 5-A

 

Testicular descent follows a well-defined timeline during fetal development:

 

  • 1-B: Iliac fossa (3rd month): The testes begins its descent from the lumbar region.
  • 2-D: Deep inguinal ring (End of 6th month): It moves down towards the deep inguinal ring.
  • 3-C: Inguinal canal (7th month): The testes passes through the inguinal canal.
  • 4-E: Superficial inguinal ring (End of 8th month): It reaches the superficial inguinal ring.

  • 5-A: Scrotum (9th month): The testes finally descends into the scrotum before birth.

     

Educational Objective:

questions.text:
A 15-year-old boy presents with:

 

  • Bone pain
  • Fatigue
  • Easy bruising for the past 4 months

 

Examination findings:

 

  • Multiple petechiae on his skin
  • Palpable lymph nodes in the axilla and neck bilaterally
  • Hepatosplenomegaly

 

Investigations:

 

  • Platelets: 123 × 10⁹/L (Normal: 150–400)
  • Neutrophils: 1.1 × 10⁹/L (Normal: 1.5–7.0)
  • Peripheral smear: 

 

 

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acute lymphoblastic leukaemia

 

  • The patient's presentation is consistent with acute lymphoblastic leukaemia (ALL), the most common type of cancer in children. Here's why:
    • Bone pain, fatigue, and easy bruising: These are common symptoms of bone marrow failure, which occurs in ALL when abnormal lymphoid progenitor cells proliferate uncontrollably, crowding out normal blood cells.
    • Petechiae and ecchymoses: These are signs of thrombocytopenia, a common feature in ALL due to the bone marrow being infiltrated by leukemic cells, leading to a reduction in platelet production.
    • Lymphadenopathy (palpable axillary and cervical lymph nodes) and hepatosplenomegaly: These are common signs of lymphoid infiltration seen in ALL. Leukemic cells can infiltrate various organs, including lymph nodes, liver, and spleen.
    • Neutropenia: Low neutrophil count in the context of ALL reflects bone marrow suppression due to infiltration by malignant lymphoid cells.
  • ALL is characterized by the malignant transformation of lymphoid progenitor cells (often B-cells or T-cells), leading to the uncontrolled proliferation of these cells and subsequent infiltration of various organs. 
  • This results in symptoms like fatigue, bone pain, and signs of bone marrow failure (anemia, neutropenia, thrombocytopenia).

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Acute myeloid leukaemia (AML): While AML also presents with bone pain, fatigue, and pancytopenia (including neutropenia and thrombocytopenia), the lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly in this patient make ALL more likely. AML usually presents more acutely and is less commonly associated with lymphadenopathy in children.

 

Option C. Hodgkin’s lymphoma: Hodgkin’s lymphoma typically presents with painless lymphadenopathy, and it is less likely to cause bone pain, easy bruising, and neutropenia in the absence of significant fever, night sweats, or weight loss. Hepatosplenomegaly is not a classic finding in Hodgkin's lymphoma, and ALL is far more common in children.

 

Option D. Multiple myeloma: Multiple myeloma is a plasma cell malignancy typically seen in older adults and presents with symptoms like bone pain, renal failure, and hypercalcemia, but it does not typically present with lymphadenopathy, neutropenia, or thrombocytopenia in children.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Acute lymphoblastic leukaemia (ALL) is the most common pediatric malignancy, and it presents with symptoms of bone marrow failure, such as fatigue, bone pain, easy bruising, and pancytopenia (including neutropenia and thrombocytopenia).
  • Lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly are common signs of lymphoid infiltration seen in ALL.
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by bone marrow biopsy and flow cytometry to identify abnormal lymphoid cells.
  • Treatment involves chemotherapy, and the prognosis is generally favorable with early diagnosis and treatment.

questions.text:
A 49-year-old man presents with:

 

  • Bilateral, intermittent hand pain and morning stiffness for 5 months.
  • History of Hashimoto thyroiditis (managed with levothyroxine).

Examination:

 

  • Swelling and tenderness in the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints.
  • Pain on metacarpophalangeal (MCP) squeeze test

 

Investigations:

 

  • X-ray image is shown below, 

 

 

Which is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Methotrexate

 

  • This presentation is highly suggestive of rheumatoid arthritis (RA), a chronic autoimmune inflammatory arthritis.

 

Key Features of Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA):

 

  • Bilateral, inflammatory arthritis in the hands (PIP and MCP joints affected).
  • Morning stiffness lasting >1 hour, improving with movement.
  • Painful MCP squeeze test → Suggests active synovitis.
  • Hashimoto thyroiditis → RA and Hashimoto’s thyroiditis are both autoimmune diseases and commonly coexist.
    X-ray findings:
  • Joint space narrowing → Due to cartilage loss.
  • Osteopenia near PIP joints → Due to periarticular bone resorption.

 

Management of Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA):

 

  • First-line treatment: Methotrexate (a DMARD) → Slows disease progression and prevents joint deformity.
  • Short-term corticosteroids (e.g., prednisolone) → Used as a bridging therapy until DMARDs take effect.
  • NSAIDs for symptom relief, but do not prevent disease progression.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Colchicine: Used for gout, which presents with acute monoarthritis, not chronic polyarthritis.

 

Option B. Exercise and NSAIDs: NSAIDs help with pain, but they do not modify disease progression. RA requires a DMARD (like methotrexate) to prevent joint destruction.

 

Option D. Paracetamol: Useful for osteoarthritis, but does not treat inflammatory arthritis or prevent joint damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) presents with bilateral PIP and MCP joint pain, morning stiffness, and periarticular osteopenia on X-ray. 
  • Methotrexate is the first-line disease-modifying treatment to slow disease progression and prevent joint deformities.

choices.text: Transverse of oblique fractures of long bones

questions.text: Locking compression plating is commonly indicated in which of the following fracture types?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Periarticular fractures

 

LOCKING COMPRESSION PLATING 

 

  • For long bone fracture, intramedullary implant is more suitable.
  • Periarticular fractures involve the joints or the areas around them, such as the distal femur or proximal tibia. 
  • These fractures often require stable fixation to allow for early mobilization and prevent joint stiffness or instability.
  • Locking compression plates offer advantages in periarticular fractures due to their ability to provide stable fixation even in osteoporotic bone or in cases where there is poor bone stock.
  • The locking screws create a fixed-angle construct, which enhances stability and minimizes the risk of implant failure or loosening.
  • Advantages of locking plates are:
    • Osteopenic bones 
    • Metaphyseal areas
    • Periprosthetic fractures
    • Failed fixation (non-union)

 

 

Closed reduction and internal fixation 

 

 

Locking compression plate

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Transverse or oblique fractures of long bones: While traditional compression plating is effective for these fracture types, LCPs can also be used, particularly in cases of poor bone quality or when added stability is desired. LCP's can be used here, but traditional compression plating is also very common.

 

Option C. Intertrochanteric fractures: Intertrochanteric fractures occur at the proximal end of the femur, typically between the greater trochanter and the lesser trochanter. Intertrochanteric fractures are often managed with devices like intramedullary nails or dynamic hip screws, which are specifically designed for these types of fractures.

 

Option D. Fracture of long bones: The choice of fixation depends on various factors such as the location and type of fracture, patient's age, bone quality, and surgeon's preference. While locking compression plating may be suitable for certain long bone fractures, other options like intramedullary nails, external fixation, or conventional compression plates may also be considered depending on the specific case.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Locking compression plating is commonly indicated in the periarticular type fractures.

choices.text: Ingestion of egg in contaminated water

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with complaints of diarrhea, abdominal pain, and eosinophilia. He reports a history of drinking water from an untreated source while traveling in a rural area. A stool examination reveals the characteristic egg, shown in the image. What is the mode of transmission and the infective form of the parasite responsible for this infection?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ingestion of egg in contaminated water

 

  • The egg shown in the picture is of a Trichuris trichura also called as pin worm. 
  • The mode of transmission is ingestion of the fertilised egg. 
  • The way to identify the egg is that is barrel shaped with mucus plugs in the end which is typical for this worm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ingestion of uncooked/raw beef: 

 

  • This mode of transmission is associated with Taenia saginata (beef tapeworm), which is acquired by consuming cysticerci (larval stage) in raw or undercooked beef.
  • However, Taenia species do not produce the eggs shown in the picture. 

 

Option C. Penetration by filariform larva: 

 

  • This transmission mode is associated with hookworms (Necator americanus, Ancylostoma duodenale) and Strongyloides stercoralis.
  • The filariform larvae penetrate the skin (commonly via bare feet), migrate to the lungs, and then to the intestines.
  • However, these parasites produce non-operculated eggs, making this choice incorrect.

 

Option D. Penetration by rhabditiform larva: 

 

  • Strongyloides stercoralis produces rhabditiform larvae in the stool, which can mature into filariform larvae and cause autoinfection.
  • However, Strongyloides does not produce the eggs shown in the picture making this choice incorrect. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Fasciola hepatica is transmitted through ingestion of metacercariae from contaminated water or aquatic plants (e.g., watercress).
  • Its eggs are large, oval, and operculated, distinguishing them from non-operculated eggs of nematodes and cestodes.
  • Other parasites like Taenia, hookworms, and Strongyloides have different transmission mechanisms and egg morphology.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female with a history of fatty food intolerance and episodic right upper quadrant pain is diagnosed with gallstones via ultrasound. She has normal liver function tests and no signs of cholecystitis. What is the most appropriate management strategy for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy

 

  • In patients with symptomatic gallstones, as indicated by fatty food intolerance and episodic pain, elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy is the treatment of choice to prevent future episodes and complications such as acute cholecystitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Medical management with ursodeoxycholic acid: Incorrect because medical management is typically reserved for patients who are poor surgical candidates.

 

Option C. Observation with symptomatic treatment: Incorrect as observation is recommended for asymptomatic gallstones, not symptomatic ones.

 

Option D. Immediate open cholecystectomy: Incorrect because laparoscopic cholecystectomy is preferred over open due to better recovery profiles unless contraindications exist.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Symptomatic gallstones is an indication for elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy to prevent complications and resolve symptoms.

questions.text: Identify the following instruments used during a pelvic surgery for uterine fibroids?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Green Armitage

 

  • The instrument shown in the image has distinct characteristics that align with the Green Armitage forceps: broad jaws and horizontal serrations, which are specifically intended for non-traumatic handling of tissue.
  • The Green Armitage forceps is a specialized instrument commonly used in gynecological surgeries, particularly in procedures like hysterectomy and uterine fibroids. 
  • Its broad, flat, and serrated jaws are designed to grasp delicate tissues such as the uterine vessels or the edges of the uterus without causing damage. 
  • This atraumatic characteristic makes it ideal for use in pelvic and gynecological surgeries, allowing surgeons to securely hold or compress tissue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Allis: Allis forceps have a different design, with a toothed grasping end that holds tissue firmly but can cause trauma to delicate structures. They are often used in procedures where secure traction on tough or connective tissue is required, but they lack the atraumatic, broad jaws seen in Green Armitage forceps.

 

Option C. Kocher: Kocher forceps have serrated jaws with a single, strong tooth at the tip, intended for securely grasping tough tissue or fascia, which can be more traumatic to soft or delicate structures. This design is distinctly different from the atraumatic broad, flat, and serrated jaws of the Green Armitage forceps.

 

Option D. Vulsellum: Vulsellum forceps are toothed forceps often used to grasp the cervix or uterus during gynecologic procedures. The presence of teeth allows for a firm grip on tissue, which can sometimes cause trauma. This toothed design is different from the atraumatic, flat jaws of the Green Armitage forceps shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • The Green Armitage forceps, with broad, flat, and serrated jaws, is used in gynecological surgeries to grasp and stabilize tissue atraumatically, particularly in procedures involving the uterus.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with metabolic acidosis and hyperkalemia. Lab findings show a normal anion gap, low serum aldosterone levels, and impaired NH₃ production. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for his presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Type 4 Renal Tubular Acidosis

 

  • Characterized by hyperkalemia, normal anion gap metabolic acidosis, and impaired NH₃ production.
  • Commonly caused by hypoaldosteronism or aldosterone resistance, leading to reduced H⁺ and K⁺ excretion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type 1 RTA (Distal): Causes hypokalemia and defective H⁺ secretion, leading to an alkaline urine pH (>5.5).

 

Option B. Type 2 RTA (Proximal): Results from defective bicarbonate reabsorption and hypokalemia, with an acidic urine pH after bicarbonate depletion.

 

Option C. Type 3 RTA: Rare and usually seen in genetic disorders involving combined proximal and distal dysfunction.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Type 4 RTA is caused by aldosterone deficiency or resistance, leading to hyperkalemia, impaired NH₃ production, and normal anion gap metabolic acidosis.

choices.text: The district has completely eliminated malaria with zero indigenous cases
The district has an API <1 per 1000 population at risk and is in the elimination phase
The district has a high burden of malaria and requires intensified control measures
The district has no malaria transmission but is at risk of re-establishment

questions.text: A district in India is classified under Category 1 in the National Malaria Elimination Framework. What is the correct interpretation of this classification?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The district has an API <1 per 1000 population at risk and is in the elimination phase

 

  • Category 1 (Elimination phase) refers to states or UTs where API is <1 per 1000 population at risk.
  • The focus in Category 1 is to achieve complete malaria elimination.
  • Category 0 states have already eliminated malaria.
  • Category 3 states have an API >1/1000 and need intensified control.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The district has completely eliminated malaria with zero indigenous cases: Category 0 is for states with zero indigenous cases and a focus on preventing re-establishment.

 

Option C. The district has a high burden of malaria and requires intensified control measures: Category 3 includes states with an API >1/1000, requiring aggressive control.

 

Option D. The district has no malaria transmission but is at risk of re-establishment: Category 0 states have already eliminated malaria and focus on preventing re-introduction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Category 1 states in India’s malaria elimination framework have API <1/1000 and are in the elimination phase. 
  • The goal is to achieve zero indigenous cases.

 

Categories of state/UTs:

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents to the emergency room after a motor vehicle accident. CT scan shows a grade III splenic laceration, without contrast extravasation or evidence of hemodynamic instability. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Non-operative management with close monitoring

 

  • Non-operative management is appropriate for hemodynamically stable patients with splenic injuries, including grade III lacerations. 
  • This approach includes close monitoring of vital signs and hematocrit levels to ensure stability.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immediate splenectomy: Incorrect as immediate splenectomy is reserved for hemodynamically unstable patients or those who fail non-operative management.

 

Option C. Angiography and possible embolization: Incorrect because angiography and embolization are considered if the patient becomes unstable or if there is evidence of ongoing bleeding.

 

Option D. Administration of prophylactic antibiotics: Incorrect as prophylactic antibiotics are not typically indicated in the management of isolated splenic injuries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Non-operative management can be implemented for stable patients with splenic injuries, reserving more invasive measures for signs of instability or failure of conservative management.

choices.text: The test indicates a need for spherical correction

questions.text: During a subjective refraction test, an optometrist places following instrument in front of a 25-year-old patient. The patient states that the vertical lines appear much clearer than the horizontal lines. Which of the following statements correctly interprets the findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) The patient has with-the-rule astigmatism

 

  • With-the-rule astigmatism occurs when the vertical meridian is steeper than the horizontal meridian, causing horizontal blur. 
  • This means the patient sees vertical lines more clearly on the astigmatic fan.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. The patient has against-the-rule astigmatism: Against-the-rule astigmatism occurs when the horizontal meridian is steeper, making vertical lines appear blurry.

 

Option C. The patient has mixed astigmatism: Mixed astigmatism occurs when one meridian is myopic and the other is hyperopic, leading to distorted vision at all angles.

 

Option D. The test indicates a need for spherical correction: Spherical correction is not determined by this test, as it only refines cylindrical errors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • If vertical lines appear clearer than horizontal lines on the astigmatic fan, it suggests with-the-rule astigmatism. 
  • This helps guide the optometrist in refining the cylindrical axis for the best correction.

questions.text: A 14-year-old complains of arm pain following a minor trauma. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Unicameral bone cyst

 

  • A unicameral bone cyst (UBC) is a benign, fluid-filled cavity within the bone.
  • It's most common in children and adolescents, typically in the proximal humerus or femur.
  • Often asymptomatic until a pathologic fracture occurs.
  • It is often asymptomatic.
  • Pain after minor trauma, due to a pathologic fracture.
  • May have mild swelling.
  • Well-defined, lytic lesion in the metaphysis.
  • "Fallen fragment" sign (a fragment of bone within the cyst).
  • The presentation of arm pain following minor trauma is consistent with a pathologic fracture through a UBC.
  • UBC's are very common in the proximal Humerus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Osteosarcoma: Osteosarcoma is a malignant bone tumour that originates from bone-forming cells. It's most common in adolescents and young adults, often occurring during periods of rapid bone growth. It typically arises in the metaphysis of long bones, particularly the femur, tibia, and humerus. Pain, often worse at night. Swelling or a palpable mass. May present after minor trauma, as the tumour weakens the bone. Systemic symptoms like fever or weight loss are less common but can occur. Destructive bone lesion. "Sunburst" or "Codman triangle" appearance (periosteal reaction). While this age range is appropriate for Osteosarcoma, minor trauma leading to pain, is more in line with a benign lesion.

 

Option B. Giant Cell Tumour: Giant cell tumours are typically benign but can be locally aggressive. They usually occur in the epiphysis of long bones, often around the knee. They are more common in adults, particularly in their 20s and 30s, although they can occur in adolescents. Pain and swelling. Limited joint movement. Pathologic fracture can occur. Lytic lesion in the epiphysis. "Soap bubble" appearance can be appreciated. Though it can appear in adolescents, it is more common in adults, and the location of the tumour is usually near the epiphysis.

 

Option C. Fibrous Dysplasia: Fibrous dysplasia is a benign condition where normal bone is replaced with fibrous tissue. It can affect single or multiple bones. It can cause bone deformities and pathologic fractures. Pain, swelling, deformity can be present. It is a pathologic fracture. "Ground-glass" appearance of the bone. Bone expansion and deformity. While it can cause pain after minor trauma, it is more often associated with visible deformities, and the radiographic findings are very characteristic.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A unicameral bone cyst (UBC) is a benign, fluid-filled cavity within the bone. 
  • It Is most common in children and adolescents, typically in the proximal humerus or femur.

questions.text: Dr. Ramesh, a 32-year-old man from Mumbai, presents with excessive bleeding after a dental extraction 4 days ago and frequent spontaneous nosebleeds over the past year. He has multiple minor bruises on his forearms and shins but no history of joint pain or deep muscle hematomas. His maternal uncle had recurrent joint bleeds, and his younger brother has a diagnosed bleeding disorder. Lab results show prolonged aPTT (62 sec), normal PT, and Factor VIII activity of 8%. What is the most likely mode of inheritance of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) X-Linked recessive

 

  • The patient's symptoms, including excessive bleeding, bruising, and prolonged bleeding after tooth extraction, along with the family history of haemophilia A in her father, strongly suggest haemophilia A, an X-linked recessive disorder. Here’s why:
    • Haemophilia A is caused by a deficiency in factor VIII, a clotting factor, and is inherited in an X-linked recessive manner.
    • In X-linked recessive inheritance, males are more commonly affected because they only have one X chromosome, and a single defective copy of the gene on the X chromosome will result in the condition.
    • Females have two X chromosomes, so they would typically need two copies of the defective gene to express the condition. However, females with an affected father and a carrier mother (or an affected mother) can inherit the disease and present with mild to moderate symptoms, as in this case.
    • The girl’s father has haemophilia A, and she likely inherited the defective X chromosome from him, making her a carrier or a mildly affected female.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Autosomal dominant: Haemophilia A is not inherited in an autosomal dominant manner. In autosomal dominant conditions, one copy of the defective gene on any chromosome (not X or Y) would be sufficient to cause the disease, which is not the case here.

 

Option B. Autosomal recessive: Haemophilia A is not autosomal recessive. In autosomal recessive inheritance, both copies of the gene (one from each parent) would need to be defective to cause the condition, which does not fit the pattern for haemophilia.

 

Option C. Mitochondrial: Mitochondrial inheritance involves genes located in the mitochondria, passed only from the mother to all offspring. Haemophilia A is not a mitochondrial disorder, and inheritance follows the X-linked recessive pattern.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Haemophilia A is an X-linked recessive disorder, typically affecting males. Females can be carriers or may have mild symptoms if they inherit the affected X chromosome from their father and a carrier or affected X chromosome from their mother.
  • Symptoms include excessive bleeding, bruising, and prolonged bleeding after injuries or surgeries.
  • Management involves replacement therapy with factor VIII and genetic counselling for family members.

choices.text: A 24-year-old woman with FNAC report of Bethesda category 4
A 60-year-old man with FNAC report of Thy2
A 66-year-old man with positive Pemberton’s sign

questions.text: Patients present in your OPD, with the following reports. To which patient will you least likely advice surgery for thyroid disorder?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A 60-year-old man with FNAC report of Thy2

 

  • FNAC report Thy2 suggests a non-neoplastic origin, meaning it is likely a benign thyroid nodule. 
  • Surgery is not typically recommended for Thy2 lesions, as they are usually benign, unless causing symptoms.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. A 24-year-old woman with FNAC report of Bethesda category 4: Bethesda category 4 on FNAC indicates a suspicious for malignancy finding. This is a strong indication for surgery because there is a concern for potential thyroid cancer.

 

Option C. A 45-year-old with toxic multinodular goitre: Toxic nodular goitre is often large and uncomfortable and enlarges still further with antithyroid drugs. Large goitres should be treated surgically because they do not respond as well or as rapidly to radioiodine or antithyroid drugs as does a diffuse toxic goitre.

 

Option D. A 66-year-old man with positive Pemberton’s sign: A positive Pemberton's sign indicates compression of the neck's venous structures when the arms are elevated, typically due to a large goitre. This sign may indicate the need for surgery to relieve pressure symptoms and improve venous return.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • FNAC Thy2 findings are suggestive of a benign, non-neoplastic thyroid nodule, and surgical intervention is typically not indicated for such cases.

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman presents with recurrent episodes of upper abdominal pain and vomiting. A CT scan finding is shown in the image. Which of the following is the most likely underlying condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gallstone ileus

 

  • Gallstone ileus occurs when a large gallstone erodes through the gallbladder wall, creating a biliary-enteric fistula.
  • Pneumobilia (air in the bile ducts) and an obstructing gallstone in the bowel are classic findings.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Emphysematous cholecystitis: Incorrect. Causes gas in the gallbladder wall, not pneumobilia or duodenal gallstones.

 

Option C. Mirizzi syndrome: Incorrect. Obstruction of the common hepatic duct by an impacted gallstone in the cystic duct, without fistula formation.

 

Option D. Ascending cholangitis: Incorrect. Characterized by biliary obstruction and infection, not a gallstone in the bowel.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Gallstone ileus occurs when a gallstone erodes into the bowel, causing pneumobilia and mechanical obstruction.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male from a rural community in Central India presents to the clinic with a 6-month history of progressive stiffness and spasticity in his lower limbs. He reports no loss of sensation, changes in cognition, or bladder dysfunction. Dietary history reveals a significant consumption of a local legume, shown in the image, as a staple. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lathyrism

 

  • Lathyrism is caused by chronic consumption of Lathyrus sativus, which contains the neurotoxin BOAA (β-N-Oxalyl-L-α,β-diaminopropionic acid). 
  • This toxin predominantly affects the corticospinal and spinocerebellar tracts, leading to a clinical presentation characterized by symmetrical spastic paralysis, particularly in the lower limbs, without sensory or cognitive impairment. 
  • The dietary history and clinical presentation align with neurolathyrism, making it the most likely diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Multiple sclerosis: Multiple sclerosis typically presents with episodes of neurological deficits that may include sensory loss, optic neuritis, and changes in cognition, which do not match the patient’s symptoms focused solely on spasticity without sensory involvement.

 

Option B. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis involves both upper and lower motor neuron signs such as muscle weakness, atrophy, and fasciculations, alongside spasticity. The absence of muscle atrophy and the specific dietary link make ALS less likely.

 

Option D. Guillain-Barré syndrome: Guillain-Barré syndrome presents with ascending paralysis, often starting from the feet and moving upwards, and is associated with autonomic dysfunction or preceding infectious illness, not chronic dietary exposure.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Lathyrism results from chronic consumption of the Lathyrus sativus legume, containing the neurotoxin BOAA, which specifically affects motor neurons and leads to spastic paralysis, especially of the lower limbs, without affecting sensory or cognitive functions. 
  • Awareness of dietary habits is crucial in diagnosing neurolathyrism in regions where Lathyrus is commonly consumed.

questions.text: A 10-day-old neonate presents with bilateral mucopurulent eye discharge and mild eyelid swelling. Gram stain is negative, but Giemsa stain reveals intracellular inclusions. What is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Oral erythromycin

 

  • The delayed onset (7–14 days) of mucopurulent conjunctivitis and intracellular inclusions on Giemsa stain strongly suggest Chlamydia trachomatis conjunctivitis (D-K serotypes). 
  • This infection also predisposes neonates to chlamydial pneumonia, so systemic therapy (oral erythromycin) is required.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Topical ciprofloxacin: Used for bacterial conjunctivitis, but Chlamydia requires systemic treatment.

 

Option C. IV ceftriaxone: Used for gonococcal conjunctivitis, which presents earlier (3–5 days) with profuse purulent discharge.

 

Option D. Topical acyclovir: Used for herpetic conjunctivitis (5–7 days), which presents with vesicles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Chlamydial conjunctivitis presents at 7–14 days with mucopurulent discharge. Intracellular inclusions on Giemsa stain confirm the diagnosis. 
  • Treatment requires oral erythromycin to prevent pneumonia.

 

Neonatal Conjunctivitis

choices.text: Deficiency of complement C1 esterase inhibitor

questions.text:
A 2-month-old male presents with severe failure to thrive, chronic diarrhea, and recurrent infections (Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia, persistent oral thrush). Laboratory tests show:

  • Lymphocyte count: 200 cells/µL
  • Serum IgG, IgA, IgM: Absent
  • Flow cytometry: Absent T and B cells

Which of the following is the most likely genetic defect in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Deficiency of adenosine deaminase (ADA)

 

  • This patient has Severe Combined Immunodeficiency (SCID), presenting with:
    • Recurrent opportunistic infections (PCP, Candida, viral infections)
    • Absent T and B cells
    • Hypogammaglobulinemia
  • ADA deficiency is a common cause of SCID, leading to the accumulation of toxic purine metabolites, resulting in T and B cell apoptosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Defective BTK gene: Incorrect. BTK mutation causes X-linked agammaglobulinemia (Bruton disease), which only affects B cells, not T cells.

 

Option C. Mutation in FOXP3: Incorrect. FOXP3 mutation causes IPEX syndrome (immune dysregulation, polyendocrinopathy, enteropathy, X-linked).
