Option D. Deficiency of complement C1 esterase inhibitor: Incorrect. C1 esterase inhibitor deficiency causes hereditary angioedema, not SCID.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • ADA deficiency causes SCID by impairing lymphocyte survival, leading to severe combined B and T cell immunodeficiency.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with schizophrenia has been taking chlorpromazine for the past six months. Which of the following side effects is least likely to be caused by chlorpromazine?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Osteoporosis

 

  • Chlorpromazine is a first-generation (typical) antipsychotic that blocks dopamine D2 receptors in the CNS.
  • It is associated with multiple side effects, including extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS), hyperprolactinemia, and dermatologic reactions.
  • Osteoporosis is not a commonly recognized adverse effect of chlorpromazine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Drug-induced Parkinsonism: Chlorpromazine blocks dopamine in the nigrostriatal pathway, leading to parkinsonian symptoms (resting tremors, rigidity, bradykinesia).

 

Option C. Skin rash: Chlorpromazine is associated with photosensitivity and skin pigmentation disorders.

 

Option D. Amenorrhea: D2 blockade increases prolactin secretion, leading to hyperprolactinemia, which causes amenorrhea and galactorrhea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Chlorpromazine can cause extrapyramidal symptoms (drug-induced Parkinsonism), hyperprolactinemia (amenorrhea), and dermatologic side effects (skin rash, photosensitivity). 
  • It is not associated with osteoporosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a sign of dehydration in an infant:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Peri-anal excoriation

 

  • Dehydration in infants is classified based on clinical signs and symptoms, which help guide fluid management. The key signs of dehydration include:
    • Decreased urine output (oliguria)
    • Sunken eyeballs (due to loss of tissue turgor)
    • Thirst (compensatory mechanism to restore fluid balance)
  • Peri-anal excoriation is not a sign of dehydration; instead, it is commonly associated with lactose intolerance, where acidic stools lead to skin breakdown in the perianal region.

 

Classification of Dehydration (WHO Guidelines)

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Decreased urine output: A hallmark feature of dehydration due to reduced renal perfusion.

 

Option C. Sunken eyeballs: Seen in moderate to severe dehydration, indicating fluid loss from interstitial spaces.

 

Option D. Thirst: One of the earliest signs of dehydration; severe dehydration can impair the ability to drink.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Dehydration in infants is diagnosed clinically, and early recognition is crucial for appropriate rehydration therapy (ORS or IV fluids based on severity).

questions.text: A 32-year-old HIV-positive male presents with persistent cough and weight loss. His sputum smear microscopy is negative, but tuberculosis is still suspected. Under NTEP guidelines, which of the following tests should be performed next for rapid confirmation of TB?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cartridge-Based Nucleic Acid Amplification Test (CBNAAT)

 

  • CBNAAT (GeneXpert) is the preferred diagnostic test in sputum smear-negative TB cases, particularly in HIV-positive patients.
  • It provides rapid results and simultaneously detects rifampicin resistance, which is crucial for managing TB in immunocompromised individuals.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Solid LJ Medium Culture: Culture takes several weeks to provide results, making it less useful for rapid diagnosis.

 

Option B. Line Probe Assay (LPA): LPA is used to detect drug resistance but is not the first test for smear-negative TB cases.

 

Option D. Standardized Tuberculin Skin Test: Tuberculin skin tests can indicate prior TB exposure but cannot differentiate active TB from latent TB.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • CBNAAT (GeneXpert) is the preferred rapid molecular diagnostic test for TB, especially in HIV-positive and smear-negative cases.

 

TB Diagnosis Under RNTCP
